From this passage it is made evident that in the external man, of which alone a man becomes conscious in this life, there are three most distinct parts; namely, the Corporeal, or the body; the Natural; and the Rational; and it appears further, that in the Rational there are interior goods and truths; and in the Natural there are on the one hand intermediate goods and truths, and, on the other, exterior goods and truths; so that the Natural by itself is again bipartite. The same applies to the memory; for there is the interior memory which belongs to the Rational; and again there is the exterior memory which belongs to the Natural; but if the Natural by itself is bipartite, the same applies also to the memory; wherefore in the exterior memory, just as in the Natural, there are two degrees, of which the one, as we have seen above (no. 250), is the natural degree proper, and the other the sensual degree.

The constituents of the External man, as we have further seen, are both volitional and intellectual; for the contents of both the interior and the exterior memory are goods and truths of which the former have reference to the will, and the latter to the understanding; and this distinction extends as far as the corporeal part where two of the senses, sight and hearing, according to Swedenborg, minister to mans intellectual part, and the three remaining senses to his will-part. Nevertheless, man, as he is now constituted, becomes conscious chiefly of the intellectual ingredients of the memory. These Swedenborg arranges distinctly into three classes, for which he uses the following appellations:--

382

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 383

(1) sensations or sensuous impressions (sensualia), sensuous scientifics, and sensuous truths; (2) scientifics, natural scientifics and scientific truths; (3) doctrinal or rational truths, or truths simply. The relations between these three degrees in the memory, which are identical with those of the external or natural man in general, are exhibited clearly in the following passage:--

Sensuous impressions (sensualia) are one thing, scientifics another, and truths still another thing. They succeed each other mutually; for scientifics exist from sensuous impressions, and truths from scientifics. For the things which enter through the senses are stored up in the memory; and from them the man concludes the scientific, or from them he perceives the scientific which he is learning. From scientifics afterwards he concludes truths, that is, from them he perceives the truth which he is learning.

In this wise also every man progresses from boyhood (pueritia), as he is growing up. So long as he is a mere lad (puer) he thinks and grasps things from sensuous impressions. As he advances in age he thinks and grasps things from scientifics; and afterwards from truths. This is the road to judgment which increases in man by age.

Hence it may appear that sensuous impressions, scientifics, and truths are distinct things; yea, that they also remain so distinct, that a man sometimes is in sensations or sensuous impressions, as is the cave when he thinks of nothing except what strikes the senses (sensualia); that at another time he is in scientifics, which occurs when he raises himself above the impressions of the senses, and thinks more interiorly; and that at still another time he is in the truths which are concluded from scientifics, as is the case when he thinks more interiorly still (A. C. 5774).

257. Sensuous impressions and scientifics are in the exterior memory, and rational truths in the interior memory. In the exterior memory, however, prevails the light of the world; while in the interior memory prevails the light of heaven. For the interior memory is in the rational part, and the rational part is nearest to the internal man, which is bathed in the light of heaven.

383

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 384

This latter light streams from the internal man into the rational part, and enlightens there the interior memory. On this subject we read:--

The lowest truths, that is, the truths of the exterior Natural, are called scientifics, because they are in the natural, i.e., the external memory of man; and because they participate for the most part of the light of the world.... Those things, however, which belong to the interior memory, are not called scientifics, but truths, so far as they participate of the light of heaven (A. C. 5212).

Again we read:--

Those things which belong to the natural mind [or part], for the most part are in the light of the world, which light is called natural lumen; but the things in the rational mind [or part] are in the light of heaven, which light is spiritual light (A. C. 7130).

Now, since man, as we have seen above, in proportion as he advances in age, progresses from sensations, or sensuous impressions, to scientifics, and from scientifics to truths, it follows that at the same rate in which he advances from scientifics to truths, that is, in which from scientifics he concludes truths, he sees things in spiritual, and no longer in natural light. This follows plainly from what Swedenborg states in what follows:--

When truth is raised out of the natural into the rational part, it is taken out of the sphere of the light of the world, into the sphere of heavenly light; and thus, as it were, out of the darkness of night into the clearness of day. The things of the light of the world, indeed, in which are all natural things, are respectively in night, compared with those things which belong to the light of heaven. The things in this latter light are spiritual, and these things are respectively in daylight (A. C. 3190).

258. Again, there is a difference between the natural light which enlightens the natural scientifics, in the natural degree proper, and that light which enlightens the sensuous scientifics, that is, the sensuous impressions in the exterior natural degree which is called the sensual degree. For sensuous impressions, scientifics sad truths are related like generals, particulars and singulars, as is shown by Swedenborg in what follows:--

384

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 385

The more exterior a thing is, the more general also it is; and the more interior, the less general--so that interior things are respectively called particulars and singulars. The case with generals is so, that they are called generals, because they consist of particulars; and, consequently, because they contain in themselves particulars. Generals apart from particulars, are not generals; but they are called so from particulars....

Thus it is with man and his faculties, which are general in proportion as they are exterior; for they consist of interior faculties, and these again of inmost faculties in their order. The body itself, and the things belonging to the body, such as are called external sensations and actions, are most general respectively. The natural mind, and the things belonging to that mind, are less general, because they are interior; they are called particulars. But the rational mind, and the things belonging to that mind are more interior still, sand are respectively singulars. This appears to the life when a man is divested of his body, and becomes a spirit; for then it becomes manifest to him, that his bodily or corporeal thing were nothing else than the most general things of those which belonged to his spirit; and, further, that corporeal things existed and subsisted from those which belonged to his spirit that the things belonging to the spirit, therefore, are respectively particulars. And when this same spirit becomes an angel, and is elevated into heaven, then those things which he saw and felt before in general, and thus in obscurity, he now sees and feels in clearness; for he then perceives innumerable things, which he had seen and felt before as a one.

This also becomes manifest to the man himself, during his life in the world. The things which he sees and feels in childhood are most general; but those things which he sees and feels while a youth and a young man are the particulars of these generals while the he sees and feels in adult age are the singulars of the particulars. For in proportion as a man advances in age he instills particulars into the generals of childhood, and afterwards singulars into these particulars; for he progresses successively towards interior things, and fills generals with particulars, and particulars with singulars (A. C. 4348).

259. From this passage it follows that what is exterior is related to what is interior, as generals are related to particulars.

385

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 386

Such, therefore, is the relation which exists between sensuous impressions and scientifics, and again between scientifics and rational truths and such, consequently, is also the relation which exists between the light which prevails in the sensual degree, and that which prevails in the natural degree proper. The former light, therefore, is grosser and more general than the latter light.

This, however, is not the only difference which exists between the light of the sensual degree, and that which prevails in the natural degree proper. Another difference arises from the fact that light in the mind is not alone; but that it is qualified by the heat--the love, which prevails in each of the degrees of the mind. Thus a different kind of light prevails is mans sensual degree during infancy and childhood so long as the good of innocence and charity are still a prevailing feature there; compared with the state of the sensual degree after a man has reached his age of maturity, and has entered upon the use of his own freedom and rationality, when the goods and truths of childhood and early youth, are withdrawn from the outward parts of his external man towards the interior; as appears from what follows:--

As a man, in his adolescent age, begins to think for himself, and to act accordingly he cell no longer be kept in charity, as heretofore for he calls forth hereditary evils, by which he suffers himself to be led. When this state arrives the goods of charity and of innocence, which he had previously received, are exterminated, and indeed in the same proportion as the man thinks evils and confirms them by act; and yet these goods ace not exterminated, but they are withdrawn by the Lord towards the interiors, and are there stored up (A. C. 5343).

260. The change caused in the sensual degree by the withdrawal of the good of remains (see above no. 191 et. seq.), entails a change in the spirits who are associated with man in his sensual degree;

386

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 387

for the good spirits and angels who are attendant upon children and youths, while the sensual degreethe first degree of their external man--is being opened and developed in them, retire from this degree in the exact proportion in which the goods and truths of remains are withdrawn from it; and their place is taken by evil spirits of hell, who take up their abode in the evils and falsities which then accumulate in the sensual degree. A change in associate spirits, however, entails a change in spiritual light; for spirits are the medium through whom light is communicated to man from the spiritual world in a form accommodated to the state of a mans mind, so far as it is formed either of goods and truths, or of evils and falsities (see above no. 249). The degree of light in either case remains the same; that is, the light communicated to infants, children and youths through their associate spirits and angels is still sensuous lumen, but of such a quality as prevails in heaven; while, after the withdrawal of the goods and truths of remains from the sensual degree, it becomes the recipient of that sensual lumen which prevails in hell, and which from hell emanates into the lower sphere of the world of spirits. Such a lumen is communicated to mans sensual degree before his regeneration, and also during the earlier stages of regeneration. The quality of this sensual lumen, according to Swedenborg, is as follows:--

Each division of mans interiors has a distinct light (lumen) and a distinct heat. The sensual degree has a comparatively gross light (S. D. 4627).

When a man is in this light, his thought is almost in the same light in which his external sight is; and he is then nearly in the body. The men who are in this light, are to be called sensual; for they do not think beyond the sensations of the body. What is beyond, they do not perceive, nor believe. They believe only what they see and touch. In this lumen are those who have not cultivated at all their interior [faculties], living in neglect and contempt of all things which are rational and spiritual. In this light are especially misers and adulterers;

387

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 388

further, those who have lived in mere pleasures, and in slothful ease. Hence such persons think filthy things, and concerning the holy things of the Church even scandalous things. The hells are in this light. In this light are also some who are not so bad; that is, who were not avaricious, adulterers and voluptuaries, but who have become such because they did not cultivate their rational faculty (A. C. 6310, 6311).

The case in general is that sensual lumen, or light appears to the ignorant as spiritual light. In this light it is not known whether a statement is made simply from the memory, or from the understanding moreover sensual light is more resplendent than interior light), because it exists in the world. Those, especially, who are in evil are in the sensual light, and they are more cunning than others wherefore by the Ancients they were called serpents, because they call reason more adroitly than the rest (S. D. 6708).

Whoever is in this gross light, namely, in the sensual, is also in the pleasures of the beds and of the senses, because they, are the first things of life, and he is also in such scientifics, as serve to promote these things. When a person thinks of the truths of faith, of heaven, and of Divine things from this lumen, he considers them of no account, and rejects them, as being things that may indeed be talked about, but that have no reality, because he cannot see, and touch them. He believes only his senses. Such sensual men are at present in great number in the world.... The sensual lumen is of this character, because all who are in the world of spirits from hell are in such a lumen; and whenever any one is in this lumen, he is in consort, in the world of spirits, with the infernal crew (S. D. 4627).

Those who are in the sensual lumen, most rarely, if ever, are able to be in good and truth; that is, are able to have good and truth for an end; consequently, they cannot have for an end the country, nor justice, but only themselves, their own gain and their own honor.... I was let into this lumen; and as often as I came into it, evil and falsity, scandals against God and heaven, and against good and truth filthy and nasty things, and especially lascivious things flow in. The reason is, that spirits who are of such a character, are in this light, and how in (S. D. 4629).

When a man, therefore, is being regenerated, the truths of faith and the goods of charity are insinuated by the Lord into those things which belong to sensual light and heat. These things, together with still more interior things, are then contained in the above.

388

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 389

For spiritual light is then in the sensual lumen, and leads it, as the soul the body (S. D. 4627).

261. Concerning the light that prevails in the degree immediately above the sensual degree, called the natural or interior-natural degree, Swedenborg says:--

When a man is raised above this sensual lumen, as is the case when he is drawn, or led away a little from the impressions received from the senses, he comes into a more interior light which does not belong to the sensual, but to the interior-natural degree. When a man is in this light, he is in a better state, and he is then in a condition in which he can observe sensuous impressions, that is, their quality and their causes (S. D.4627).

When a man is raised towards the interiors, he comes out of the gross sensual lumen, into a milder light; and he is then led away at the same time, from the influx of scandalous and filthy things, and is taken nearer to those things which belong to what is just and fair; because nearer to the angels who are with him, and thus nearer to the light of heaven. This elevation was known to the Ancients, and even to the Gentiles, wherefore their sophi said, that when the lower mind (animus) is led away from the things pertaining to the senses, it comes into a more inward light, and at the same time into a tranquil state and into a certain heavenly blessedness.

A man can be raised more interiorly still, and the more interiorly he rises, the clearer the light into which he comes; and at last he comes into the light of heaven; which light is nothing else than wisdom and intelligence from the Lord (A. C. 6313).

So long as a man lives in this world, it is not possible for him to be permanently raised above the light or lumen, which prevails in the sensual degree. Whenever in his thoughts and affections he approaches the things of this world, and when his attention is absorbed by them, he cannot help coming into, and abiding temporarily in, sensual lumen; yet, his essential dwelling-place, as to his thoughts and affections, is above the sensual degree; and whenever a man who is undergoing regeneration is beginning to be infested by the states which are inherent in the sensual degree, by the Divine mercy of the Lord, he is raised into a higher lumen or light;

389

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 390

as Swedenborg states in what follows:--

The man who in this life, through the good of faith, has been elevated above the things belonging to the senses, is alternately in the sensual lumen, and in a higher lumen. When absorbed by worldly cares, or when in it company where external things rule, or again, when in the enjoyment of pleasures, he is in the sensual state. In this state he is averse to, and avoids speaking and thinking about God and the things belonging to faith; and should he talk and think about them, he would not consider them of any consequence, unless at the very instant he is raised by the Lord towards the interiors. When such a man is not absorbed by worldly things, but is in an interior lumen, he thinks from what is just and fair; and if he is in a still higher lumen, he thinks from spiritual truth and good. He who is in the good of life is raised from one lumen into another; and as soon as he begins to think evilly he is instantaneously raised into an interior light; for the angels are near him (A. C. 6315).

262. A more inward light still into which a man may be raised, is that of the rational degree, which is the highest degree of the external man. This degree receives light immediately out of heaven. Since this degree is at the same time the highest degree of the natural, that is, the external man, this degree is also called by Swedenborg the spiritual-natural degree, as in the following passage:--

If a man is able to think more interiorly still, he comes into a still more inward light; namely, into that of the spiritual-natural degree. This light exists partly from the light of heaven in natural light (S. D. 4627).

Of these three kinds of light, namely, the sensual lumen, the interior-natural light, and the light of the rational or spiritual-natural degree, a man may become conscious during his life in the natural world; but although there are more interior kinds of light still, by which the degrees of the internal or spiritual man are illuminated, so long as a man carries about with him his gross, material body, he is unable to become conscious of any higher, spiritual elevation, and thus of the opening of any higher, spiritual degree within him than the rational degree.

390

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 391

The rational mind or degree, however, by continuity may be raised to the level of the spiritual degree or mind, and even as far as the celestial degree and thus may be enlightened thence; yet the enlightenment is received then by the rational degree, and it strikes the man simply as an additional development of the rational mind. On this subject we read:--

Every man is born into the faculty of understanding truths even to the inmost degree, in which are the angels of the third heaven. For the human understanding as it rises by continuity upwards around the two higher degrees, receives the light of wisdom of these degrees. Hence it is that a man becomes rational according to this elevation. If he is elevated to the third degree, he becomes rational from the third degree, if he is elevated to the second degree, he becomes rational from the second degree; and if he is not elevated, he remains rational in the first degree. It is said that he becomes rational from the above degrees, because the natural degree [of which the rational mind forms the highest part] is the general receptacle of their light. The rational [mind] of man, to appearance, is thus as it were of three degrees; rational from the celestial, rational from the spiritual, and rational from the natural degree (D. L. W. 258).

Again we read:--

A man whose understanding of the truths of the Church is enlightened by the light of heaven, and thus by the Lord, can see the truths of the Church rationally in the world, spiritually after death (A. E. 846).

And again:--

All truths of the Word which are truths of heaven and of the Church can be seen with the understanding, in heaven spiritually, in the world rationally (A. E. 1102).

263. We have now become acquainted with the capacities of the human mind and the plan according to which that mind is organized, together with the various kinds of spiritual and natural heat and light, of which it is the recipient;

391

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 392

and we have further learned in what way the human mind is cared for by the Lord by immediate and mediate influx. Our next step will be to study the laws of development of the human mind, and to inquire in what way it is raised from natural into spiritual light, and thus into a state of enlightenment from the Lord.

All development in the direction of spiritual enlightenment, which marks an advanced state of regeneration, is caused by good--even as enlightenment itself is conveyed to man through the medium of spiritual good. The Lord, through His immediate influx, constantly instills good into man, from his very first formation. In this good which is the good of remains, that is, the good of infancy and childhood, the Lord is present with him, and through that good He governs and superintends his spiritual growth; and if the man himself is willing, and co-operates with the Lord, He reforms and regenerates him, and thereby conjoins him to Himself. Concerning this first insemination of good into man, we read:--

Infants and children are first of all in good; for they are in a state of innocence, and in a state of love towards their parents and nurses, as well as in a state of mutual charity towards their companions, so that with every man good is the first-born. The good into which a man has been initiated remains; for whatever a man has been imbued with from childhood puts on life, and because it remains becomes the good of life. For if a man were deprived of the good which he has brought with him from childhood, he would not be a man, but would be more ferocious than ally wild beast of the forest (A. C. 3494).

264. On account of the depraved condition of man the will and the understanding are totally separated in him at birth; which is also the reason why man, different from the animals, is then utterly void of all knowledge.

392

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 393

The Lords object, however, with the spiritual, that is, the fallen man, from his very birth is to bring about a conjunction between the will and the understanding, and thus to generate in him by regeneration the heavenly marriage, which is equivalent to the conjunction of good and truth, of will and understanding, in his soul. This conjunction is brought altogether by good; wherefore also, through the medium of good, and thus through the medium of the affection to which the inflowing good gives rise, the Lord begins to weave in man a conjunction between the will and the understanding. The first conjunction, according to Swedenborg, is effected through the affection of knowing which culminates in the affection of the truth. This affection flows from the will into the understanding, and is the result of the first presence of the will in the understanding; or rather it is caused by good from the will flowing into the understanding. On this subject we read:--

Good flows in continually from the Lord through the internal into the external man; and during the first age of man it appears in the external man under the appearance of the affection of truth (A. C. 3159).

And again:--

In the beginning, before a man is being regenerated ... good which flows in continually is productive of the affection or truth; for the affection of truth is from no other source then from the continual effort of Divine Good of flowing in (A. C. 4247).

The first form, however, in which the affection of the truth manifests itself, is the affection of knowing, or of acquiring knowledge, concerning which Swedenborg says:--

There are several affections of the exterior man, each of which is devoted to its own use but the chiefest of these affections is the affection of knowledges and of the sciences when it has for its end, that a man shall become truly rational; for then it has for its end what is good and true (A. C. 1909).

The affection of knowing gives birth to that feeling of curiosity which characterizes man during the early ages of childhood and youth, and which induces him to imbibe eagerly every kind of information or knowledge.

393

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 394

That the affection of knowing is the first bond of conjunction between the will and understanding, Swedenborg declares in what follows:--

The first conjunction is brought about thought the affection of knowing, from which comes the affection of the truth. This first state of conjunction exists after birth, and it continues from the state of ignorance even to the state of intelligence, and from this latter state to the state of wisdom. The first state is one of mere ignorance, because then there is no thought from the understanding but only an obscure affection on the part of the love, or the will. In the second state which belongs to mans childhood and early youth (pueritia), there is with him, as is well-known, the affection of knowing. Through this affection the child learns to speak and read, and afterwards he gradually imbibes the things belonging to the understanding. That the love which belongs to the understanding operates this, cannot be doubted for a moment; for unless the love or the will acted thus, the above would not be brought about. Everyone who examines experience from a principle of reason acknowledges that the affection of knowing is with every man after birth, and that through this affection he learns those things by which his understanding is formed, and through which it increases and is perfected. That the affection of the truth arises from the affection of knowing, is evident; for after a men by virtue of the affection of knowing has become intelligent, he is no longer impelled so much by his affection to acquire knowledge, as to reason and to draw conclusions concerning those things which belong to his love, whether they have reference to household affairs, or to civil and moral things. When this same affection is raised to spiritual things, it becomes the affection of spiritual truth. That the first or initial form of the affection of the truth was the affection of knowing, may be seen from this circumstance, that the affection of the truth is a heightened affection of knowing; for being affected with truths means being anxious to know them from affection, and after finding them drinking them in from the delight of affection (D. L. W. 404).

265. The affection of knowing, which culminates in the affection of truth, thus attracts knowledge and information, and the delight of this affection fixes it in the memory, and causes it to be reproduced.

394

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 395

We thus read:--

The scientifics [the matters of knowledge] which enter the memory are always introduced by some affection; those things which are not introduced by any affection, do not remain fixed, but are passed by. The reason is that there is life in the affection, but not in scientifics, except through an affection. It appears hence that scientifics have always conjoined to them things belonging to affection, or what amounts to the same thing, such things as belong to some love, and consequently some good. For all that belongs to love is called good, whether it is good, or is thought to be good. Scientifics, therefore, form with these goods some kind of marriage. Hence it is that when good is excited, the scientific with which it has been conjoined, is likewise excited at once; and conversely, when the scientific is recalled the good conjoined with it also comes forth (A. C. 5489).

As the love, and thus the affection is the man himself, it follows that scientifics and knowledges have a different affection, and thus a different good, adjoined to them with regenerate and non-regenerate persons. We thus read further:--

With the non-regenerate who have rejected the good of charity, the scientifics which are truths of the Church, have adjoined to them such things as belong to the love of self and of the world--thus evils, which on account of the delight that is in them are called goods, and which through sinister interpretations are also made to appear as goods. These scientifics, to all appearance come forth glibly when these loves reign universally, and according to the degree in which they reign. But with the regenerate scientifics which are of the Church have adjoined to them such things as belong to the love towards the neighbor, and love to God--thus genuine goods, These goods are stored up by the Lord in the truths of the Church with all those who are being regenerated. When, therefore, the Lord with them instills a zeal for good, those truths come forth in their own order, and when He instills a zeal for truth, that good is present, and enkindles the man (A. C. 5489).

266. Good, in the form of the affection of knowledge, thus receives and seizes the scientifics and knowledges, which enter into the memory through the gateways of the senses;

395

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 396

and yet these objects do not enter into the memory of their own accord, but they are summoned into it by an actual call of the soul; as appears from what follows:--

Man is not born into any science, and still less into any intelligence and wisdom; but only into the faculty of receiving them, and of investing himself therewith. This u done by a twofold way, namely, by an internal, and an external way. By the internal way flows in the Divine, and by the external way the worldly element. These two meet interiorly in the man, and in proportion as he suffers himself to be enlightened by the Divine, in the same proportion he comes into wisdom. The things that flow in by external way, come in through the senses of the body; and yet they do not flow in of their own accord, but they are summoned from [the world] by the internal man, so as to serve as it plane for the celestial and spiritual things which flow in from the Divine by the internal way (A. C. 5081).

Again we read:--

It appears as if the things which are in the world flowed in through the senses towards the interiors; but this is a fallacy of the senses. For there is an influx from interior into exterior things, and by this influx there is apperception [the power of noticing things] (A. C. 5119).

And again:--

All instruction is simply an opening of the way, and as the way is opened, or what amounts to the same thing, as the vessels are opened, rational things flow in, in due order, from celestial-spiritual things; these latter things flow into rational things, and into the celestial-spiritual things flow celestial things. These celestial things [by which is meant good] are constantly present, and they prepare, and thus form for themselves vessels, which are being opened (A. C. 1495).

267. The good which flows into man from the Lord, and which descends out of the internal into the external man, thus causes in man first the affection of knowing, and afterwards the affection of the truth; and these two affections summon into the man scientifics and knowledges, through the medium of the senses. Good, in the form of the delight of the above affections, also fixes these scientifics and knowledges in the memory, and causes them to be reproduced thence.

396

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 397

Yet Good from the Lord does even more; for it classifies and arranges mans knowledge, as it enters into the memory. We thus read:--

Divine Good flows into the natural man..... By this influx Divine Good enlightens and vivifies all things which are there, and arranges them into order for all light, life, and order in the natural man are due to an influx from the Divine (A. C. 3086).

Again:--

It is known that man is not born into any science, nor into anything rational but only into the faculty of receiving these things; also that he learns and imbibes all things by degrees, and chiefly by the sensations of sight and hearing; and, further, that in proportion as he learns and imbibes, he becomes rational. It is evident that this is effected by the way of the body, that is, by an external way, because by hearing and seeing. But what man does not know, because he does not reflect upon it, is that something is continually flowing in from the interior which receives the things that thus enter and are instilled, and which arranges them order. That which flows in, which receives and arranges is celestial Divine Good which is from the Lord; hence is the life of these things, hence their order and hence are the affinities and relationships among them (A. C. 2557).

And again:--

Good which flows in from the Lord through heaven arranges all things, and so far as the man suffers it, disposes them according to the image of heaven. Thence it is that a mans thought flows in accordance with the heavenly form. The heavenly form is that into which the heavenly societies are arranged; and the heavenly societies are arranged according to that form which is induced by the good and truth which proceed from the Lord (A. C. 5288).

268. The things that are being stored up in the memory through the affection of knowing, as we have already seen, are called by Swedenborg scientifics, and knowledges. The former, that is, the scientifics, are derived partly from the world and by a study of the natural sciences, and partly by a study of the literal sense of the Divine Word, and of the correspondences that are contained in it.

397

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 398

Knowledges, however, are imbibed by a study of the truths of doctrine, and thus of those truths which are contained in the spiritual sense of the Divine Word. So long, however, as these knowledges or these matters of doctrine are simply in the memory, and are not loved by the man for the sake of life, they are merely scientifics, and are impressed upon the memory by the affection of knowing; that is, they are acquired simply from a feeling of curiosity.

The first scientifics that are impressed upon the memory are called by Swedenborg sensuous scientifics, and together with the affection, or rather with the delights of the affection which flows in from within, they form the first degree of the natural mind called the sensual. Concerning these sensuous scientifics Swedenborg says:--

Sensuous scientifics are scientifics of the outward things belonging to the world, and hence they are the mast general of all. They are those things which enter immediately through the external senses, and are perceived by the very sense. All in infancy or childhood are in these things, and they serve as planes for the knowledges of spiritual things; for spiritual things are founded on natural things and are represented in them (A. C. 4360).

Those sensuous scientifics which serve as planes for the knowledges of spiritual things, are such as contain within them what is Divine, and as are called knowledges of external or corporeal truth. Such knowledges are contained in the literal sense of the Divine Word. We read concerning them as follows:--

With respect to the knowledges of external or corporeal truth which contain within themselves what is Divine, and hence are capable of admitting within themselves genuine goods, which knowledges are with children who are subsequently regenerated--they are such as belong to the historical parts of the Word; for instance those that are related there concerning the Paradise, concerning the first man who was there, concerning the tree of life which was in its midst, and the tree of knowledge on which was the serpent who deceived. These are knowledges of the kind that contain within themselves what is Divine, and that admit within themselves spiritual and celestial truths, because represent and signify them.

398

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 399

Such knowledges also are all the rest in the historical parts of the Word, as for instance those that are recorded there concerning the tabernacle and the temple, and their construction; also, concerning the garments of Aaron and his sons, likewise concerning the feast of tabernacles, concerning that of the first fruits of the harvest, and that of unleavened bread, and similar other things. When these and such like things are known and thought by a child, the angels who are with him think of the Divine things which are represented and signified thereby; and since the angels are affected by these things, the affection of the angels is communicated, and constitutes the delightful and pleasurable feeling which the child derives therefrom, and it prepares his mind for the reception of genuine truths and goods (A. C. 3665).

269. Not only the above knowledges of external or corporeal truth, but also all other impressions received from the world through the senses of hearing and sight, and hence all sensuous scientifics--according to what was stated above in no. 267--are arranged and disposed in the childs memory into heavenly order by the inflowing Divine Good which causes in the child the affection of knowing. But especially is this heavenly arrangement promoted by the state of innocence in which the children are. Os this subject we read:--

From childhood even to youth the man is merely sensual through the senses of the body he receives only earthly, corporeal and worldly things; his ideas and thoughts also are then from these things. The communication with the interior man is not yet opened; except so far, that the man is able to comprehend and retain the above things. The innocence in which he is, is then merely external, and not internal; for true innocence dwells in wisdom. Through innocence, i.e., external innocence, the Lord reduces into order those things that enter through the senses. Apart from the influx of innocence from the Lord in that first age, no fundamental [plane] could exist, on which an Intellectual or Rational which is mans might be erected (A. C. 5126).

And again:--

From childhood even to youth, and sometimes to first adolescence, a man imbibes goods and truths by instruction from his parents and teachers.

399

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 400

He seizes them, and believes them in simplicity. The state of innocence promotes instruction, and fits these things into the memory; set it lodges them only in its first threshold. For childlike and youthful innocence is not internal innocence which affects the Rational, but it is external innocence which affects only the external Natural (A. C. 5135).

As regards the quality of the affection of acquiring knowledge which prevails with man during childhood and youth, we read concerning it:--

When a boy is first instructed, he is affected by a desire of knowing for no particular purpose evident to himself but his desire arises from a certain pleasure, and a connate delight, or from a delight derived from some other source, afterwards, as he is growing up, he is affected with a desire of knowing for some definite purpose--for instance, that he may excel others, that is, those who are competing with him. By and by he desires to acquire knowledge for the sake of some end in the world. But when he is about to be regenerated, his delight springs from the delight and pleasantness of the truth, and while he is being regenerated, which takes place in adult age, his desire of knowing springs from the love of the truth, and afterwards, from the love of good. The ends or purposes that have preceded, together with their delights, are gradually separated; and they are succeeded by an interior good from the Lord, which manifests itself in the affection. It appears hence, that the former delights which in their outward form appeared as goods, served as means (A. C. 3818).

270. As a youth advances in age the communication between the sensual and the interior natural degree of the external man begins to be opened and to be organized; and at the same time a higher faculty of the mind--the imagination, is brought into play. This faculty which is also called the interior sensual, sees in a higher light than the exterior sensual degree which is opened in man during infancy and childhood. Concerning this higher light, see above, no. 261. But concerning that interior degree of the natural man which is then opened, and in which the faculty of imagination is active, we read:--

All the things which are in the natural mind are scientifics and knowledges of every description;

400

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 401

in a word, each and all things which belong to the external and corporeal memory. To the natural mind also belongs everything imaginative which is the interior sensual with man, and which is especially active with youths and in the age of first adolescence. To that mind belong also all affections which man has in common with brute animals (A. C. 3020).

Concerning the imagination, which is the intellectual activity of the natural mind, we read further:--

The objects of the world, all of which derive something from the light of the sun, enter through the eye, and are deposited in the memory; and, indeed, under a kind of visual appearance. For the things that are produced thence, are seen interiorly; from whence there arises mans imagination, the ideas of which the philosophers call material (A. C. 4408).

And again:--

Mans imagination is nothing else than the forms and appearances of those things which are seized by the sight of the body, varied in a wonderful manner, and so to say modified (A. C. 3337).

271. By the activity of the imagination scientifics proper and knowledges are developed and extracted out of the sensual scientifics of the sensual mind below. For as we have seen above (in A. C. 5774, p. 382), The things which enter through the senses are deposited in the memory; and from them the man concludes the scientific, or from them he perceives the scientific, which he is learning. The sensual scientifics, as we have seen, are in the threshold of the external or corporeal memory, while the scientifics proper and the knowledges are placed more interiorly. On this subject we read:--

In the Natural there are scientifics of various kinds. There are [1] scientifics about earthly, bodily and worldly things, which are the lowest; for they are immediately from the external senses, that is, from those of the body. There are [2] scientifics about the civil state--concerning its government, statutes and laws, which are a little more interior. There are [3] scientifics concerning those things which belong to the moral life, which are more interior still. But [4] those scientifics which belong to spiritual life, are the most interior of all. They are the truths of the Church;

401

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 402

and so long as they are with a man only from doctrine they are nothing else than scientifics; but when they are from the good of love, they pass beyond the scientifics; for they are in spiritual light, from which they regard the scientifics in their order below themselves. Through such degrees of scientifics man ascends to intelligence; for scientifics, through those degrees, open the mind, so that light out of the spiritual world can flow in (A. C. 5934).

To the scientifics about earthly, bodily, and worldly things belong the facts of the natural sciences, of history, and those included in the study of languages, etc. All these scientifics are extracted from, and based upon, sensuous scientifics. Concerning the scientifics of civil and moral life, we read:--

Civil truths have reference to those things which belong to judgment, and to the government in kingdoms. In general they refer to what is just and fair in these things. Moral truths have reference to those things which belong to the life of everyone in society and in friendly intercourse with others; in general they refer to what is sincere and straight-forward; and specifically they refer to virtues of every kind (H. H. 468).

And again we read:--

Those who in respect to civil life live according to what is just and fair, and in respect to moral life, according to what is honorable and decorous, are such that the Lord is able to be the mind, be with them. For the Lords presence with man is in good, and therefore in what is just and fair, and in what is honorable and decorous. What is honorable is the complex of all moral virtues what is decorous [that is, what is courteous and polite] is only its form (A. C. 2915).

272. With respect to the truths of the Church so far as they are scientifics, that is, so far as they are in the natural or corporeal memory, it must be observed that there are two kinds of the scientifics of the Church. There are scientifics of the Church which are essentially scientifics, and which are never raised out of the natural or external memory, but remain there; and there are other scientifics of the Church which are such by virtue of their entering into the natural memory through the ministration of the senses of hearing and of sight;

402

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 403

but which are not intended to remain there, but to become principles of thought and life. These latter scientifics are generally called by Swedenborg knowledges of good and truth.

Scientifics of the Church of the former kind, that is, such as are essentially scientifics are all the things of the literal sense of the Word which are vessels of interior truths; as appears from what follows:--

Scientifics of the Church, at the present day, are all those things which belong to the literal sense of the Word. Unless truths from the internal sense are instilled into these scientifics, the mind may be carried off into any heresy (A. C. 6071).

Again, we read:--

The scientific truth of the Church is nothing else than the Word in the sense of the letter and also every representative and significative of the Church which was among the posterity of Jacob. These things in the external form are called scientific truths; but in the internal form they are called spiritual truths (A. C. 6832).

273. A distinction is made between scientifics and knowledges, when a comparison is drawn between them alone; nevertheless, in a larger sense, when truths in the natural man, i.e., natural truths, are placed in opposition to spiritual truths, scientifics and knowledges are sometimes classed together under the more general head of scientifics, its in the following passage:--

Scientifics into which the things belonging to faith and charity can become fitted are very many, as for instance all the scientific of the Church. Such scientifics are all true scientifics concerning correspondences, representatives, significatives, influx, order, intelligence and wisdom, affections; yea, all truths of an interior and of an exterior nature, both visible and invisible; because these truths correspond to spiritual truths (A. C. 5213).

Scientifics and knowledges are thus classed under one head, in their character as truths in the natural mind;

403

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 404

and they are then comprised under the general term scientifics. Nevertheless, in the letter of the Word scientifics and knowledges are kept most distinct; so much so, indeed, that the former are represented there by Egypt, and the latter by Philistia. On account of their inherent distinction also the knowledges of good and truth are defined as interior scientifics, because in the memory they occupy a more interior position. We thus read:--

By knowledges of good and truth are meant interior scientifics, such as are those of the Church concerning faith and love (A. C. 9945).

As a general thing, however, it must be borne in mind, that all truths of faith, and all truths of the Church, and hence all knowledges of good and truth are nothing but scientifics, so long as they are only in the natural memory, and are animated there only by the affection of knowing. Thus we read:--

By scientifics which are of the Church, are meant all knowledges of good and truth, before they are conjoined with the interior man; that is, through the interior man with heaven; thus, through heaven with the Lord. The doctrinals of the Church and its rituals, as well as the knowledges which teach what spiritual things represented thereby, and in what way, and other similar things, are nothing but scientifics, before a man sees from the Word whether they are true, and hence has appropriated them (A. C. 5402).

Again:--

The truths of faith in which there is not charity are nothing but scientifics; for they are in the memory in the same way in which other things are there; but when the truths of faith are from charity, that is, when charity is in them, then they are distinguished very perceptibly from scientifics, and then at times they raise themselves above scientifics, and look upon them as underneath (A. C. 6077).

And again:--

The truths of the Church which are the most interior of all scientifics, so long as they are with man only from doctrine, are nothing else than scientifics;

404

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 405

but when they are from the good of love, they pass beyond the scientifics; for then they are in spiritual light, from which they regard the scientifics, below themselves, in their order (A. C. 6934).

274. With respect to the light in which the scientifics appear in the natural memory--they are exhibited there at first in natural light; for not only do they enter into the memory through the senses of the body, and thus by means of natural light; but natural light also prevails generally in the natural memory, as appears from what follows:--

The lowest truths, that is, those of the exterior Natural, are called scientifics, because they are in the natural, i. e., the external memory of man, and because they participate for the most part of the light of the world and hence are able to be set forth and represented before others in the form of words, that is, by ideas formed into words through such things as belong to the world and its light (A. C. 8212).

The fact that natural light prevails in the external memory is due, however, in a great measure to the mixed character of the affection by which the scientifics are received in the memory before a man enters upon his course of regeneration. For the affection which reigns in a man causes him to be either in an affirmative, or in a negative state. An affirmative state is produced in him by an affection springing from the love of the Lord and of the neighbor, and a negative state by all affection which has its origin in the loves of self and of the world. But an affirmative state makes a man receptive of spiritual light, and thus enables him to see and believe spiritual truths, while a negative state closes his mind against the reception of spiritual light, and causes him to see things in natural light. Thus in childhood, that is, so long as a man is in a state of innocence, he is in an affirmative state in respect to the truth, or rather in respect to what he is being taught by his parents or teachers;

405

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 406

while he comes more or less into a state of doubt or denial as he approaches the age of manhood, and gets under the influence of his hereditary loves of self and of the world.

275. Concerning the condition of a mans Natural during childhood and youth, and generally before regeneration, we read as follows:--

The marriage of good and truth is not in the Natural with a man at his birth; because man alone is not born into Divine order. The good of innocence and charity which flows in from the Lord in early childhood, is indeed with him, but not any truth is with him to which that good can be wedded. As the man progresses in age, the good which has been instilled into him by the Lord in infancy, is withdrawn towards the interiors, and is kept there by the Lord, that through it the states of life which he puts on afterwards, may be tempered; for apart from the good of his childhood and early youth. the man would be worse and more ferocious than any wild beast. When that good of infancy is drawn inwards, evil succeeds in its place in the Natural, and becomes wedded there to falsity, so that a conjunction, and as it were a marriage of evil and falsity is then effected in the man. In order, therefore, that he may be saved, he must be regenerated, and evil has to be removed, and good to be instilled by the Lord; and according to the good which he receives, truth is instilled into him, so that there results thence an alliance, and as it were a marriage of good and truth.... But since all conjunction of truth with good is effected by affection, therefore, the affection of truth has to be wedded to good (A. C. 3793).

The condition of a mans Natural at first is as follows:

From earliest infancy and childhood, the Natural receives its quality from those things which flow in through the external senses. By them and from them the man acquires to himself an Intellectual; but since he is then in the delights of the loves of self and of the world, and hence in lusts, both from his hereditary and his actual nature; therefore, the Intellectual which he then acquires, is filled with things of this character, and the things which favor his delights he then regards as Natural is inverted, that is, contrary to heavenly order. When the Natural is in such a state, the light of heaven indeed flows in through the Rational, for from this influx man has the power of thinking, reasoning, speaking, and acting courteously and in goods and truths. Wherefore, the order of these things in the Natural is inverted, that is, contrary to heavenly order. When the Natural is in such a state, the light of heaven indeed flows in through the Rational, for from this influx man has the power of thinking, reasoning, speaking, and acting courteously and in a civil manner; but still the things which belong to this light, and which lead the man to eternal happiness are not in the Natural.

406

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 407

For the delights which rule in it resist these things; since the delights of the loves of self and of the world in themselves are altogether opposed to the delights of the love of the neighbor, and hence of the love of the Lord. The Natural, indeed, may become acquainted [in the form of scientifics] with the things belonging to light,, i.e. to heaven, but it can become affected with them only so far as they are of use to a man in reaching places of honor, and in obtaining gain; thus only so far as they favor the delights of the loves of self and of the world. When, therefore, the light of heaven flows into the natural through the Rational, this light cannot help being either reflected, or suffocated, or perverted. Hence then it is that the Natural must first be regenerated, before it can be conjoined to the Rational. For when the natural has been regenerated, then those things that flow in from the Lord through heaven, and hence through the Rational into the Natural, are received, because they agree; since the natural is nothing else than a receptacle of good and truth from the Rational, that is, through the Rational from the Lord. (A. C. 4612).

276. A mans Natural, that is, his external or natural man as it is before regeneration, differs thus very much from its quality after the man has entered upon the course of his regeneration; for in the former case the affection which reigns universally throughout the Natural is derived from the loves of self and of the world, and thus is productive of a negative state; while in the latter case the ruling affection in the Natural is derived from the love of the Lord and the love of the neighbor, and hence hears an affirmative character. From this, however, it follows, that the affection of the truth before regeneration is altogether different from the affection of the truth which is with man after he has entered upon his regeneration. Both affections are caused by an influx of Divine Good through the internal into the external man. But even as is the case with good in general, which, when it flows from the Lord into man is turned by the latter into evil, in proportion as he turns sway from the Lord to his own self (see T. C. R. 490), and thus in proportion as Good from the Lord flows with him into the love of self

407

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 408

so also the affection of truth which is caused in a man by an influx of Divine Good, becomes altered in a like manner by the delight of the love of self in the natural man. But from this it follows that there is both a genuine and a spurious affection of the truth; concerning which we read as follows:--

The genuine affection of truth consists in willing and desiring to know the veriest, truths of faith for the sake of a good use as an end, and for the sake of life. But the affection of truth which is not genuine consists in willing and desiring to know truths for the sake of self, and thus for the sake of reaching places of honor, and of acquiring gain. Those who are in the affection of truth from the latter origin do not care whether the truths which they know are genuine or not, provided they can pass them off as truths. Wherefore, such persons limit themselves to a confirmation of the doctrinals of the Church in which they were born, whether these doctrinals are true or not. As to real truths they are in darkness; for worldly ends which are gains, and bodily ends which are posts of honor, blind them altogether. Those, on the other hand, who are in the genuine affection of the truth, that is, wile desire to know truths For the sake of a good use and for the sake of life, remain likewise in the doctrinals of the Church until they reach an age when they begin to think from themselves but then they examine the Scripture, and pray to the Lord for enlightenment, and when they are enlightened they rejoice from the heart; for they know that if they had been bent where another doctrine of the Church prevails, yea, where the greatest heresy reigns, they would have remained in that doctrine or in that heresy, unless they examined the Scripture from a genuine affection of the truth (A. C. 8093).

277. The affection of truth, just like the affection of acquiring knowledge, is therefore at first of a mixed character; still, although impure, this affection is nevertheless utilized by the Lord in causing n man to accumulate knowledge, and afterwards in inducing him to reflect on this knowledge, and to draw conclusions from it. We thus read:--

With a person who is to be regenerated the case is so that his first affection of the truth is quite impure;

408

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 409

for there is contained in it the affection of a use, that is, of an end for the sake of self, for the sake of the world, for the sake of glory in heaven, and for other like things that have respect to self; but there is not contained in it an affection for the sake of the common weal, the Lords kingdom, and least of all for the sake of the Lord. Nevertheless, this same affection of the truth is successively purified by the Lord, until at last falsities and evils are separated cast as it were into the circumference. These same falsities and evils, however, had served as means (A. C. 3090)

Again we read:--

In the first state of the spiritual men, the delights of the loves of self and of the world which he regards as goods, apply themselves to his truth, and constitute for the most part the affection of truth with him. For he then thinks that truths may be of use to him either for reaching posts of honor, or gain, or reputation in the world, or again that they may acquire for him merit in the other life. All these things, notwithstanding their not being good, but evil, excite and also kindle in him that affection of the truth. Nevertheless, the Lord permits that during this first period he shall be borne away by such things, because otherwise he cannot be regenerated; intelligence and wisdom come in time. Meanwhile, through such things, because otherwise such things, he is introduced into good, that is, into charity; and when he is in charity he perceives what good is, and he acts from good, and from that good he judges, and draws conclusions concerning truths; and those things which do not agree he call falsities and rejects them He thus rules over truths, as a master over his servants (A. C. 3330).

Again:--

Every affection of truth in the natural man exists through an influx of the affection of good from the Rational, that is, through the Rational from the Divine. The affection of truth which through this influx exists in the natural man, in the beginning is not the affection of genuine truth. For genuine truth comes by degrees, and is substituted successively in the place of the former things which were not true in themselves, but were simply means leading to genuine truth (A. C. 3040)

And finally:--

It does not matter if in the beginning, when the man is being formed, the affection of truth is also for the sake of self and of the world; but this quality has to be put off, as good increases through truths. Then also the man is constantly being purged of such things, as the bowels are purged of useless things (A. C. 10266)

409

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 410

278. After a mans mind through the [affection of truth, so far as his memory is concerned has been stored with scientifics and knowledges, upon his reaching adult age, the good which is constantly flowing into him from the Lord, is productive in him of another affection--the affection of understanding, which causes in him the perception of the truth. This affection, according to Swedenborg, is the second means by which a conjunction is effected between the will and the understanding.

Hitherto the man, under the influence of the affection of truth, had been storing up scientifics and knowledges of every description; yet he had been acquiring them under the influence of others, and therefore had seen them in their light, and not in his own light. Under the influence of the affection of understanding by which he is animated at his entrance into manhood, and which is derived from his lifes love, he begins to see matters and things in his own light, that is, in the light of his own reason. On this subject we read:--

That the second conjunction of the will with the understanding is effected through the affection of understanding, from which [conjunction] comes the perception of the truth, must be evident to every one, who is willing to examine this from rational intuition. Upon taking a rational view of this subject, it appears that the affection of the truth and the perception of the truth are two faculties which with some persons are coincident, and with others not. They are coincident with those who wish to perceive the truths with the understanding; and they do not coincide with those who are only willing to become acquainted with the truth. It appears also that every one is in the perception of the truth just so far as he is in the affection of understanding. For if you take away the affection of understanding the truth, there will be no perception of the truth; but wherever the affection of understanding the truth is present, there also will be a perception of the truth according to the degree of the affection for it. For no one whose reason is should is ever destitute of the perception of the truth so long as he has the affection of understanding the truth. Every one possesses the faculty of understanding the truth which is called rationality (D. L. W. 404).

410

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 411

279. It will be observed here that there is a difference between the affection of understanding the truth and the faculty of understanding the truth, called rationality. By the affection of understanding, the knowledges and scientifics of the natural memory are taken up singly and collectively, and submitted to the faculty of reason; that is, they are exposed to the light of heaven, and that light enables a man to perceive the truth in the very light of truth, and thus to pass a rational judgment concerning these same scientifics and knowledges. A man is enabled to do this, because by virtue of his rationality he is able to raise his understanding into the very light of heaven, and by virtue of his freedom he is able to will that the understanding shall be raised (see above, nos. 225 and 226). From this, however, it follows that the affection of understanding depends in the end upon the character of a mans freedom; wherefore it will be necessary for us to examine mans freedom more is detail. We read on this subject:--

All freedom belongs to love, so much so, indeed, that love, so much, indeed, that love and freedom are one.... All delight enjoyed by a man flows from his love; there is no delight from any other source; and acting from the delight of a love means acting from freedom.... There are: as many kinds of freedom as there are kinds of love; but in general there are three kinds: natural, rational, and spiritual freedom. Every man by inheritance has natural freedom. From this freedom he loves nothing except himself and the world. His first life is nothing else; and since all evils derive their existence from these two loves, and evils thereby are made the subjects of love, it follows that a mans natural freedom consists in thinking and willing evils; and it follows further that after he has confirmed these evils in himself through reasonings, he does them from freedom according to his reason. He does these evils by virtue of his faculty called Liberty or Freedom; and he confirms them from that other faculty which is called Rationality.

Rational freedom arises from the love of reputation for the sake of honor and gain.

411

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 412

The delight of this love consists in a person appearing in the outward form like a moral man; and because he loves this reputation he does not commit adultery, he does not avenge himself, and he does not revile others. And since he makes these things the subjects of his reason, he also from freedom according to his reason does what is sincere, just, chaste, and neighborly; nay, from reason he can talk correctly in favor of these things. If, however, his rational principle is only natural, and not at the same time spiritual, that freedom is only an outward, and not an inward freedom; and, therefore, notwithstanding all this, he does not love the above goods interiorly, but only exteriorly, namely, for the sake of reputation: wherefore the good actions which he does are not intrinsically good ... and therefore the above rational freedom inwardly is natural freedom.

Spiritual freedom flows from the love of eternal life. Only those come into this love and its delights who think that evils are sins, and who on this ground do not will them, and who at the same time look to the Lord.... No one can do these things except from a more interior, that is, a higher love. This freedom, in the beginning, does not appear as freedom, and yet it is freedom; but it appears as such by and by; and then a person in thinking, speaking and doing good and truth, acts from very freedom and very reason. Spiritual freedom increases in proportion as natural freedom decreases and becomes subservient; it also conjoins itself with rational freedom and purifies it (D. P. 73).

280. The affection of understanding the truth, by which knowledges and scientifics are raised into the light of heaven, varies according as a man in the rational examination of his knowledges and scientifics is influenced either by rational or spiritual freedom. In the former case, his affection of understanding the truth flows from the love of acquiring posts of honor, glory, and gain, and thus from the love of use for the sake of ones own self; but in the latter case it flows from the love of use for the sake of the neighbor. When a man is influenced by rational freedom, that is, by the freedom which is inherent in the love of use for the sake of self, the understanding only is elevated, and then the knowledges which he examines in the light of heaven continue with him in the memory in the form of scientifics.

412

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 413

But when a man in the examination of the truth is influenced by spiritual freedom, that is, by the freedom which is inherent, in the love of use for the sake of the neighbor, then not only his understanding, but also his love or his will is elevated; and the result of this is that his spiritual mind or man is opened, and that the truth which he perceives to be true is implanted in the good of charity in his spiritual mind, that is, in the spiritual degree of the rational man, and that conscience is established there by this means.

That the faculty of reason, that is, the faculty of examining knowledges from the Word in the light of heaven, is possessed also by those who are actuated by a natural love, appears from what follows:--

There is a natural love and there is a spiritual love. The man who is in a natural and at the same time in a spiritual love, is a rational man; but he who is only in a natural love indeed think in a rational manner altogether like a spiritual man, but still he is not a rational man. He raises his understanding even to the light of heaven, and thus to wisdom, but still the things which belong to wisdom, that is, to the light of heaven, do not belong to his love. His love, indeed, brings this about, but it does it from the affection of honor glory and gain. When, therefore, his love perceives that it does not receive anything of that sort by such an elevation of the understanding; as is the case when the man thinks with himself from his own natural love, then it does not love the things which belong to the light of heaven, that is, to wisdom; wherefore it drags down the understanding from its height, so that it may act as one with itself. For instance, when the understanding by virtue of elevation is in wisdom, the love sees what justice, what sincerity, what chastity, yea what genuine love is; for the natural love see this by means of its faculty of understanding and contemplating things in the light of heaven; yea, the natural love can speak, preach, and describe these things as moral, and at the same time as spiritual virtues. When the understanding however, is not in a state of elevation, then the love, if it is purely natural, does not see those virtues, but hi the place of justice it sees injustice. in the place of sincerity deception, and in the place of chastity lasciviousness.

413

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 414

If, then, a man thinks of those things of which he had spoken while his understanding was in a state of elevation, it is possible for him even to laugh at these things, and to think only that they are of use for captivating the lower mind (D. L. W. 416).

Unless, therefore, a person in examining truths, i. e. the knowledges of the truth, in the light of heaven, is actuated by the love of use for the sake of the neighbor, he does not become spiritual, but remains natural; wherefore, he cannot then be raised, as to his spirit, from the plane of knowledge and science into that of spiritual intelligence and wisdom, as appears from whet follows:--

Those who are not willing to understand anything but what belongs to the world and its nature, and who are not willing to know what moral and spiritual good and truth are, cannot be raised from science into intelligence, and still less into wisdom; for they have blocked up in themselves the faculties of freedom and rationality; wherefore they are human beings no further than that from the rationality and freedom implanted in them they are able to understand if they will (D. P. 75).

281. From the above we see that in order for any one to become truly rational, it is essential that while his understanding, under the influence of the affection of understanding the truth is raised into the light of heaven, his love or his will shall be raised at the same time. But this is done by the spiritual love of that is, by the love of use not for the sake of self but for the sake of the neighbor, as is clearly taught in what follows:

The love or the will can be raised in like manner as the understanding, if it loves the things which belong to the light of heaven, or to wisdom. But the love of the will cannot be raised by anything that belongs to honor, glory, or gain as an end it is raised by the love of use not for the sake of self, but for the sake of the neighbor; and indeed, because this love comes from the Lord alone out of heaven. The Lord, however, imparts this love when a man shuns evils as sins; wherefore by this means the love, that is, the will can also be elevated, but without this means it cannot be raised. The love or the will, however, is raised into the heat of heaven, and the understanding into the light of heaven;

414

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 415

and if both are raised, a marriage is effected there between the two, which is called the heavenly marriage, because it is the marriage of love and wisdom (D. L. W. 413).

The affection of the truth and the affection of understanding the truth are properly affections of the understanding, and through them the understanding is first developed, and afterwards reformed; yet it is reformed only if both these affections have use for their end, and if the very knowledges and scientifics also, with which they are conjoined, are permeated by the love of use. Then also under the influence of these affections, the rational degree in mans mind is developed; as appears from what follows:--

The Rational can never be conceived and born, that is, formed, apart from scientifics and knowledges, but scientifics and knowledges must have use for their end; and when use is their end, life also is their end, for all life is of uses, because of ends. Unless they are learned for the sake of the life of uses, they are of no consequence, because of no use. From scientifics, and knowledges alone, without any life of use, a Rational arises which is like a wild ass, morose, pugnacious, having a hot dry life from a certain love of truth defiled with self-love. But when scienitifics and knowledges have use for an end, they receive life from uses; still the quality of the life is according to the quality of the uses.

They who learn knowledges that they may be perfected in the faith of love--for a true and real faith consists in love to the Lord and charity towards the neighbor--are in the use of all uses, and receive spiritual and celestial life from the Lord; and when they are in that life they are in the faculty of perceiving all things which are in the Lords kingdom. In that life are all angels, and because they are in that life they are in intelligence and wisdom itself (A. C. 1964).

From this passage it follows that those only who are in spiritual freedom, and from that freedom in the spiritual love of uses, are able to have the rational mind, that is, the spiritual degree of that mind developed in them. From the same passage it also follows, that two Rationals may be formed in man; one under the influence of the love of use for the sake of the neighbor; and another Rational which is generated under the influence of a love which has no respect to use, but looks to self and the world.

415

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 416

The former national is beginning to be born in man when he enters upon the course of his regeneration; while the latter exists with him before he is regenerated, and so long as he is under the influence of the natural loves of self and of the world. Concerning these two Rationals we read:--

With every man who is being regenerated there are two Rationals; one before, and the other after regeneration. The first Rational, which exists with man before regeneration, is acquired through the experiences of the senses, through reflections on those things which happen in civil and in moral life, through the sciences, and reasonings from them and by them; further, through knowledges of spiritual things from the doctrine of faith, or from the Word. These things, however, at that time, pass only a very little beyond the ideas of the corporeal memory, which are respectively quite material. Whatever a man then thinks is from such things; or, again, things similar to the above are presented by the way of comparison and analogy, in order that they may strike the interior, that is, the intellectual sight. Of such a nature is the first Rational, that is, the Rational which exists before regeneration.

The Rational after regeneration is formed by the Lord through the affections of spiritual truth and spiritual good. These affections are in a wonderful manner implanted by the Lord in the truths of the first Rational, and those things in it that are congruous and favorable are vivified in this manner; but the rest, as things of no use, are separated from it; so that at last the spiritual goods and truths are gathered together, as it were, into bundles, the incongruous things which cannot be vivified having been rejected towards the circumference; and this is done successively in proportion as the spiritual goods and truths, together with the life of their affections, increase. Thence appears the quality of the second Rational.

How the case herein may be illustrated by a comparison with the fruit of trees.
