The first Rational in the beginning is like unripe fruit, which ripens by degrees, until at last it deposits seeds in itself; which the fruit has reached that stage and begins to separate itself from the tree, its state is full. The second Rational, however with which a man is gifted by the Lord when he is being regenerated, is like that same fruit in a good soil;

416

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 417

there those things which are around the seeds rot away while the seeds themselves push themselves forward from their interior recesses, and put forth the root, and afterwards the shoot above the ground, which grows into a new tree, and unfolds itself, so as to produce at last new fruits, and then it multiplies itself into gardens and paradises, according to the affections of good and truth which the man receives (see Matth. xiii. 31, 22; John xii. 24).

But since examples are more convincing, let the self or proprium which belongs to a man before regeneration, and the self or proprium which belongs to him after regeneration, serve as an example. By virtue of his first Rational which is acquired by the man through the means specified above, he thinks that from himself, and thus from his proprium, he thinks what is true, and does what is good. The first Rational cannot understand otherwise, even if it is informed that all the good of love, and all the truth of faith is from the Lord. But when the man is being regenerated, which takes place in adult age, by virtue of the second Rational with which he is gifted by the Lord, he begins to think, that good and truth are not from his own self, or from proprium, but from the Lord, yet that he must nevertheless do good and think truth as from himself. The more then he is confirmed in this, the more he is led into the light of truth concerning those things, until at last he believes that all good and all truth are from the Lord. The self or proprium of the first national is then successively removed, and the man is gifted by the Lord with a new proprium, which becomes a part of the new Rational.

Let another example be adduced: The first Rational in the beginning knows no other love than the love of self and the world, and although it hears that heavenly love is altogether different, it does not comprehend it. But when, in the sequel, the first Rational does any good, the only delight which it derives from doing it consists in this, that it seems to itself to delight which it acquire favor thereby in the eyes of another or that the doer of that good in consequence of it is called a Christian, or that he obtains thereby the joy of eternal life. But the second Rational with which man is gifted by the Lord through regeneration begins to feel some delight in the very good and truth; and it begins to be affected with that delight, not for the sake of anything of self, but for the sake of good and truth. When a man is influenced by this delight, he rejects merit, until at last he detests it as something enormous. This delight increases with him by degrees, and becomes happiness, and in the other life blessedness; nay, it becomes his very heaven (A. C. 2657).

417

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 418

282. The second national, which is here spoken of, is identical with the spiritual degree of the rational mind (see above, D. L. W. 258, in no. 262), and also with the spiritual mind or man which has been discussed above (nos. 241 to 247): but of the first Rational we read in the above passage that the things which it acquires by reflection on things moral and civil, etc., pass only a very little beyond the ideas of the corporeal memory; wherefore, the first Rational is not identical with the natural degree of the rational mind (see above, no. 262). Besides, the first Rational, so far as the knowledges of the Divine Truth are concerned, which are in it, is gradually absorbed by the second Rational; just as unripe fruit gradually passes over into ripe
fruit; those parts of the first national which are heterogeneous being cast off to the circumference. As a general thing it may be stated that the spiritual degree of the Rational or the spiritual mind or man is formed out of knowledges; and the natural degree of the Rational, which is also called the Rational proper, or the rational man, but which is not identical with the first national, out of scientifics; as appears from the following passage:--

The truths of the natural man are scientific truths which are under the intuition of the rational man; and likewise knowledges of the truth which are under the intuition of the spiritual man. Knowledges of the truth are those which the natural man knows from the Word; and scientific truths are those which the natural man sees from the Rational; through these latter truths also the natural man is wont to confirm the truths of the Church (A. E. 406).

On this same subject we read further:--

Uses for perfecting the Rational [the natural degree of the Rational], are all those things which are called sciences and pursuits, and which deal with natural things, with things of domestic economy, and with civil and moral things; and which are acquired either from parents and teachers, or from books, or by intercourse with others, or by ones own reflection on such things. These things perfect the Rational so far as they are uses of a higher degree; and they remain so far as they are applied to the life (D. L. W. 338).

Uses for receiving from the Lord a Spiritual are all things which belong to Religion and to Worship from religion; hence they are those things which teach the acknowledgment and knowledge of God, and the knowledge and acknowledgment of good and truth, and thus life eternal. These things, just like the [sciences and other] pursuits, are likewise imbibed from parents and teachers, from preaching, and books, and especially by applications to the life made in accordance with these teachings.

418

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 419

In Christendom these things are imbibed by doctrines and teachings from the Word, and by the Word from the Lord (D. L. W. 333).

282. The Spiritual which is received from the Lord through knowledges from the Word when they have use for their end, is of a twofold character; according as the knowledges from the Word, by means of which the Spiritual is received from the Lord, that is, formed, are derived either from the external or literal sense of the Word, or from its spiritual sense. In the latter case there is derived from these knowledges, on the plane of the spiritual degree of the rational mind, the interior conscience of what is good and true; and in the former case there is derived from them, on the plane of the natural degree of the rational mind, the exterior conscience of what is just and fair. Concerning these two degrees of conscience, see above (no. 143, p. 199).

Those with whom conscience is formed in the spiritual degree of their rational mind, are also said to be in the Internal of the Church, as well as in spiritual good; while those with whom conscience is formed in the natural degree of their rational mind are said to be in the External of the Church, as well as in natural good. Concerning both of these we read:--

Whether you say natural good, or the External of the spiritual good, or the Internal of the Church it is the same;

419

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 420

for natural good constitutes the External of the Church, and spiritual good the Internal of the Church. That is said to be spiritual which is in the light of heaven; for what is in that light has WITHIN itself the affection of good and the perception of truth. These things are in that light because that light is from the Lord. Wherefore, those who are in spiritual good and truth are in the Internal of the Church; for with the head they are within heaven. But that is called natural which is in the light of the world; and what is in that light has the affection of good and the perception of truth not WITHIN but OUTSIDE of itself. For the light of heaven flows in, and illuminates all around, thus from the outside, and not from within; and it imparts the knowledge that good is good, and truth true, because it is so said, and not because it is perceived to be so. Wherefore, those who are in natural good are in the External of the Church, for they are not with the head in heaven, but their head is illuminated from without out of heaven (A. 5965).

283. From the above it follows, that the development of the national with man may be threefold; for there is first, the Rational before regeneration, secondly, the Rational during the process of regeneration, and thirdly, the Rational after it has been regenerated. The Rational before regeneration is the first Rational mentioned above. It is formed under the influence of rational freedom (see above, no. 279) which intrinsically is nothing else but that natural freedom which is inherent in the natural loves of self and of the world. The first Rational has no perception in spiritual things, but only in natural things; and from the perception which it enjoys is natural things it judges of the spiritual truths which concern the Lord and His kingdom. Of these latter truths also it takes a merely intellectual view, and regards them as subjects of speculation, and not of practice. The second Rational--the product of regeneration, is twofold, according as it is established either in the spiritual, or in the natural degree of the rational mind. With those who are instructed in the particular doctrines of the spiritual sense, the second national, under the influence of spiritual freedom is formed first in the natural, and afterwards in the spiritual degree of the national;

420

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 421

while with those who are instructed only in the general doctrines of the literal sense, it is formed in the natural degree of the national.

So long as a man is rational from the natural degree, he is in natural good, i.e., in the good of obedience, and he belongs to the external Church. He enjoys thee a general perception out of heaven, which enables him to see the truth when stated by another. He perceives the truth then from WITHOUT, not from WITHIN; and the truth which he perceives from others, he is able to confirm by rational considerations. He is essentially in the affection of the truth; but not yet in the affection of understanding the truth in the light of his own reason, from which comes the perception of the truth. A man is rational from the natural degree during the first period of regeneration, and especially while leading a life of repentance. In proportion as the affection of truth with man becomes purified of evils and falsities, by a life of repentance, he becomes gradually animated by the affection of understanding the truth immediately from the Lord, and not first from others; and in the same proportion there becomes opened within him his spiritual mind, and he becomes rational from the spiritual degree. The spiritual degree of that mans Rational is bathed in spiritual light, and under the influence of the knowledges of the spiritual sense of the Divine Word which are now illuminated by this light, he is able to do spiritual good, and to become a member of the internal Church.

284. It has been stated above that a man comes into the second national, and thus is able to be rational from the spiritual degree, by virtue of spiritual freedom; but that he is in his first national, that is, in a Rational of a purely natural quality, by virtue of natural freedom.

421

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 422

As a man from birth is in natural freedom, and in proportion as he advances towards the age of manhood is in rational freedom, which intrinsically is purely natural (see above, no. 279), it follows that if he desires to be regenerated at the hands of the Lord, and if from the first Rational he would advance into the second Rational, he must employ his freedom of choice which is preserved in him by the Lord; and by virtue of his freedom of choice he must declare either in favor of spiritual, or of natural freedom--in favor of the love of the Lord and the love of the neighbor, or in favor of the loves of self and of the world. This choice and also the battles to which a man becomes exposed after he has made his choice, take place in the rational plane of his mind. On this subject we read:--

The sphere of heaven and the sphere of hell meet with man in the natural world in the rational plane; ... for from above there flows into that plane the marriage of good and truth, and from below the marriage of evil and falsity; the latter flows in through the world, the former through heaven. Thence it is that the human Rational can turn in either direction, and receive influx from either side. If it turns towards good, it receives this influx out of heaven, and then the mans rational mind is formed more and more for the reception of heaven; but if it turns towards evil, it receives this influx from below and the mans Rational is formed more and more for the reception of hell (C. L. 438).

And again we read:--

The Rational, which is called the rational man, is most distinct from the Natural, even to such a degree that the one may disagree from the other i.e., the Rational, which is called the rational man, from the Natural, which is the natural man that the rational man may even see and perceive the evil which is in the Natural; and if it is a genuine Rational, to correct the same. Before these two parts are conjoined, the man cannot be a whole man, nor can he be in the tranquillity of peace; for the one fights with the other. The angels who are with the man rule his Rational, but the evil spirits who are with him his Natural; hence there is a conflict. If the Rational then conquers, the Natural is subdued, and the man is gifted with conscience;

422

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 423

but if the Natural conquers, the man cannot receive anything of conscience. If the Rational conquers, the mans Natural becomes of such a quality as to be like the Rational also; but if the Natural conquers, the Rational becomes of such a quality as if it were also natural. Again, if the Rational conquers, the angels draw nearer to the man, and instill into him charity, which is the Celestial that comes from the Lord through the angels; and then the evil spirits withdraw to a distance. But if the Natural conquers, the angels remove to a greater distance, i.e., more towards the interiors; the evil spirits, however, approach nearer towards the Rational, and constantly assault it; but the lower parts of that mind they fill with hatreds, revenges, cunning, and the like. If the Rational conquers, the man comes into the tranquillity of peace, and in the other life into the peace of heaven; but if the Natural conquers, then, during life, the man appears to be in tranquillity, but in the other life he comes into unrest and torture of hell.... A man, therefore, can be made blessed and happy only when the Natural is being conformed to the national, and both are conjoined. This, however, is effected only through charity, and charity is alone from the Lord (A. C. 2183).

The common effect, however, of the victory of the rational man over the natural is, that the spiritual mind or degree, that is, the internal man, is opened towards heaves, and the influx of the Lord through heaven is able to descend out of the internal into the external man, and regenerate it into its likeness.

If the Natural conquers, we read that the spiritual degree of the Rational together with the natural degree of the Rational are closed, and that a kind of perverted rational mind is formed interiorly in the Natural from which the man thee acts; which, however, consists of mere falsities and evils (see above, p. 365, A. C. 406).

285. From this it follows, that the equilibrium in which a man is kept during his life in the world, resides in his rational mind or part, where he is called upon to exercise his freedom of choice which consists of the faculties of freedom sad reason combined. But in this freedom of choice he is kept by the Lord.

423

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 424

In this same freedom of choice, however, freedom is the primary, and reason the secondary agent. Freedom alone, independently of reason, does not constitute a mans freedom of choice; nevertheless, freedom is a more interior attribute of that same freedom of choice, than reason.

According to the doctrine taught by Swedenborg (see above p. 330, D. P. 96), nothing enters into a mans will except through the faculty of freedom, and nothing enters his understanding except through the faculty of reason. But from this it follows, that everything that has entered into a mans will is connected in it with the faculty of freedom, and therefore reacts upon that faculty; and in like manner it follows thence that everything that has entered into a mans understanding, is connected in it with the faculty of reason, and communicates to that faculty the quality of the understanding. Wherefore, a mans freedom and rationality do not by any means remain unaffected by the quality of the mans mind. They seem unaffected at first, before the man has a will and an understanding of his own, that is, so long as the man still acts from the states impressed on him during childhood and youth; but as soon as he begins to exercise in fullness that freedom and that reason with which the Lord is present in his soul, and as soon as by virtue of these two faculties, he begins to declare either in favor of good, or in favor of evil, these same faculties partake manifestly either of an affirmative, or of a negative quality, as appears from the following declaration of Swedenborg:--

If a man turns towards the Lord, his freedom and rationality are directed by the Lord; but if he turns his back upon the Lord, his freedom and. rationality are directed by hell (C. L. 437).

286. In the rational plane with man there is both a will and an understanding; yet the equilibrium between good and evil, and between truth and falsity is in the intellectual part, and not in the will-part.

424

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 425

For a mans will, that is, his ruling love, must either be good or evil it cannot be good and evil at the same time; and therefore it cannot receive at the same time an influx out of heaven, and an influx out of hell; and hence it cannot be in spiritual and in natural freedom at the same time. With the understanding it is different, as appears from what follows:--

The mans understanding, but not his very will is the recipient of good, as well as of evil; of truth as well as of falsity. The will [after a man has reached adult age] must will is the man himself, and his lifes love is in it. Good and evil, however, are separated in the understanding, like what is internal and external. Hence it is possible for a man to be interiorly in evil and exteriorly in good. Nevertheless, when the man is being reformed, good and evil are let together, end there arises then a conflict and battle, which when it is severe, is called a temptation; but when it is not severe, the case is as when wine or strong drink are fermenting. If good then conquers, evil with its falsity is removed to the sides, comparatively as when the dregs are precipitated to the bottom of a vessel; good then becomes like generous wine and clear spirituous drink after fermentation; but when evil conquers good with its truth is removed to the side, and becomes turbid and foul, like unfermented wine and unfermented strong drink (D. P. 284).

If good, therefore, conquers, the man by virtue of the freedom of choice which he exercises in his understanding, determines that his ruling will shall be good, but if evil conquers he decrees that his will shall be evil. According to the ruling quality of a mans love which is determined in this manner, will be in time the quality of his understanding, and hence the quality of his reason. In the former case also, as we have seen, the mans freedom and rationality are directed by the Lord, and in the latter case by hell. From the above passage, when read in connection with H. H. 290 (see above, p. 317), it is made very evident, that since the equilibrium with a man resides in his understanding, the battles of his reformation are also fought in that faculty.

425

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 426

They are fought in it by the good and evil spirits who take possession of the contents of the mans memory. But while the good and evil spirits struggle in the understanding for the mastery, the man himself has still possession of his will, and by the exercise of his freedom of will, in which he is kept by an immediate influx from the Lord, as well as by his faculty of reason which is imparted to him at the same time, and which enables him to examine the two sides of a controversy, the man himself decides whether the good or the evil spirits shall gain the upper hand in him. Of the Lords immediate influx, however, so far as it takes place into his will, the man does not become conscious; but he does become conscious of what enters into his understanding, and thus of the contests which are being fought in it between the good and evil spirits. Concerning the Lords immediate presence with a man in his will whereby He imparts to him the faculty of freedom, Swedenborg says:--

It is the mans freedom, through which, in which, and by which the Lord is present in him, and whereby he urges the reception of Himself; and yet He never puts aside, or abrogates a mans freedom; because whatever is not done by a man from a principle of freedom in spiritual matters does not remain; wherefore it can be said that it is in a mans freedom that the Lord dwells with him in his soul (T. C. R. 408.)

287. As the choice with the member of the Church is made in the understanding, therefore the understanding is first reformed, and in the understanding there is gradually formed anew will. The new will, indeed, is at work in the understanding from the very first; for it gives rise in it first to the affection of knowing, afterwards to the affection of the truth, and finally to the affection of understanding the truth. And again, through Good in the new will the Lord arranges into order all the scientifics and knowledges in the mind of the man who is about to be regenerated.

426

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 427

By this means the faculties of the will and of the understanding which originally are separated, are gradually re-united; yet so that for a long time, even throughout the whole of the first period of regeneration, the understanding preponderates over the will. The new will thus expends itself at first in intellectual acquisitions and in intellectual operations, until at last when the man passes from the first into the second state of regeneration, the new will asserts its primogeniture, and becomes the ruling faculty in man. The progression of the new will, from the beginning until at last it brings forth in man the good of charity, is as follows:--

While man is an infant he receives good from the Lord; this good is the good of innocence such as children have. This good forms the initiament of the new will with man, and it grows in the succeeding ago according to the life of innocence with companions, and according to the life of uprightness and obedience towards parents and teachers; get more with those who suffer themselves to be regenerated afterwards. This is foreseen by the Lord, and He makes provision according to the state of the life that follows. For in all that belongs to the present the Lord foresees evil and provides good, and indeed from the first manifestation of life to eternity. Afterwards when the man advances in age and begins to think from himself, in the proportion in which he is then carried off by the delights of the loves of self and of the world, in the same proportion that new Voluntary, that is, the initiament of the new will is closed; and in the proportion in which the man is not carried off then by those delights, the new will is opened, and also perfected. But how it is perfected, namely, through the implantation of truth, shall now be told. That new Voluntary which is from the good of innocence is the dwelling-place through which the Lord enters with a man, and stimulates the man to will good, and from willing good to do good. This influx from the Lord is operative in a man so far as he desists from evils. From this influx he has the faculty of knowing, of taking notice of, of reflecting upon, and of understanding, moral and civil truths and goods, according to the delight of use. Afterwards through the above good the Lord flows into the truths of the doctrine of the Church which are with the man, and He summons from the memory those truths which are subservient to the use of life and these truths He implants in good and [thereby] perfects it.

427

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 428

Thence it is that good with a man is altogether according to the use of life. If the use of life is in favor of the neighbor, i. e., in favor of the good of ones fellow-citizens, of the country, of the Church, of heaven, and of the Lord, then that good is the good of charity; but if the use of life is solely for self and the world, the initiament of the new will is closed, and underneath it there is formed a Voluntary out of the evils of the loves of self and of the world, and an Intellectual is formed thence out of falsities. This Voluntary is closed above and open below; that is, it is closed towards heaven, and opened towards the world. In this way truths are implanted in good, and good is formed through them (A. C. 9296).

288. As regards the gradual development of the understanding, and its preparation for conjunction with the will, this takes place as follows:-

A mans Natural sees things in the light of the world, which light is called natural lumen. The man acquires for himself that lumen through the objects which enter through the sight and through hearing; thus by means of objects which come from the world. The man thus sees those objects interiorly in himself, almost in the same way as the eye sees them. Those objects which enter through the above senses, first strike him as something pleasurable and delightful. Afterwards the infant man distinguishes between delights, and by doing so he learns how to discriminate, and indeed more and more exquisitely by degrees. When light out of heaven flows into these things the man begins to see them in a spiritual manner, and he first distinguishes between useful and useless objects, and thereby begins to discern what is true; for what is useful to him is true in his eyes, and what is useless is not true for him. This discernment increases according to the influx of the light of heaven until at last the man not only makes a distinction between truths, but also between the truths in his truths; and indeed with a greater degree of lucidity the more the communication between the internal and external man is opened. This is the source of mans perception; nevertheless, this is not yet spiritual perception for this latter perception does not exist from natural, but from spiritual truths. Spiritual truths are those which are called truths of faith. Spiritual perception exists from these truths on this ground, that the light of heaven is the Divine Truth which proceeds from the Lord, and this Truth shines before the eyes of the angels as 1ight it also shines in their understanding and imparts to them intelligence and wisdom;

428

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 429

yet with a variety according to the reception of that truth in good. In order, therefore, that spiritual perception may exist, the knowledges of spiritual things must be with a man in his Natural; but the knowledges of spiritual things must be from Revelation. When the light of heaven flows into these knowledges, it flows into its own; for, as already said, this light is the Divine Truth which proceeds from the Lord. From that source man has intelligence and wisdom in those things which belong to eternal life and these things increase according to the reception of that light, that is, according to the reception of the truths of faith in good; but good is charity (A. C. 9103).

289. In these two passages it is shown very plainly how the new Voluntary is first formed in man, and how in the spiritual degree of the rational man it is afterwards conjoined with the new Intellectual. The process by which this is done is briefly as follows: Truths of faith are summoned from the natural memory into the spiritual degree of the rational man, and are implanted in it in the good of the new will, that is, in the good of charity. The summoning of these truths is effected by the affections of the new will, and indeed in the exact proportion in which these affections are fired with the desire of doing good, that is, of accomplishing uses. Concerning this summoning of truths of faith from the natural memory into the spiritual degree of the rational mind, we read:--

Man is not born rational, but he is born into the potency of becoming rational. This takes piece through scientifics, that is, through knowledges of various kinds and species. Those scientifics that are received first are means for acquiring those that immediately follow; and hence they are means for acquiring in due order the last, which are knowledges concerning the spiritual things of the Lords kingdom, and which are called doctrinals. These doctrinals are partly learned from the doctrine of faith, partly immediately from the word, and partly by ones own study, from either of these sources. So long as these doctrines are simply in the memory, they are merely scientific truths, which are not appropriated to the man as his own until begins to love them for the sake of life, and still more when he applies them to the life. When such is the case, truths are raised from the natural memory into the [spiritual degree of the] national, and are conjoined there to good, and after they have been conjoined they are no longer matters of science, but of life;

429

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 430

for the man then no longer learns from truths how he ought to live, but he lives from them. Truths thus are appropriated to him, and become matters of the will. In this wise he enters into the heavenly marriage; for the heavenly marriage is the conjunction of good and truth in the [spiritual degree of the] Rational. This the Lord does in the man (A. C. 3161).

Truth at first preponderates in the national; for this degree of the mind is formed, and increases by the implantation of truth from without in the good of charity which is there from within. Truth preponderates thus during the whole duration of the first state of regeneration, and hence while the man from truth looks to good; but this relation is inverted as the man approaches the second state of regeneration, when from good he begins to look to truth and from charity to faith. The condition of the Rational during the first state of regeneration is described in what follows:--

The primary thing of the Rational with man is truth consequently the affection of truth. In order that a man may be reformed, and thus regenerated, which is effected through the knowledges and scientifics belonging to truthwhich are continually being implanted in good, i.e., in charity, so as to receive the life of charity--the affection of truth prevails with the man in his Rational. For the case with the life of charity which is the very heavenly life, is thus that with those who are being reformed and regenerated, that life is continually being born, it grows up and receives increase--yet through truths; wherefore, the more of truth there is implanted, the more the life of charity is perfected. Hence charity with a man is according to the quality and quantity of truth (A. C. 2189).

Such is the condition of the national during the first state of re6eneration called reformation; but to the second state apply the following words:--

In truth there is no life, but in good. Truth is merely a recipient of life, that is, of good. Truth is like an integument and clothing of good. When good, therefore, constitutes the Rational [that is, in the second state of regeneration], truth disappears;

430

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 431

and then truth becomes as it were good. Good then shines through truth, as it does with the angels (Ibid).

200. As regards the method by which truth is raised from the Natural into the Rational, we read further:--

There is n continual Divine influx through the internal into the external man; that is, an influx of celestial and spiritual things through the rational into the natural man; or what is the same thing into the natural things belonging to the external man; and through this influx truths are continually called forth from the natural man. They are elevated and implanted in the good which is in the Rational (A. C. 3085).

Further:--

A man is not born into any truth, but has to learn all, and indeed by an external may; namely by sight and hearing. By this way truth has to be instilled into, and implanted in, the memory. So long, however, as truth is only there, it is mere science. In order that truth may permeate the man, it has to be called forth thence, and to be borne away more towards the interiors. For the really human nature of man is more interior; namely, in his Rational. Unless, indeed, a man becomes [spiritually] rational, he is not a man. In proportion, therefore, to the quality and quantity of a mans Rational, in the same proportion, and to the same extent, he is a man.

A man can never be [spiritually] rational, unless he is good. The good which a man has above the animals consists in loving God, and loving the neighbor. All [truly] human good is thence. Into this good truth is to be initiated, and with this good it is to be conjoined, and indeed in the [spiritual degree of the] Rational Truth is initiated into good and conjoined with it when a man loves God, and when he loves the neighbor; for then truth steps inwards and draws near to good; for good and truth mutually acknowledge each other. All truth, indeed, is from good, and truth looks to good as to its end, and as to its soul, in order that it may derive life from it. It is, however, difficult for truth to be separated from the natural man, and to be elevated from it into the rational man; for in the rational man there are fallacies, lusts of evil, persuasions of the false; and so long as these things re there, and adjoin themselves to the truth, the natural man keeps back the truth, and does not allow it to be raised into the Rational. For the natural man involves the truth with doubts, and reasons concerning it whether it be so.

431

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 432

But as soon as the lusts of evil, and the persuasions of the false, and the fallacies thence are separated by the Lord; and as soon as a man by virtue of good begins to feel an aversion for reasonings against the truth, and to smile at doubts, so soon truth is in a condition to withdraw from the Natural, and to be elevated into the Rational, and to put on a state of good; for truth then becomes a matter of good, and receives life (A. C. 3175).

291. It is to be observed here that the affection of truth; that is, truth conjoined with some affection by which it is kept in the memory, is raised from the Natural into the Rational, and not truth alone; for there is no life in truth alone (see A. C. 3066). We thus read further:--

The affection of truth is separated from the natural man when it is no longer a matter of science, but of life for when, by habit, it has become a matter of life it permeates the man, like an inborn genius of disposition. Then truth thus permeates the man, it flows out into act spontaneously, as it were, and indeed without his thinking concerning it from any scientific. Nay, when it becomes a matter of life it can govern and rule scientifics, and take up from them innumerable things which confirm. The case is thus with every truth which in the early age of man has been a matter of science, but which in his advancing age has been made a matter of life. The case herein is as with children when they learn to walk, to talk, to think, and when they learn to see from the understanding, and to draw conclusions from judgment. For when these things, by habit, have become matters of the will, and are thus spontaneous and involuntary, they disappear from among the scientifics, since they flow forth spontaneously. So also it is with the things which belong to the knowledges of spiritual good and truth among the men who are regenerated or re-born by the Lord. At first such persons differ scarcely from children; spiritual truths with them are at first scientifics; for when doctrinals are being learned and committed to the memory they are nothing else; but they are successively called forth from the memory by the Lord and committed to life, that is, to good; for good means life. When such is the case, there is an inversion, as it were; for then the man begins to act from good, that is, from life, and not as before, from science. A person, therefore, who is being born anew is like a child in this respect: but the things which he puts on belong to spiritual life; yet in this wise that he does not act from a doctrinal or a truth, but from charity or good.

432

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 433

When such is the case he is first in a state of blessedness, and of wisdom (A. C. 3203).

On this subject we read further:--

When a truth is elevated out of the Natural into the [spiritual degree of the] Rational, it is taken out of the sphere of worldly light into the sphere of heavenly light; thus, as it were, out of the darkness of night into clear daylight. For the things belonging to the light of the world in which are all natural things, are respectively as in night; but the things belonging to the light of heaven in which are spiritual things, are respectively in daylight. When therefore a truth is raised out of the Natural towards the Rational, the man is raised at the same time into intelligence and into wisdom. All intelligence and wisdom with man is from thence (A. C. 3100).

292. On taking a retrospect of the manner in which the spiritual degree of the rational mind, that is, the spiritual mind proper is organized, we find that by the application of a mans spiritual freedom which acts in conjunction with the spiritual love of uses, and the affection of understanding the truth, the truths from the Word are elevated from the natural memory into the spiritual degree of the rational mind, where they are inseminated into the good of charity. Truths are thus raised out of natural into spiritual light, and become instrumental thereby is conjoining the understanding with the will on the plane of that interior degree of the national.

This raising of truths out of the natural into the rational man, we learn is by no means an easy task; since the fallacies, lusts of evils, and persuasions of the false which are in the natural man, adjoin themselves to the truth which is there, and prevent the truth from being raised into the Rational. These disorderly ingredients, therefore, have first to be separated from truths by the Lord, before they are in a condition to withdraw from the Natural, and to be elevated into the Rational. This, however, requires on the man s part an active state of repentance, and also a humbling of the first Rational, and thus a bowing of the mans pride of intellect and of his self-prudence before the Divine Truth revealed by the Lord, concerning which we read:--

433

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 434

Unless the Rational [i.e. the first Rational] submits itself to the goods and truths of the Lord, the celestial things of love and faith which flow in from the Lord through the internal man, are either suffocated, rejected, or perverted, and still more if they flow into the sensual scientific of the memory. Such is the meaning of the seed falling either on the way, on stony ground, or among thorns (Mat. xiii, 3-7 etc.) But when the Rational submits itself, and believes the Lord, that is, the Word, then the Rational becomes like good soil, into which the see falls, and bears much fruit (A. C. 1940).

293. From this, therefore, it follows that the opening of the spiritual mind, and the conjunction there of the will and the understanding by elevation of truths from the natural man, and their insemination into the good of charity, is in exact proportion to the shunning of evils in the natural man by a process of repentance, and to the humbling of a mans own Rational before the Lord and a belief in His Word.

By such means the national is regenerated; and by the regeneration of the national is meant the regeneration of a mans first Rational. For a man is regenerated as to his Rational, before he is regenerated as to his Natural, and the Natural is regenerated through the Rational (see A. C. 3468). So long, however, as the national is indeed regenerated but not yet the Natural, a mans spiritual sight is dim, as appears from the following passage:--

When the Rational has been regenerated, but not yet the Natural, the former appears to itself as obscured, because there no correspondence. For the Rational has its vision from the light of heaven, and the Natural has its sight from the light of the world; and unless there is a correspondence, the Rational can see nothing of what there is in the Natural. All that is there appears to the Rational as wrapped in shade; or, again, as if it were mere darkness. But when there is correspondence. Then the things which are in the Natural appear to the Rational in light;

434

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 435

for then the things which belong to the light of the world are enlightened by those things which belong to the light of heaven, and they are then as If they were translucent (A. C. 3403).

294. From this it follows that it is of the greatest importance that the perception of the rational man shall be continued into the natural man, and that it shall he supported by a corresponding state of the natural man; that, therefore, the sight of the rational man which sees in the light of heaven, shall not be perverted or extinguished altogether by a contradictory state of the knowledges and scientifics is the natural man below. We thus read:--

Unless the sight of the eye has objects outside of itself which it may see, it perishes. Again, if the objects are of an altogether opposite character, they induce death--just as when the vein of some spring has no efflux for its waters, it is choked up. So also, unless the light of the rational mind is received in the natural mind, its sight perishes. For the scientifics--information in the memory--are the objects of sight of the rational mind, and if these objects ore opposed to the light, that is, to the intelligence of truth and the wisdom of good, the rational vision also perishes, because it cannot flow into any object contradictory to itself. Wherefore the rational mind, with those who are in evils and falsities, is closed up, and is kept open only by chinks, as it were, whereby the faculty of thought, of reasoning, and of speaking is preserved in them (A. C. 4618).

And again:--

If the external sight is injured, it can no longer be of any use to internal sight; for if the external eye perverts the objects, the internal sight can only see perversely through the external sight. The case is exactly the same with the internal man. If scientific truths, i.e. truths committed to the memory, are perverted or extinguished in the external man [by false reasonings or erroneous scientifics], the internal man cannot see the truth; thus it can think only perversely and falsely. Hence, in order that man may become regenerate, the natural man must be regenerated (A. C. 9061).

295. In order that the perception of the truth may be continued from the rational into the natural man; that, therefore, the truth which is perceived in the Rational, may be seen by a man in the Natural, a third affection--the affection of seeing the truth, from which is thought, is developed in the man during his course of regeneration;

435

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 436

and by the ministration of this affection a conjunction of the will and understanding is brought about in the mans Natural, and the perception of the rational man becomes thereby a matter of sight in the natural man. Concerning these three affections, through which the will is conjoined with the understanding, we read in a general way:--

Love conjoins itself to wisdom [and hence, the will to the understanding] through the affection of knowing or of acquiring knowledge, from which comes the affection of the truth further, through the affection of understanding, from which comes the perception of the truth and, lastly through the affection of seeing what is known and understood, from which comes thought. The Lord flows into all these affections for they are derivations from the lifes love of everyone (D. P. 28).

Concerning the affection of seeing what is known and understood we read more particularly:--

The third conjunction [of the will with the understanding] is effected through the affection of seeing it [namely, the truth], from which conjunction comes thought. That the affection of the truth is one thing, the perception of the truth another thing, and thought still another, appears only obscurely with those who are unable to perceive distinctly the operations of the mind, but it appears clearly with those who are able to perceive them. The reason why this distinction appears only obscurely with those who do not perceive distinctly the operations of the mind is, that these three are simultaneously in the thought with those who are in the affection of the truth, and in the perception of the truth, and when they are thus simultaneously together, they cannot be distinguished. A man is in manifest thought when his spirit thinks in the body, which is especially the case when he is in company with others; but when he is in the affection of understanding, and when through that affection he conies into the perception of the truth, then he is in the thought of his spirit, which thought is meditation. This thought indeed descends into the thought of the body, but into tacit thought for the former thought is above the latter, and regards, as underneath itself, those things which belong to thought from the memory;

436

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 437

for from the things which belong to the latter thought it either draws conclusions, or procures confirmations. But the affection of truth itself is not perceived otherwise than as an effort of the will arising from some pleasurable sensation, which is interiorly in the meditation, as its life, but to which only little attention is paid.

From all this it may appear that those three things, namely, the affection of the truth, the perception of the truth, and thought follow in order from love; and that they do not exist anywhere else than in the understanding. For when the love enters into the understanding, which is the case after the conjunction has been brought about, then the love first produces the affection of the truth; afterwards the affection of understanding what it knows, and at last the affection of seeing what it understands, in the thought of the body. For thought is nothing else than internal sight. Thought indeed exists at first, because it belongs to the natural mind; but thought from the perception of the truth which arises from the affection of understanding the truth, exists last. This latter thought is the thought of wisdom, but the former thought is thought from the memory through the sight of the natural mind.

All the operations of love, that is, of the will outside of the understanding have no reference to the affections of truth, but to the affections of good (D. L. W. 404).

296. Through the affection of seeing, the perception of the truth is brought down from the internal man into the consciousness of the natural man where it gives rise to thought, that is, to interior thought. This thought consists essentially of the inward perception of the truth, in a more general, outward form accommodated to the natural man; and this thought becomes reinforced by truths which it extracts out of the knowledges and scientifics in the natural man. These truths, under the influence of the affection of seeing the truths are woven into a rational system of doctrine on the plane of the natural degree of the Rational. The peculiarity of these truths is, that they are all capable of being conjoined with good; while those that are still is the natural memory below in the form of knowledges and scientifics, are not necessarily in that condition.

437

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 438

Concerning this difference among truths we read:--

There are truths with which good cannot yet be conjoined, and there are truths with which it can. Truths with which good can be conjoined are truths confirmed, and also consociated with a number of other truths even with such as delight the intellectual vision. Thus these truths enter into the affection, which causes the man to will them. When such is the case, good conjoins itself with them, which causes the man to will them; for willing truths, and hence doing them, causes these truths to become good. It is further to be observed that good is not conjoined with truths, before these truths are purified from the falsities which spring from evils and before a connection is established between them and all the [other] truths that ought to belong to faith with a person who is to be regenerated. This connection and purification of truths is seen and perceived clearly and evidently by the angels from the Lord; howsoever the man neither feels nor perceives anything of the kind in himself (A. C. 3728).

297. The object of truths is evidently to become conjoined with good, and thus to become good. Yet when the internal flows into the external man with the view of regenerating it, the influx is first directed into the intellectual part of the Natural, and by means of the thought which results from the affection of seeing the truth, truths are extracted from the knowledges and scientifics in the natural memory, and woven into a rational system of doctrine. Concerning the action of thought in this respect we read:--

When a man inquires into any truth, scientifics are present, but do not appear; for thought extracts what they contain, and indeed out of many [scientifics] scattered about, and even out of such as are hidden away. Thus the man draws conclusions; and the more interiorly the thought rises, the further he withdraws from scientifics (A. C. 6874).

The things thus extracted are truths, which are also called doctrinals, and doctrinal or rational truths. These truths are concluded from scientifics and knowledges, under the influence of the perception of the truth in the spiritual degree of the Rational, or in the plane of conscience.

438

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 439

Wherefore, these truths are extracted from scientifics, while the man himself is in a state of enlightenment from the Lord. Hence also these truths which are called doctrinals are defined in A. C. 3726, as truths of the spiritual man in the natural man, while scientifics are defined simply as truths of the natural man.

Doctrinals, thus, are the results of mans rational thought, while he is in the enjoyment of enlightenment from within, and they are created under the influence of the affection of seeing in the natural man the truth which has been perceived by the spiritual man; while scientifics are imbibed by the man while he is under the influence of the affection of the truth, which results from the affection of knowing, or of acquiring knowledge. Moreover, doctrinals, are extracted from knowledges and scientifics, while the man has in view a distinct purpose of use; as appears from what follows:--

Scientifics and doctrinals are distinct from each other in this respect, that doctrinals are derived from scientifics; and, further, that doctrinals have respect to use, and that they are acquired from scientifics by reflexion (A. C. 3652).

There is thus a vast distinction between doctrinals and scientifics in this respect, that the former intrinsically are creations from within, and are in a state of heavenly order; while scientifics, to all appearance, are gathered promiscuously from the world through the senses of the body. Still doctrinals rest on scientifics, and through doctrinals the latter are reduced into a state of order; and when scientifics are thus marshaled into order they are no longer called scientifics, but scientific truths; as in the following passage:--

Doctrinals are the interior truths which the natural man has. The first truths are sensuous, the second scientific, and the interior truths are doctrinal.

439

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 440

Doctrinal truths are founded on scientific truths, so far as a man is unable to have and retain any idea, notion or conception of doctrinal truths, except from scientific truths. Scientific truths, however, are founded on sensuous truths; for apart from sensuous truths they cannot be apprehended by man (A. C. 3310).

Doctrinal truths are otherwise called simply truths, as in A. C. 5774 which has been quoted above at p. 382; and also in other passages.

298. Those truths which have been elevated from the natural memory into the spiritual sphere of the rational mind, and which, after having been implanted there in the good of charity, have entered into the formation of the interior conscience, are called intellectual truths. These truths are entirely beyond the reach of mans consciousness while he lives in a natural body; still the intellectual truths enlighten the doctrinal truths in the natural man below, which in this connection are called rational truths. We thus read:--

Intellectual truth is a genuine sense is truth adjoined to good. Rational truth is under it, and thus lower. This latter truth is born from sciences and knowledges, vivified by an affection corresponding to them (A. C. 1805).

Again we read:--

Scientific truth is one the one thing rational truth another thing, and intellectual truth still another thing; they succeed each other. Scientific truth is a matter of knowledge; rational truth is scientific truth conjoined by reason, and intellectual truth is conjoined with the inward perception that a thing is so (A. C. 1496).

And again:--

Intellectual truth is distinguished from rational truth, and this from scientific truth, like the Internal, the Intermediate, and the External. Intellectual truth is internal, rational truth intermediate, and scientific truth external. Those three are most distinct from each other, because one is more interior than the other. Intellectual truth, which is internal, that is, which is with a mans inmost, does not belong to man, but it is the Lords with man. From it the Lord flows into the Rational, where truth first appears as mans, and through the Rational He flows into the scientific.

440

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 441

It appears from this that man can never think from intellectual truth, but from rational and scientific truth, because these truths appear as mans own (A. C. 1904).

Intellectual truth is thus the Lords with man, and it is the dwelling place of the angels in mans interiors; hence also it is the first recipient in man of the light of heaven, which is imparted to him by the presence of the angels; and, therefore Swedenborg defines intellectual truth as the very spiritual which flows into man out of heaven, as is shown in the following passage:--

Intellectual truth is the very Spiritual which flows in through heaven thus by an intellectual way, and indeed with every man. It constantly goes to meet the knowledges which are instilled through the senses, and which are implanted in the memory. Man does not know this, because intellectual truth is too pure to be perceived with a general idea. It is like a certain light that illuminates, and imparts the faculty of knowing, thinking, and understanding (A. C. 1001).

299. Intellectual truth thus resides in conscience which is in the spiritual degree of the rational mind, and hence is outside the sphere of mans consciousness; but by the affection of seeing the truth, from which comes thought, it is brought down from the internal into the external man; and, indeed, into the highest degree of the latter which is also called the natural degree of the Rational. There it is productive of doctrinal or rational truths, which under the influence of the affection of seeing the truth are extracted by thought from the knowledges and scientifics in the natural memory below.

The relation between conscience where the Lord is present with man and enlightens him, and the thought which is generated by the affection of seeing the truth, is explained in what follows:--

Thought flows from conscience; for those who have conscience think and speak according to it. Thought also is scarcely anything else than an unfolding of those things which belong to conscience; and thus it is equivalent to their partition into ideas, and afterwards into expressions.

441

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 442

Hence it is that those who have conscience are kept by the Lord so as to think well of the neighbor, and they are kept hack from thinking evilly; wherefore conscience is possible only with those who love the neighbor as themselves, and who think correctly of the truths of faith (A. C. 1919).

300. The thought which is thus generated from conscience, or from intellectual truth, is interior thought, which dwells in the truths of the natural-rational degree of the external man. From that degree, which is a creation of conscience from within, and, therefore, in a state of correspondence with it, interior thought which is identical with mans interior or intellectual vision, regards the knowledges and scientifics in the natural memory below, and, through the medium of exterior thought, reduces them into a state of harmony and correspondence with itself. The perception of conscience is thus continued through interior thought into exterior thought, and by this latter thought is invested with the words which repose in the corporeal or sensual sphere of the natural memory. By the principle of correspondence these words are finally communicated to the organs of the body, by which they ape converted into oral or written speech. The appearance is as if thought was altogether of the external man, because it is there that thought takes place, yet it is not the external man that does the thinking, but the rational or internal man thinks in the natural or external man. And again, the thought of the rational in the natural man is according to the state of correspondence of the latter with the former, as is shown in the following passage:--

It is the rational or internal man which thinks, not the external or natural man; for the internal man is in the light of heaven, in which light there is intelligence and wisdom from the Lord; but the external man is in the light of the world, in which there is no intelligence and not even any light. Still it appears to man as if thought were in his External; for he thinks from those things which have entered through the senses and which belong to the world.

442

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 443

So long as a man is in the body, he thinks from the Rational in the Natural; but with a difference according as the Natural corresponds to the Rational, or does not correspond. When the Natural corresponds, the man is rational and thinks spiritually; but when the Natural does not correspond, he is not rational, and cannot think spiritually (A. C. 3679).

301. The Rational, consequently, thinks in the Natural, when the Natural is in a state of order, that is, when it is reduced into a state of correspondence. The spiritual Rational then thinks in the natural Rational which is the highest degree of the external or natural man. The Rational thinks there under the influence of the affection of seeing the truth; and in the highest degree of the Natural where are doctrinals and rational truths, it produces therefrom interior thought. In the form of interior thought, and still under the influence of the affection of seeing the truth, the national then descends among the knowledges and scientifics of the natural memory, and causes there exterior thought, and through its agency clothes itself with, and thus confirms itself by, knowledges and scientifics. But by the principle of correspondence exterior thought, which contains within itself interior thought together with the perception of the truth of conscience, clothes itself with words in the lower, corporeal part of the natural memory, which words through the agency of the organs of the body, are finally expressed by oral or written speech.

Thought is circumstanced thus with the regenerate; that is, with those whose natural man is in the process of regeneration. In a general way, however, the perception of the internal man descends into the sphere of natural consciousness with all those who are NOT under the influence of their natural self or proprium. All such persons enjoy a general perception of the truth from the Lord, so that they are able to recognize the truth when they either hear it stated by another, or when they read it themselves.

443

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 444

This general perception may also defined as common sense in spiritual matters. Concerning this general perception of the truth which is enjoyed by those who are in a state of good, we read:--

General perception comes from the conjunction of heaven with man. Man has general perception when he is not in proprium (Life, 3, 7).

Again:--

Man has general perception, which is identical with the influx of heaven into the interiors of his mind. By virtue of this general perception he perceives truths interiorly in himself

Further:--

In things of a purely rational, moral, and spiritual nature, truths appear from their own light, provided a man by means of a good education is made in some degree rational moral, and spiritual. The reason is that every man as to his spirit which does the thinking, is in the spiritual world, and is one with those who are there consequently, he is in the spiritual light which enlightens his interiors, and as it were dictates. For spiritual light in its essence is the Divine Truth of the Lords Divine Wisdom. Hence it is that a man is able to think analytically, to draw conclusions in matters of judgment concerning what is just and fair, and to sec what is honorable in moral life, and what is good in spiritual life and also to recognize many truths which do not fall into darkness, except from falsities that have been confirmed. A man sees these things comparatively as he sees the mind of another in his face, in which he perceives his affections from the tone of his voice, without any other science than that which is connate with every one. Why, then, should not man, in some measure, see from influx the interior things of his life which are spiritual and moral when yet there is no animal which does not see from influx the things necessary to it which are natural (D. P. 317)?

Again we read:--

Every man is so constituted that he is able to see and comprehend the truth when he hears it; but a person confirmed in falsities cannot introduce the truth into his understanding so that it remains there; because it does not find there any room;

444

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 445

and if perchance, it does enter, the crowd of falsities which are congregated there casts it out as heterogeneous (T. C. R. 759).

And again:--

General perception is from influx out of heaven, and it descends into thought, even as far as sight (D. L. W. 361).

302. In addition to this general perception which enters into man out of heaven, and which enables him to perceive truths, he has also his own proper perception, which is derived from the influx of the light of the world, and which enables him to perceive the objects in the world. This latter perception is on the plane of the natural memory, which as we have seen above (no. 254, at p. 378), occupies the two lower degrees of the external man, namely, the interior and the exterior Natural, which are also called the Natural proper and the Sensual. But the natural memory, as we have likewise seen (no. 239, at p. 355), is receptive of the light of the world; wherefore, the perception which a man enjoys on the basis of his natural memory, enables him to perceive, and thus to cognize, the objects of the natural world. In the mans Natural, however, especially in his exterior Natural which is likewise called the Sensual, dwells also his own proper self; for as we have seen above (nos. 247 and 260), the mans exterior natural or sensual degree is receptive not only of the light, but also of the heat of the natural sun; and this latter heat by virtue of the influx of the Lords life is turned with man into natural love and affection, i.e., into the love of self and of the world. Hence it is that the perception which a man enjoys by virtue of the influx of light from the natural world, is specifically his own proper perception; as appears from the following passage, where the two general perceptions of which man is the recipient, are described:--

Common or general perception a man has by virtue of the influx of light out of heaven, when he hears a truth.

445

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 446

His own proper perception he has by virtue of the influx of light from the world. These two perceptions, namely, the internal and the external, or the spiritual and the natural, make one with the wise--with those who look to the Lord and shun evil (T. C. R. 461).

For when a man looks up to the Lord, his internal mind is opened, and he receives the influx of light out of heaven; and when he shuns evil, the antagonistic influx of the love of self and of the world is removed from his natural man, so that the light of heaven, and hence the general perception of the truth, is able to penetrate with him into the contents of the natural memory which receives the light of nature, and this latter light it is able to reduce into harmony with itself.

303. The character of the two-fold perception which a man enjoys by virtue of the influx into him of the light of heaven and of the light of the world, is clearly shown in whet follows:--

All perception is from the interior. There is never any perception of the interior from the exterior; for perception is from the same source from which influx is. With every person there is the faculty of perceiving whether a thing is so, or whether it is not so. The faculty of forming conclusions inwardly in ones self, that is, in ones mind, causes a thing to be perceived. This faculty is never possible, unless there is an influx from the spiritual world. This gift is more excellent in some than in others. Those who do not excel so much in that gift are they who draw inferences, and hence perceive, only little interiorly in themselves, that is, in their own mind; but who say that a thing is so, because others in whom they have confidence, have said so. But those who excel more are they who do not see from others, but from themselves, that a thing is so. With every person there is a perception in worldly things; but not, at the present day, a perception in spiritual things. The cause is, that the Spiritual which flows in, and iv productive of perception, has been obscured and almost extinguished wherefore delights of the love of the world and the love of self fore also people [nowadays] do not concern themselves about spiritual things, except from a sense of duty and from habit or custom.

446

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 447

If the fear arising from duty, and the delight which originates from habit or custom were removed, they would disdain, turn away from, yea, even deny these things.

He who intends to have perception in spiritual things must be in the affection of the truth from good, and must continually desire to know truths. Thence his Intellectual is illuminated, and after his Intellectual has been illuminated it is granted him to have some perception interiorly. But with him who is not in any affection of the truth, the knowledge of what he knows to be so, is derived from some doctrinal of the church, to which he attaches credence; and, indeed, because some priest, minister, or monk has said so (A. C. 5937).

General perception with him who does not look to the Lord, and does not repent of evil, is circumstanced thus: such a main is under the influence of the love generated in him from the heat of the natural sun, namely, the love of self and of the world, and hence he is receptive only of natural, and not of spiritual light, and, therefore, is able to perceive only natural, and not spiritual objects. By virtue of his reason, as we have seen above (no. 280), he is still able to raise his understanding into the light of heaven, and to perceive the truth when stated by another; but when he returns into his own people perception, in the lower, natural man below, his proper natural perception extinguishes what he had seen before with the perception of his spirit. This is clearly shown in the following passage, where Swedenborg first shows that by virtue of the general perception which all men enjoy by virtue of the influx of light and of heaven, they are able to see the truth on many spiritual subjects, and then continues:--

Man knows these things by virtue of general perception, but he does not know them from through or by virtue of writing them down from thought.... The reason is that thought then [i.e. when a person writes] communicates with the mans Sensual which is his own self or proprium. Hence it is that some are able to think well and to speak well, but not to write well--this is usual, with the feminine sex. A man thus recedes from general perception, when he submits the above truths to thought; but when he writes concerning these things from thought [i.e., from external thought], he confirms them from appearances and fallacies, and by words of sound and no import.

447

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 448

Hence it is that those who have thought much and written much [on the above subjects], have weakened and obscured, nay, destroyed common or general perception with themselves; and that the simple-minded see more clearly what is good and true, than those who think that they excel them in wisdom. General perception is from influx out of heaven, and enters into thought even as far as sight; but thought separate from general perception, enters into the imagination from sight and from proprium (D. L. W. 381).

304. The difference between the simple-minded and those who are wise, consists in this that the latter, actuated by the affection of the truth, have their minds furnished with an abundance of knowledges and scientifics from the Word, and the doctrines of the Church. Further, that the affection of understanding is at work in their soul, and that their spiritual mind, i.e. the spiritual degree of their national is not only opened thereby, so that they enjoy the perception of the truth, but is also formed and organized; and that under the influence of the developed with them by the process of regeneration, the rational degree of their external man, which is the plane of interior thought. With them, finally, their interior thought, which is formed from the doctrinal and rational truths in the rational degree of their external man, is based upon the knowledges and scientifics of the natural memory below, which is in the natural degree of their external man; and by means of the exterior thought which is derived thence and which is in harmony with it, the interior thought, which in the first place emanates from conscience, clothes itself in the sensual or corporeal part of the natural memory with words; which words, at last, through the principle of correspondence are expressed by the organs of the natural body in an oral or written form.

448

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 449

Such is not the case with the simple-minded. They are under the influence of the affection of spiritual truth; and under its influence their spiritual mind has been opened, so that they are able to be enlightened by spiritual light; but neither their spiritual mind, nor yet the rational degree of their natural man has actually been formed and developed. For they are indeed in the affection of spiritual truth; but they are not in the affection of understanding the truth by their own ratiocination; nor are they in the affection of seeing the truth in the natural man below, by virtue of their own thought. But they are rather in the affection of seeing the truth is the light of the rational thought of others. Of those who are wise by virtue of their own perception of, end their own thought concerning, truths, we read that the Internal of the Church is organized within them, and that they are in spiritual good, and further, that the truth in their minds is enlightened from within; but of the simple-minded we read that they are in the External of the Church, and in natural Good, and further that the truth in their minds is enlightened from without (see above, A. C. 5965, p. 360).

305. A similar condition, so far as enlightenment is concerned, prevails with those who are in the first state of their regeneration; that is, who are in a state of truth, and from truth have respect to good. They are internally in the love of the Lord and of the neighbor, and therefore their internal, spiritual mind is not only opened, but Conscience also is beginning to be formed there with them. Hence also they repent of their evils in the sight of God; nevertheless, they still desire to govern themselves, and to superintend their own course of reformation; which, as we have seen (no. 175, at page 251 et seq.), is a characteristic with man during the first three days of creation. Since man, in the beginning of regeneration, desires to do good from himself, therefore also he is not yet able then to produce genuine spiritual good.

449

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 450

This kind of good can be produced by man only, after his national has been regenerated; that is, after conscience has been established is the spiritual degree of the Rational, and after the natural-rational degree has been reformed sad regenerated by its means. On this subject we read:--

Before man is regenerated, the good of the Rational does not flow immediately into the good of the Natural; but it flows in through the truth of the Rational, and thereby causes in the Natural something which is like good; but it is not genuine good, and hence also the truth is not genuine.... For the will-principle which is good is then without, and the Intellectual which is of the truth is within. The will-principle which is then without, admits many things which are useful for regeneration but it is like a sponge which sucks in both clear and dirty waters. Hence also it imbibes such things as otherwise would be rejected; nevertheless, these things serve as means, and are also for the purpose of forming ideas concerning goods and truths, and are subservient for other uses (A. C. 3563).

And further:--

When a man is affected by the truth not for the sake of the ends of life, but for the sake of other ends, namely, that he may become learned, and indeed from some affection of emulation, and from some affection of childish envy, end also from a certain affection of glory--the good and the truth of the Natural are in such an inverted order respectively; that is, the will-principle which is of good is then without, and the Intellectual which is of truth is within (A. C. 3683).

306. So long as good with man is without, and truth within, man is enabled to see the truth when propounded by others, and he is also able to confirm such truths. Yea, he actually needs then confirmations in order to see and believe these truths. Moreover, in that state he is unable to perceive genuine truth, but requires appearances of the truth in order to perceive the truth at all. But, after conscience has been fully established in the man;

450

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 451

and after the Natural has been regenerated through conscience, then the man is able to see the truth in its own light, that is, in a state of enlightenment from the Lord, and independently of confirmations. On this subject we read:--

Those who have not the perception of good and truth, must needs be confirmed by scientifics. Every one forms to himself some idea concerning those things which he has learned, and even concerning the goods and truths of faith. Without any idea, nothing remains in the memory, except as some empty thing. Confirmations accede and fill the idea concerning a thing from other knowledges, and even from scientifics. The confirmation of an idea by several things causes that idea not only to inhere in the memory, and to be called forth thence by thought, but it even enables faith to be instilled into it (A. C. 2831).

And again:--

It was perceived that knowledges of faith must at first be confirmed by sensuous and natural truths for man cannot believe anything without confirmation. After these knowledges, however, have been confirmed, man is gifted by the Lord with conscience, so that he is able to believe apart from confirmations. He then rejects all reasonings; this is the angelic sphere in which evil spirits cannot be. So long, however, as a man is in the state in which these things are confirmed with him, and so long as he reasons concerning them, in order to convince others of the truth, evil spirits are able to be present. It is almost the same with him who is in principles; for he rejects all reasonings in opposition to principles, and is even indignant when anyone disputes them (S. D. 3977).

307. It is the mans thought which is the subject of enlightenment. For thought, as have seen, is his internal sight; and while the man is thinking, that is, while he is exercising his internal organ of sight, it is being illuminated by the light of truth which enters into him through mediate and immediate influx from the Lord. Thought, however, in order to become the subject of enlightenment should be inspired by a genuine, affirmative love, and to be conjoined with it; for enlightenment reaches the thought through affection and indeed through the affection of good.

451

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 452

Thought from a negative love excludes enlightenment; for thought from a negative love sees in natural and not in spiritual light.

Thought from an affirmative, spiritual love, again, as we have seen, is different with the simple-minded from what it is with the wise.
