For a simple-minded person sees the truth by virtue of general perception, when it is presented to him by another; but he does not see it by any exercise of his own

Again, thought from an affirmative, spiritual love differs with the man when he is in the first, and in the second state of regeneration. So long as he is in the first state, and is led from truth to good, he enjoys enlightenment in general; but he sees the truth then from without and not yet from within; and, again, he sees it in the light of confirmations, but not yet in the light of faith which is the light that illuminates conscience.

Thought before regeneration is from first national (see above, no. 281), the things which, as we have seen, pass only a very little beyond the ideas of the corporeal memory, which are respectively quite material. Thought during the first state of regeneration is from conscience--yet, from the exterior conscience of what is just and fair; and, again, it is from the confirmations of a truth, seen in the light of others, and thus seen from without, and not from within. During the second state of regeneration, when a man acts from the good of charity in the first place, and when 1re perceives the truth from good, his thought is from the interior conscience of what is good and true, and the truths from which he thinks in the natural mind, are enlightened from within, through the good with which they are conjoined.

308. Before a man enters upon his regeneration his thought is from his own self, and thus from proprium;

452

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 453

but after he has entered upon his regeneration, he begins to think from the Lord--at first in a general way; but in proportion to the accumulation, and the rational digestion by himself, of the spiritual truths of the Divine Word; and in the proportion in which he humbles his first national before the Lord, and desires to be led by the Lord through His Divine Truth, not only the generals, but also the particulars of his thought come from the Lord. On this subject we read:--

There are two states of thought with man. One when he is in thought concerning truths from the Lord; and another when he is in thought from himself. When he is in thought concerning truths from the Lord, his mind is raised even into the light of heaven; thence he has enlightenment and a just perception of truth. But when he is in thought concerning truths from himself, his mind lapses into the light of the world; and this light in respect to respect to those things which belong to heaven and the Church, is in dense darkness. In that darkness a man sees only such things as shine from the fire of the love of self and of the world, which in themselves are falsities opposed to truths (A. E. 817).

309. No man thinks in reality from himself, but from others. This is a general truth taught by Swedenborg, as in what follows:--

The influx into man from the spiritual world is circumstanced in a general way thus: A man cannot think, nor will anything from himself; but all enters into him by influx--good and truth from the Lord through heaven, and hence through the angels who are with the man; and evil and falsity from hell, and hence through the evil spirits who are with the man. This influx takes place into a mans thought, and into his will (A. C. 5846).

If thought thus flows into man through the angels who are with him, it follows that spiritual enlightenment which takes place into thought, must likewise be communicated to a man through the mediation of the angels who are with him. On this subject we read:--

Every man as to his thoughts and affections is in the spiritual world--consequently, as to his spirit;

453

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 454

for a mans spirit it is which thinks and is affected. The man who has become spiritual through regeneration by the Lord as to his spirit is in a heavenly society.... With this man goods constantly flow in out of heaven, and are also received by him; and since goods flow into his affection, and through affection into the thought, he has enlightenment (A. E. 759)

If spiritual enlightenment, however, is conveyed to a man through the mediation of the angels of heaven, the reverse of enlightenment must flow in with him when he is in the association With evil spirits; as is shown in A. C. 4967 (at p. 370).

Thoughts are thus communicated to a man by his attendant angels and spirits; but when the man with his affections takes hold of those thoughts which are communicated to him by others, and which result in the first place from the truths stored up in his mind, to which the angels and spirits attendant upon him have access, these thoughts themselves extend far and wide from him into the spiritual world, and indeed from one society there to another; and they derive strength and stability from the life and light of those several societies--the thoughts growing stronger and clearer as they proceed in that way. On this subject we read:--

The thoughts of man are extensions into societies either of heaven or of hell; and unless they were extensions, they would not have being. A mans thought is like the sight of his eyes in this respect that unless it had extension outside of itself it would either be none, or it would be blind. It is a mans love that determines his thought into societies a good love determines it into heavenly societies, and a wicked love into infernal societies.

A mans love is comparatively like fire, and his thoughts are like rays of light. If the love is good, the thoughts which are like rays are falsities. Thoughts from a good love, which are truths, tend towards heaven, and thoughts from an evil love, which are falsities, tend towards hell; they join themselves to, and fit and inoculate themselves, as if were, into homogeneous societies; namely, into such as are in a similar love.

The light which is the truth of faith, and the heat which is the good of love--both from the Lord, flow into the societies with which the mans love acts as one....

454

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 455

Not even the least thing of thought can exist unless there is some reception of it in some society--not with the individuals there, that is, with, the angels of heaven but with the affection of love, from which, and in which that society is. Hence the angels know nothing of that influx [of a mans thought], nor does that influx disturb their society in any way (A. E. 1093).

310. There is a great difference between the thought which arises from truth and thus from doctrine, and the thought which flows from love; and hence between the mans thought during the first state of his regeneration wen from truth he has respect to good, and his thought during the second state of his regeneration, when from good he has respect to truth. We thus read:--

There is thought of light and thought of love. The thought of light alone is the thought that there is a God, which thought appears like acknowledgment; yet it is not acknowledgment. The thought of light causes a mans presence in heaven, but it does not conjoin him to heaven.... But the thought of love causes a mans conjunction with heaven; because love is spiritual conjunction. When a mans thought of light, therefore, becomes the thought of his love, he is introduced into heaven, as into a marriage; and in proportion as love takes the first place in the thought of light, or as it leads that thought, in the same proportion the man enters into heaven, as a bride into the bridal chamber and becomes married. By being married is meant becoming conjoined with heaven in some one of its societies; and a man becomes conjoined with heaven in the same proportion in which he acquires to himself in the world intelligence and wisdom from the Lord through the Word; thus in the proportion in which through Divine truths he learns to think that there is a God, and that the Lord is that God (A. E. 1096, 1099).

As there is thought of light, there is also thought NOT of light, concerning which we read:--

There is thought of light concerning God and the Divine things which in heaven are called celestial and spiritual, and in the world ecclesiastica1 and theological; and there is thought NOT of light concerning these things: The thought not of light is with those who are acquainted with these things, but do not understand them....

455

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 456

These persons are not from the interior in a genuine affection of truth, and hence not in any enlightenment (A. E. 1100).

311. The doctrine of thought, as unfolded in the preceding pages, in a summary, is as follows:First, a mans thought is twofold: interior and exterior; interior thought is in the rational degree of the external man, and exterior thought in the plane of the natural memory, that is, in the interior sphere of that memory where are scientifics and knowledges. Secondly, interior thought may be thought of light, or thought of love. Interior thought with man during the first state of his regeneration is thought of light, during the second state it becomes thought of love. Thirdly, the mans thought may either be thought from God, or thought from ones own self. A man thinks from God when he is regenerated by the Lord, and he thinks from his own self before he is regenerated. When he thinks from God, he thinks from the light of heaven; when he thinks from his own self, he thinks from the light of the world.

Thought is identical with a mans interior sight; wherefore by saying that a mans thought is twofold, that is, interior and exterior, we mean to say at the same time that his intellectual sight is twofold. In reality, however, a mans thought and hence his intellectual sight, which by Swedenborg is called apperception, is threefold, as appears from the following passage:--

There is actually apperception from the Sensual or the exterior Natural, apperception from the interior Natural, and apperception from the Rational. For when a man is in interior thought from affection, and withdraws the mind from sensual things and from the body, he is in rational appreciation; for then the things which are below, or which belong to the external man, are quiescent, and the man is then as it were, in his spirit. But when the man is in exterior thought, from causes which exist in the world, his apperception is from the interior Natural the national, indeed, flows in, but not with any life of the affection.

456

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 457

But when a man is in pleasures, and in the delights of the love of the world, and also of the love of self, his apperception is from the Sensual; his life is then in outward things or in the body, and does not admit from the interiors anything more than will moderate eruptions into dishonorable and unbecoming acts. The more exterior an apperception, the more obscure it is; for external things are comparatively general, because innumerable internal things appear as one m the exterior (A. C. 5141).

312. Thought naturally exists long before a man comes into that thought, which results from the affection of seeing what he knows and understands. This also is plainly stated above (in D. L. W. 404, see no. 295), where we read: Thought, indeed, exists at first, because it belongs to the natural mind; but thought from the perception of the truth which arises from the affection of [understanding] the truth, exists last. This latter thought is the thought of wisdom, but the former thought is thought from the memory through the sight of the natural mind.

The same also follows from the fact that mans intellectual sight, i.e., his apperception, as we have just seen, is threefold, according as he thinks either from the Sensual, i.e., the exterior Natural, or from the interior Natural, or finally from the Rational, i.e., the natural degree of the Rational, which is also called the spiritual-natural.

The same follows again from the fact that each division of a mans interiors, as stated above (in S. D. 4627, see p. 386) has a distinct light or lumen; that there is accordingly (1) the sensual lumen (see above, no. 260), (2) the light of the interior natural degree (see no. 261), and the light of the rational or spiritual-natural degree, concerning which we read that it exists partly from the light of heaven in natural light (see no. 262).

In infancy and childhood a man thinks from the sensual degree; in advanced youth, under the influence of imagination, from the interior natural degree;

457

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 458

and when he enters into the age of manhood, and suffers himself to be regenerated by the Lord, he thinks from the rational degree; thus we read:--

By the ultimate Sensual we mean the ultimate of thought and affection which is first opened with children, and which is such that they do not think anything else, nor are affected by any other objects than such as make one with the senses of the body. For children learn to think through the senses, and to be affected with objects according to those things which have pleased their senses. Wherefore the first Internal which is opened with them is that Sensual which is called mans ultimate Sensual, and afterwards the corporeal Sensual. Afterwards, however, when the child grows up and becomes a youth a more interior Sensual [i.e., the interior Natural] is opened with him, from which he thinks naturally, and is also affected naturally. At last, when he becomes a young man, a still more interiors Sensual [the natural Rational] is opened with him, from which he thinks rationally, and if he is in the good of charity and faith spiritually; and he is also affected in a rational and spiritual manner. This latter thought and affection is what is called the rational and the spiritual man (A. E. 543).

Again we read:--

With every man the interiors which belong to thought and affection are opened successively, and, indeed, through a perpetual influx from the Lord out of heaven. Through this Influx there is first formed the Sensual which adheres proximately to the body; whence man becomes natural. Afterwards there is formed the Natural, whence he becomes natural. After this there is formed the national, and with it the Spiritual, from which a man becomes rational and spiritual. But he becomes so in proportion as he thinks concerning God and concerning the Divine things which are from God; and he is formed and perfected in proportion as he is affected with these things, that is, in proportion as he wills and lives according to them. But if this is not the case, the spiritual man is opened in a merely general way, and is not formed and still less perfected. By the spiritual man being opened in a general way, a man has the faculty of thinking and speaking rationally from thought; for this is the general effect of the influx of heaven with every man (A. E. 643).

313. In order that a man may grow spiritually, and that the spiritual man in him may not only be opened, but also formed and perfected, it is absolutely necessary that he should think spiritually, end not naturally;

458

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 459

that, therefore, he should think Under the influence of spiritual freedom, and not of natural freedom (see above, no. 278), and should have his mind richly stored with genuine spiritual truths from the Divine Word. Those who think from spiritual freedom think from God; for spiritual freedom is inherent in the love of the Lord and in the love of the neighbor, in which loves the Lord is present with man; while those who think from natural freedom think from their own self, and thus from hell; as appears from what follows:--

Spiritual thoughts and affections are with those who think concerning God and Divine things from God; but merely natural thoughts and affections exist with those who do not think of God and Divine things from God; but who from their own self and from the world think of themselves and the world. It is to be observed, however, that thinking from ones own self and from the world does not mean thinking from ones own self, but from hell. For he who does not think from God, thinks from hell. No one can think from both at the same time.

Those who deny God; and hence Divine things, that is, those things which belong to heaven and the Church, and who confirm themselves against them, become all more or less sensual men, according to the [character of their] confirmations. When they think of spiritual things, they think mere falsities, and are affected with evils; and if they do think of any truths, whether they be spiritual, moral or civil, it is from a mere knowledge of such things stored up in the memory. Beyond the most proximate causes which they are also able to confirm, they see nothing; and if they are affected by goods, it is merely from a delight for the sake of self or the world; thus from a lust which belongs to the love of self, or to the love of the world.

Mans sensual thought is called material thought, and his affection, which is mere lust, is called corporeal affection (A. E. 543).

No matter whether a man thinks on the rational, interior natural, or sensual sphere of his natural or external man, there is an Internal and an External in his thought.

459

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 460

The Internal of his thought is from his lifes love, and the External from the contents of his memory, as appears from what follows:--

The Internal of the thought is from the lifes love and its affections, and the perceptions flowing thence. The External of the thought is from those things which are in the memory, and which serve the lifes love for confirmations, and for means towards an end from infancy to young manhood a man is in the External of thought from the affection of knowing, which then constitutes his Internal; something of lust, also, and hence of the inclinations from the lifes love from parents is present, and abets. But afterwards, a mans lifes love is determined by the character of his life; the affections of that love and the perceptions to which they give rise, cause then the Internal of his thought; and from the life s love is derived the love of means, the delights of which love together with the matters of knowledge excited from the memory cause then the External of his thought (D. P. 105).

We thus read again:--

A mans internal sight, i. e., his thought, is determined by his intention; but that intention is the will of the man (H. H. 532).

314. There is a difference between interior thought and the Internal of thought. Interior thought exists only with those who are being regenerated by the Lord, and hence have conscience; but all, even the unregenerate, have an Internal of thought. The Internal and External of thought make one with those who have a heavenly love; but with those who act from a selfish or worldly love, the Internal of thought often disagrees with its External. We thus read:--

With those who have conscience, interior thought from the Lord flows through their internal, into the interior, rational man; which may appear from this circumstance that they are able to notice the evil and the false which is in their natural man, and which combats against the good and the true in the interior [the rational] man.... But those who have no conscience cannot have any interior thought, wherefore also with them there is no combat; for their Rational acts as one with the Sensual of the body;

460

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 461

and although good and truth constantly flow in with them from the Lord, still they do not notice them, because they immediately extinguish and suffocate them; hence also they do not believe any truth of faith (A. C. 1935).

Again we read:--

With those who are in a heavenly love, the Internal and the External of thought, that is, the internal and the external man, act as one when they speak; nor are they aware of any distinction between them. The love of their life with its affections of good and the perceptions of truth of these affections is like a soul in those things which they think, and thence speak and act. If they are priests they preach from the love of the neighbor, and the love of God; if judges they judge from the very principle of justice; if merchants they act from the very principle of sincerity; and if they are married they love their wife from the feeling of chastity itself, and so forth. Their lifes love also has a love of means, as a vice-gerent, which it teaches and leads so as to act from prudence; and this love it invests with the garments of zeal for the truths of doctrine and at the same time for the goods of life (D. P. 110).

315. The Internal of thought, as we have seen, with the regenerate, is their interior thought, which under the influence of conscience is formed in the rational degree of the external man. Wherefore the homestead of interior thought is the rational degree, that is, the rational degree of the natural or external man, which is identical with the natural degree of the national; from that degree there is an ascent into the celestial and spiritual degree, of the national. With the unregenerate, on the other hand, the Internal of their thought comes from an interior mind, which, as we have seen above (A. E. 406, p. 365), is formed with them in the lower parts of their external natural man, which are under the influence of the natural loves of self and of the world, and enlightened by the light of nature. This mind, with such persons, consists of mere falsities and evils--and, indeed, for this reason, that the spiritual mind is not opened with them.

461

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 462

Interior thought, again, with the regenerate, springs from the internal memory which is in the rational mind, or in the rational degree of the external man; while exterior thought comes from the external memory. In that internal memory there are contained the doctrinal or rational truths which, as we have seen above (A. C. 3652, in no. 297), have respect to use, and are acquired from scientifics by reflexion; but in the external memory are scientifics and knowledges. In the internal memory, also, which is the homestead of interior thought, there are recorded all things that a man has willed and thought, acted and spoken, from his lifes love. Therefore, also, the internal or spiritual memory is a mans book of life, because the things which are there have all become matters of life, and can never more be blotted out. The internal memory likewise, by virtue of the life which is contained in everything belonging to it, flows into the external memory, and imparts life to the things which are there; yea there is no life in the things contained in the external memory, unless they are inscribed at the same time on the internal memory. All these points are clearly set forth in the following passages:--

Every man has two memories, namely, a natural memory and a spiritual memory, and he can think from either memory. He thinks from the natural [or external] memory when he speaks with men in the world; but he thinks from the spiritual [or internal] memory when he speaks from his spirit. This, however, he does rarely with another person, but only with himself; which is meant by thinking (A. E. 569).

We read again:--

The things which are inscribed on the interior memory are not called scientifics, because they are the things of a mans life; but they are called truths which are of faith, and goods which are of love (A. C. 9922).

And again:--

What is inscribed on the internal memory remains to eternity, and is never blotted out.

462

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 463

This consists especially of those things that have become matters of the will, that is, matters of love; for the things of love belong to the will (A. C. 9388).

And again:--

The truths of the external or natural memory which are scientifics have no life, unless they are at the same time in the internal or spiritual memory; for the things in that memory have become matters of life; inasmuch as the internal or spiritual memory is a mans book of life (A. C. 9841).

We read further:--

Scientifics, i.e., the objects of the memory, upon becoming matters of a mans life, vanish from the external memory; such as is wont to be the case with the gestures, actions, speeches, reflexions, intentions, and in general with the thoughts and affections of man, after they through constant use or habit have become, as it mere, natural and spontaneous. But no other things become matters of a mans life, except those which enter into the delights of his love and form them; thus, which enter into his life (A. C. 9394).

From this, however, it does not follow that all things which vanish from the external memory pass from the external into the internal memory. Things may vanish either from the external or the internal memory; and they do vanish from both memories when by practice a man becomes familiar with them; as appears from what follows:--

Whatever enters into a man remains, especially if it be received with affection. It is thought that when a man no longer remembers certain things, they are altogether obliterated and rejected; but such is not the case; for these things, either in the interior or in the exterior memory, enter among those things which are made familiar by practice. These things become then, as it mere, natural, and flow forth of their own accord, without it being necessary to stir them up from the memory by a sensible recollection (A. C. 7398).

316. From what we learned above it appears that the regenerate only, that is, those who have conscience, have interior thought; for with them only there is organized the natural-rational degree of the external man, which is the plane of the internal or spiritual memory. This natural-rational degree is a new creation from within.

463

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 464

It is formed out of the contents of the natural memory, under the influence of conscience, and thus of the charity and faith which are there; and, therefore, it is a product of regeneration. It is created on the fifth and sixth days of creation. As to its intellectual ingredients it is formed on the fifth day, and as to its affectional or voluntary ingredients, on the sixth day. The creation from within, however, is not limited to the natural-rational degree, and thus to the internal memory, which is the plane of interior thought; but it is also continued into the sphere of exterior thought in the external, natural memory. From the internal memory, therefore, the rational ingredients of this memory constantly descend into the natural memory below; so that in proportion as a man advances in his regeneration, the contents of his natural memory become twofold; for it contains then not only scientifics or knowledges received through the senses from without, but also rational ingredients from within. On this subject we read:--

Into the external or natural memory of man there enter, on the one hand, objects from the world through sensual things, and, on the other hand, there enter into it objects through rational things. These two kinds of objects separate in the memory. The objects that enter there through rational things place themselves more interiorly, while those that enter through sensual things, place themselves more exteriorly; wherefore the Natural becomes twofold, interior and exterior. Hence it is that a person who thinks and forms conclusions from the interior Natural, in proportion as he draws upon what hits entered there through the Rational is rational; while he who thinks and forms conclusions from the exterior Natural, in so far as he draws upon what is derived from the things of the senses, is sensual. Such a man also is called sensual, while the former is called natural-rational (A. C. 5094).

Again we read:--

The interior Natural is that which receives the ideas of truth and good from the Rational, and stores them up for use, consequently, it communicates immediately with the Rational while the exterior Natural is that which receives images, and hence the ideas of things, through sensual things from the world.

464

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 465

Unless these latter ideas are enlightened by those which are in the interior Natural, they present fallacies and when a man is in them he believes nothing except what agrees with them. The same is the case if these two latter things are not confirmative, as happens when there is no correspondence. Correspondence, however, is not brought about unless a man is imbued with charity, because in the good of charity there is life from the Lord, which arranges truths into order, so that the form of charity, that is, charity in an image, is presented (A. C. 5133).

317. In order that there may be enlightenment in the natural man, and thus in the sphere of a mans natural consciousness, it is absolutely necessary that the regeneration of the external man shall be continued into the middle degree of the external man called the interior Natural; and thus that the interior thought which is generated from the contents of the internal memory in the natural-rational degree, shall be supported and received by a corresponding exterior thought which is generated from the scientifics in the external memory. In this case also the scientifics which are in the external memory from the Word are enlightened by spiritual light from within, and the man is able to corroborate spiritual by natural truths. We thus read:--

Those who are in external things apart from any internal cannot be enlightened, and hence also they cannot be confirmed in truths. But they who are in external, and at the same time in internal things, are enlightened when reading the Word; and while in a state of enlightenment they see truths which afterwards become more and more confirmed (A. C. 7012).

Again we read:--

With a man in whom the Natural corresponds to the Rational, the communication is open, so that the light of the Natural, and enlighten the same with intelligence and wisdom; and, therefore, such a man is rational, and thinks spiritually ... for a man thinks according to the influx of the light of heaven (A. C. 3679).

318. At the present time man is being regenerated as to the rational and interior natural degrees of his external man, but not as far as the exterior natural or sensual degree;

465

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 466

although the contents of this latter degree have to be reduced into a state of correspondence with the higher regenerated degrees. By the Divine mercy of the Lord, however, it is provided that the man who is being regenerated is separated from the evils and falsities of the lowest sensual degree, and kept by the Lord in the goods and truths of the two higher degrees of the external man. We read on this subject:--

When a man is being regenerated, it is necessary that his Natural shall be regenerated down to the Sensual; for, unless this is regenerated, there is no reception of truth and good, because the inflowing truth is perverted there, and in that case the interiors are closed up. When, therefore, the exterior degrees have been regenerated, the whole man is regenerated (John xiii. 9). When the man is thus regenerated even as to his Natural, all things are then subordinated to the interiors; and when interior things flow in, they flow in as to their generals, and become sensible thereby to the man. When such is the case with a man he feels the affection of truth which is of faith, and the affection of good which is of charity. But the Sensual itself which is the ultimate of the Natural, can be regenerated only with difficulty, because it is altogether filled with material things derived from earthly, bodily, and worldly things. Wherefore, the man who is being regenerated, especially at the present clay is not regenerated as to the Sensual, but as to the Natural which is proximately above the Sensual. To this Natural he is elevated by the Lord when he thinks concerning the goods and truths of faith. With the faculty of being elevated above the Sensual, the man who is being regenerated by the Lord, is gifted by the Lord (A. C. 7442).

And again:--

From the Sensual which is in the outermost parts of the natural mind, and consequently from the falsities originating from evil which are there, those can he elevated who are in good and truth; and when they are elevated, they are also separated from the falsities which are there (A. C. 7443).

That the contents of the exterior natural or sensual degree, however, although that degree itself is not regenerated, have to be reduced into a state of correspondence with the interior, regenerated degrees of the external man, is plainly stated in what follows:--

466

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 467

The Sensual itself is not reduced into order, but those things which through the Sensual have entered into a man a phantasy. Sensual things, that is, those things which through the organs of external sense have entered from the world are reduced into order when they are in the last place; and they are in the last place when they minister or serve interior things. With those who are regenerate, sensual things are in the last place, but with the unregenerate they are in the first place. Whether sensual things are in the first or last place can be easily recognized by a man if he pays attention.... If he does not affirm all that the Sensual subjects and craves, and if he does not try to make of none effect all that the Intellectual dictates, but if, on the contrary, he sees from the interior how the things of the senses lead a man into falsities and excite him to evils, and if he tries to coerce these things and to reduce them into a state of obedience that is, to subject them to the intellectual and to the will-part which belong to the interior man, then sensual things with him are reduced into a state of order, so as to be in the last place. When sensual things are in the last place a feeling of blessedness and beatitude flows from the interior man into the delights of sensual things, and causes these delights to exceed a thousand times the previous delights (A. C. 5125).

When the things of the senses are reduced into order they are subjected to the Rational, and then these things are illuminated by the light of heaven, and the man himself enjoys a state of spiritual enlightenment. We thus read:--

The man with whom sensual things are in a state of subjection is called rational; but he with whom they are not subjected is called sensual.... When the things of the senses are subjected to the Rational, those sensual things from whence arose the mans first imagination are enlightened by the light which comes from the Lord through heaven. Sensual things, also, are arranged then into order so as to receive light and to correspond. When sensual things are in such order they no longer prevent truths from being acknowledged and seen; the things which disagree being immediately removed, and those accepted which agree. The things that agree are then, as it were, in the centres, and those that disagree in the circumferences. The things in the centres are then, as it were, raised heavenwards, and those in the circumferences hang, as it were downwards.

467

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 468

The things in the centres receive the Rational, and when presented to the sight in appear like sparkling little stars, and they shed life everywhere around, even to the circumferences, with a diminution of light according to degrees. Natural and sensual things are arranged into such order when the Rational has dominion, and sensual things are in a state of subjection. Such is the case when a man is being regenerated; and from thence he is in a condition to see and acknowledge truths in great fullness.

The reverse is the case when the Rational is subject to things sensual; for then falsities are in the middle or in the centre, and in the circumferences are truths. The things which are in the centre, are in a certain light (lumen) there, but in a fatuous light, or in such a light as arises from a coal-fire. Into that light there flows in from all sides a luminosity (lumen) from hell. That luminosity is called darkness; for as soon as any light from heaven flows into it, it is turned into darkness (A. C. 5128).

Interior things, we learn, are thus beginning to have dominion over exterior things; and exterior things are beginning to serve the interior, when the order in the state of regeneration is beginning to be inverted; that is, when the member of the Church is beginning to look from good to truth (see A. C. 5159).

319. When the external man has been regenerated as far as the interior Natural, and when sensual things have been reduced into a state of subjection to the Rational; and when in consequence of this a man can be elevated by the Lord into his regenerated interior Natural, away from the Sensual, the member of the Church has reached the end of the sixth day of creation. We then read concerning him, And God blessed them, and God said unto them, Be fruitful and multiply and replenish the earth and subdue it; and have dominion over the fish of the sea and over the fowl of the heavens, and over every living thing that creepeth upon the earth. Since the lowest degree of the external man, the exterior natural or sensual degree, is not yet regenerated with the member of the Church--although its contents are reduced into a state of harmony with the interior degrees of the external man which are conjoined with heaven, and thus with the Lord

468

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 469

through the hereditary states of his sensual man he is still exposed to assaults by the evil spirits of hell. Yet the man who has reached the sixth day, always conquers; wherefore he is said to subdue the earth and to have dominion. On this subject we read:--

While the man is being regenerated, and becomes spiritual, he is constantly in a state of combat, wherefore the Church is called the Church militant.... The time of combat is the time of the Lords operation; nor does the Lord rest, before love becomes the ruling power; then the battle ceases. At the end of the sixth day the evil spirits retire and good spirits succeed, and the man is introduced into heaven (A. C. 59, 63).

At the end of the sixth day the inversion of state which was begun on the fourth day is consummated and charity thereby becomes the governing power in the regenerate member of the Church. The Lords spiritual kingdom is now established in full in his spirit, and its interiors are being further opened in the direction of the Lords celestial kingdom which is represented by the seventh day. Concerning this additional opening of the interiors of the man who has reached the sixth day of creation, we read:--

So long as the man is still being regenerated as to his Rational and also as to his Natural, the periods of the first state--which are from the truths belonging to faith to the goods belonging to charityprevail in him, and the truths of faith apparently are in the first place, and the goods of charity in the second; for the truths of faith have respect to the goods of charity as an end. These same periods continue until the man has been regenerated.

Afterwards charity which had been the end becomes the beginning; and new states commence from it. These new states progress in both directions; namely, towards the interiors in the direction of love to the Lord [celestial love], and also towards the exteriors in the direction of the truths of faith, and even still farther in the direction of natural truths, and at last in that of sensual truths. All these are successively reduced into correspondence with the goods of charity and of love in the Rational, and thus into heavenly order.

469

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 470

Such progressions are perpetual with the man who is being regenerated, from infancy to the last state of his life in the world, and afterwards to eternity (A. C. 5122).

320. We are now able to take a retrospect, and to obtain a clear and definite idea of the Lords government of man, during regeneration, by His immediate and His mediate influx.

There are two states in mans regeneration. In the first state he is led from truth to good; in the second from good to truth. The first state extends through the first three days of creation. The second state begins at the fourth day, and is finished on the seventh.

During the first state of regeneration man is led by the Lords immediate influx (see A. C. 8625, 8701, at p. 344). The Lords immediate influx takes place into the inmost region of mans mind. It enters there into the mans will, and is thus equivalent to the influx of good into a mans soul. This influx of good--the result of the Lords immediate influx--passes through the internal into the external man, and manifests itself there at first by the affection of acquiring knowledge, which leads to the affection of the truth. Afterwards it causes in man the affection of understanding, which is productive of the perception of the truth. Through His immediate influx, also, the Lord superintends the implantation of remains in the soul of man.

Through the Lords immediate influx, preparation is made in the man for the reception of the Lords mediate influx through the angels of heaven. For by the affection of acquiring knowledge, and the affection of the truth, which are caused by Lords immediate influx into man, he is impelled to store his natural memory with scientifics and knowledges from the Word.

470

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 471

The man acquires these knowledges by the application of his own freedom and rationality, wherefore these knowledges of the truth are at first much alloyed in his mind with appearances from nature, and with the mans own opinions, the results of his self-intelligence. Moreover, in the beginning a man sees these knowledges in the light of others, and not is his own light. Through those knowledges which are derived from the Word the member of the Church is conjoined with the angels of heaven, and receives from them the Lords mediate influx which takes place into the understanding.

The truths and knowledges in a mans mind appear either in spiritual or in natural light, according as the mans spiritual mind is either opened or closed. The spiritual mind becomes opened in a man in the proportion in which he acknowledges the Lord as the only God of heaven and earth, and bows before Him his pride of intellect--his first Rational. Light, thee enters into his mind from within, and he acknowledges the reality of the Divine revelation. This is the first day of creation. Under the influence of the heavenly light, and with the application of his freedom and rationality--the result of the Lords immediate influx into man--he next divides sharply between the knowledge which is derived from the natural world, and that which comes to man by Revelation. This he does while under the full influence of the affection of the truth; then then also he delights in the acquisition of knowledges from the Writings of the Church. He arrives now at the second day of creation. A new affection, caused by the Lords immediate influx, rises next in the man--the affection of understanding what he has learned. Under the influence of this affection he begins to see with his own eyes, and no longer with the eyes of others. He sees that the Divine Truth is true, and he confirms the Divine Truth in his mind by rational considerations; he also begins to repent actively of his evils, as sins before God.

471

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 472

The third day of the creation now dawns upon him, and the exterior conscience of what is just and fair is being established in him. In proportion as the man practices repentance of the evils which spring from the loves of self and of the world, his spiritual mind is opened, and in proportion as he begins to love the truth for its own sake, the Lord summons the truths which the man acknowledges as true, into his internal, spiritual man, conjoining them in that part with the good of charity. By this means, the Lord organizes in the man, the interior conscience of what is good and true. Charity and faith now takes their rise in the mans interior, spiritual man, and he enters upon the fourth day of creation. Truth or faith at first predominates in the mans conscience; but an inversion gradually takes place there. For the man, in the hidden recesses of his conscience, declares now in favor of the good of charity, and places that good in the first, and the truth of faith in the second place. So far as his interior, spiritual man is concerned, the man leaves then the first state of regeneration, and enters upon the second state. From truth, or by means of truth he has ascended to the good of love, and the descent from good to truth begins to take place. On this subject we read:--

When the regenerate man, that is, he who is born anew, has arrived at the Celestial of love, the Lord appears to him; for he has ascended from the lowest step, as by a ladder to the highest step where the Lord is. This ascent also is signified by the ladder which appeared to Jacob placed on the earth, whose head reached into heaven, on which the angels of God ascended and descended, and above which stood Jehovah or the Lord (Gen. xxviii. 12).... The descent now takes place; for a man cannot descend unless he has first ascended. The descent means nothing else than from good to behold truth; as a man who has ascended a mountain, from that mountain gazes upon the things which are below. He can then, with one glance, take in innumerable things, as is plain to everyone.

472

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 473

The case is the same with those who are in good, that is, in love to the Lord and towards the neighbor compared with those who are in truth, i.e., in faith alone (A. C. 3882).

321. A state of enlightenment has now been brought about in the interiors; but the sight of the internal, spiritual man is as yet dim, because the external man is not yet in a state of correspondence with the internal man (see above, A. C. 3493, in no. 293). This new state of correspondence is being brought about during the descent, when the man from good beholds truth. The Lord, by His immediate influx into the will of the member of the Church, excites next in him the affection of seeing in the natural man the truth which he perceives in the spiritual man; that is, in the plane of conscience. This affection is productive of thought, in accordance with the voice of conscience. Those four media are now brought into requisition which are mentioned at p. 231, namely, (1) the principle of Affirmation, (2) Temptation, (3) the Good of Faith, (4), the Delights of the Affections of Good and Truth.

The power of the hereditary loves of self and of the world which had been established from youth up in the natural man has now to be broken systematically, and the evil spirits of hell have to be dislodged from it. A strong phalanx of doctrinal truths has to be established for this purpose in the highest--the rational degree of the natural man, for conscience to rest upon, and so that conscience, by means of these truths may operate against the hereditary loves of self and of the world in the natural man. Both the mediate influx good descends from the internal into the external and is productive in the understanding of the affection of seeing, in the external man, the truth which has been perceived in the internal man.

473

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 474

This affection, which is intrinsically the affection of the truth for the sake of the truth and for the sake of life, on its rise in the external man, is productive there of the principle of Affirmation, (see above, nos. 165-170), by virtue of which the man acknowledges unreservedly the authority of the Divine Truth as a principle of thought and a principle of life. Under the influence of the affection which constitutes this principle of Affirmation, doctrinal and rational truths are extracted from the knowledges in the natural memory, and these truths rest upon the scientifics and the knowledges in the latter memory. This principle of Affirmation, under the influence of which the man humbles his intellectual self or proprium before the Divine Truth, and acknowledges it as his supreme law, inaugurates in man those spiritual temptations which are described in the Doctrine of Temptations (from nos. 181 to 202). Affirmation and Temptation are the first two media by which the natural man is reduced into a state of correspondence with the spiritual man, and conjoined with it. Thus far truth--doctrinal truth--is still the prevailing element in the natural man below; although faith is conjoined with charity in the internal conscience of the spiritual man--although, therefore, the supremacy of charity is practically acknowledged in that part. Doctrinally this acknowledgment prevails also in the natural man; nevertheless, the arrangement of good and truth in the natural man is still of the kind as described above (no. 305, at p. 448), where truth is within and good without; which good, however, is not genuine good. This arrangement has now to be inverted, and for this purpose Good has to be developed interiorly in the truth of the natural man. All the truths of faith, in fact, in the natural man, require now to be turned into the Good of Faith, which is the third medium, by which the natural man is to be reduced into a state of correspondence with the spiritual man, and conjoined with it.

474

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 475

The method by which this is brought about has been described above (at p. 257) in this way:--

Truth becomes the good of truth [or the good of faith] thus: Every Divine truth has respect to these two commandments; namely, to loving the Lord above all things, and the neighbor as ones self. These are the commandments or precepts from which, and for the sake of which, truths are; and to these precepts truths have reference more proximately, or more remotely. When truths, therefore, are put into act, they are successively insinuated into their principle and end; namely, into charity towards the neighbor and love towards the Lord; and by this means truth becomes the good which is called the good of truth. When such is the case, truth [in the natural man] can be conjoined with the internal man; and this conjunction becomes successively more interior the more the truths implanted in that good are interior (A. C. 4353).

As to the actual method by which truths in the natural man become the goods of truth or the goods of faith, we read further:--

All uses from truths are goods of truth. Those truths which are not of use are separated; some are retained and others rejected. Those which are retained are they which introduce to good either more remotely or more proximately, and thus they are of use. Those which are rejected are such as do not introduce, and as do not apply themselves. All uses in the beginning are truths of doctrine, but in progress of time they become goods; and they become goods when the man acts according to them. Action itself thus qualifies truths. For all action descends from the will, and the will itself causes that which before was truth to become good. Thence it appears that truth in will is no longer a truth of faith, but the good of faith; and that the truth of faith makes no one happy but the good of faith; for this affects that very something which is the mans life, namely, his willing; and it imparts to him that interior delight or blessedness, and in the other life that happy life, which is called heavenly joy (A. C. 4984).

Concerning this transformation of the truth of faith into the good of faith, which at last culminates in heavenly blessedness, we read further:--

The act precedes, a mans willing follows; for what a man does from the understanding he at last does from the will, and finally he puts it on by habit; and then that truth, or that good of truth, is insinuated into the rational, i.e., into the internal men; and after it has been insinuated into it, a man no longer does good from truth but from good for then he perceives something blessed, something of heaven in the doing of it (A. C. 4353).

475

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 476

322. The feeling of blessedness which results when the good of truth, that is, the good of faith, has become habitual with a member of the Church, is identical with the Delights of the Affection of Good and Truth is the natural man, which constitute the fourth and last medium, by which the natural man is reduced into a state of correspondence with the spiritual man and conjoined with it.

When the conjunction of good and truth has thus been effected in the external man, that is, in the rational and interior-natural degrees of the same, then also the life and light of the internal man flows freely into the external man, and blesses it with a state of enlightenment from within. For the immediate influx of the Lord is then conjoined with His mediate influx, not only in the plane of conscience in the internal man, but also in the natural man below. But when not only the Internal, but also the External in man is prepared to receive the influx of the Lords Divine Humanity, then the man is in a state of day-light as to his spirit; for we read:--

By virtue of the Divine Natural which the Lord put on [when in the world], He enlightens now not only the internal spiritual man, but also the external natural man. Unless these two are enlightened at the same time, the man is comparatively in the shade; but when both are enlightened then he is in daylight (T. C. R. 109).

The Lord is able to enlighten the internal, spiritual men, and at the same time the external, natural man with all those, with whom their natural man has been reduced into a state of correspondence with their internal man, and with whom those two have become conjoined. When such is the case, man is created into the image of God, not only as to his spiritual, but also as to his natural man.

476

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 477

His natural man then is regenerated both as to his will and as to his understanding; and, therefore, we read (Gen. i. 27), male and female created He them; for by the male is represented here the understanding, and by the female, the will of the natural man, between whom there is established the heavenly marriage.

This conjunction of the will and the understanding, which is equivalent to the conjunction of charity and faith, we learn, is effected with the spiritual man in the rational, and in the interior natural degrees of the external man, but not in its exterior natural or sensual degree. Nevertheless, this last degree, so far as its contents are concerned, is reduced into a state of subjection to the interior, regenerated degrees of the external man, and hence to the internal, rational man. Concerning this state of the regenerate member of the Church we read in conclusion (Gen. i. 31), And God saw all that He had made, and behold, it was very good. And the evening was, and the morning was the sixth day. In explanation of this last verse of the first chapter of Genesis, we read:--

When the work of regeneration has prospered so far that faith is conjoined to charity, then it is said to be very good; for then the Lord leads the man as a likeness of Himself. At the close of the sixth day the evil spirits withdraw, and the good succeed, and the man is introduced into heaven, that is, into the heavenly paradise which is treated of in the following chapter (A. C. 63).

323. When the external, natural man is conjoined with the internal, spiritual or rational man, and when there is thus effected a state of correspondence between the two, the state of the man is described by Swedenborg as follows:--

When the Natural is in a state of correspondence, the man is rational, and thinks spiritually.... For with him whose Natural corresponds to his Rational [i.e., to the internal man], the communication is open, so that the light of heaven can flow in from the Lord through the Rational into the Natural, and enlighten it with intelligence and wisdom.

477

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 478

Hence that man is spiritual-rational, and thinks spiritually.... For a man thinks according to the influx of the light of heaven into him; wherefore, every man thinks recording to the state of correspondence of the Natural with the Rational, as to good and truth (A. C. 3679).

We read also:--

When the conjunction of the internal with the external man has place, there is day-dawn; for then the man enters into the spiritual or heavenly state. Then also light, like that of the morning-rise, appears, if he is in such a state as to perceive it.... The man feels then as if he awoke from sleep in the morning, when the rising sun first enlightens, and opens the day (A. C. 4283).

From this it follows that enlightenment is altogether the result of the regeneration of the natural man, whereby it is reduced into a state of correspondence with the spiritual man, and conjoined with it; wherefore, enlightenment and also perception with a man are according to the conjunction of the external and the internal man with him. Swedenborg states this in so many words, in the following passages:--

When the external man is conjoined with the internal, it is illuminated by the internal man, and enjoys a Divine sight (A. C. 1584).

And again:--

In proportion as the things which belong to the external man, are conjoined with the celestial things of the internal man, perception [the result of enlightenment] increases and becomes more interior; conjunction with celestial things imparts perception. For in the celestial things which belong to love to the Lord, consists the very life of the internal man; or what amounts to the same thing, in the celestial things which belong to love, that is, in heavenly love, the Lord is present; and this presence is not perceived in the external man before conjunction has been effected. From conjunction is all perception (A. C. 1616).

The conjunction of the external with the internal man, again, is equivalent to the conjunction in man of the Lords immediate and His mediate influx. For the former influx takes place into the will, and the latter into the understanding;

478

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 479

wherefore, when charity and faith, will and understanding, are conjoined in man, the Lords immediate influx, in man, is also conjoined with His mediate influx. But the result of the conjunction of these two influxes in man is a state of Enlightenment (see above nos. 233 and 234).

324. We thus see that the conjunction of good and truth or of charity and faith in the natural man, and hence the conjunction of the internal with the external man, is the crown of mans regeneration, and at the same time the immediate cause of his spiritual Enlightenment. Concerning this conjunction, which is consummated at the end of the sixth day, and which results in a mans spiritual enlightenment, we read in a general way:--

The internal man is said to be united to the external man when the Celestial spiritual of the internal man flows into the Natural of the external man, and causes these two to act as one. The Natural then becomes also celestial spiritual, but celestial and spiritual in a lower degree, or what amounts to the same thing, the external man from thence becomes also celestial and spiritual, but exteriorly celestial and spiritual. The internal and external man are altogether distinct, because the internal man is affected by celestial and spiritual things, and the external man by natural things. But although distinct, they are nevertheless united; namely when the celestial-spiritual of the internal man flows into the Natural of the external man, and rules it as its own (A. C. 1577).

The special conditions, however, which result from the conjunction of the internal and external man, and which conditions are identical with those that are required for a state of spiritual enlightenment, shall now be briefly enumerated.

When a man becomes spiritual by regeneration, and his external and internal man act as one, his interiors are open so as to receive the influx of the light of heaven, and his will and understanding are elevated towards heaven and the Lord. We thus read:--

When a man becomes spiritual, his interiors which see in the light of heaven are open, and the man looks upwards.

479

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 480

This is effected by the Lord through elevation; thus the man looks to heaven and the Lord. Thither also are raised all the things belonging to his will and thought; consequently, his heart, that is, his love (A. C. 10,156).

And again:--

When a man is in the good of faith and of charity his interiors together with the things of the sense are raised upwards, by the Lord.... An elevation actually takes place from the Lord, and hence a removal from evils and falsities; the angels perceive this by their sense. It is like a nisus--a tendency towards the centre of heavy things. The centre is where the Lord is in His sun; thither the heads of the angels are elevated (A. C. 6832).

What conjoins the external with the internal man, however, is chiefly mutual love, concerning which we read:--

What disjoins the external from the internal man is chiefly self-love and what conjoins the external with the internal man is chiefly mutual love. Mutual love is not possible before self-love retreats; for they are altogether contradictory. The internal man is nothing else but mutual love.

Mutual love which alone is heavenly, consists in this, that a person not only declares, but also acknowledges and believes, that he is most unworthy; and that he is something low and defiled that the Lord constantly withdraws and detains him from hell, into which he constantly endeavors, yea desires to plunge himself.... In proportion as a man is in this acknowledgment, and believes that he is of such a quality, he recedes from the love of self, and at last abhors his own self.... He who is in mutual love acknowledges and believes that all good and truth are not a mans own, but the Lords and that loving another like ones self and still more, as is the case with the angels, loving others more than ones self is also a gift of the Lord, From this gift, and thus from its felicity, a man retreats so far as he retreats from the acknowledgment that this gift is the Lords (A. C. 1594).

Love, however, implies a state of freedom; wherefore the conjunction of the internal and external man, and hence the conjunction of good and truth is effected in a state of freedom. We thus read:--

The Lord leads everyone through his affections, and He bends him thus by a silent Providence; for He leads through freedom. Wherefore, all conjunction is effected in a state of freedom, and not under compulsion.

480

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 481

When, therefore, a man has been led in freedom to good, truths are accepted and implanted; and he begins to be affected by them, and thus, little by little, he is introduced into heavenly freedom (A. C. 4364).

325. The whole process of conjunction, which is the basis of Enlightenment, is most clearly set before us in the following passage:--

The end of Regeneration is that the internal man becomes conjoined with the external man; thus the Spiritual, through the Rational, with the Natural. Apart from the conjunction of those two, there is no regeneration. This conjunction cannot take place before good has become conjoined with truths in the Natural. For the Natural must be the plane, and the things which are in the Natural must correspond. This is the reason why the conjunction of good with truths becomes successively more interior when the Natural is being regenerated. For the spiritual conjoins itself first with those things in the Natural which are inmost afterwards with those things which are exterior. Again, the Internal of man cannot conjoin itself with his External unless the truth in it becomes the good of truth, that is, truth in will and in act then only can they become conjoined. For the Lord flows in with man through the internal man, and indeed through the good which is in it. The good which is in it can be conjoined with good in the external man; but it cannot be conjoined immediately with the truth. Hence it appears that truth with man must first become truth in will, and truth in act, i.e., the good of truth, before the conjunction of the Rational with the Natural, i.e., of the internal with the external man can exist (A. C. 4353).

The actual conjunction, however, of the internal and external man is effected in the will for when truth with a man becomes truth in act and hence the good of truth, the truth then passes with the man from the understanding into the will, and in the will it meets the good which from the internal flows into the external man, and conjoins itself with it. This, however, is equivalent to the inversion of state in man, when good, and no longer truth, occupies the first place. On this subject we read as follows:--

Before conjunction, truth appears to be in the first place; after conjunction good is actually in the first place....

481

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 482

Truth cannot be conjoined to the good which flows in through the internal man, and which is Divine by origin, before truth is truth by will and act, and thus the good of truth. For the good which flows in through the internal man, and which is Divine by origin, flows into the will, and meets there the good of truth which has been insinuated through the external man [and becomes conjoined with it] (A. C. 4337).

How the truth in the natural man becomes the good of truth or the good of faith has been shown above (no. 321). This good of truth increases in proportion as a man is in the exercise of the good of charity. This same good of truth also, which is the result of regeneration in the natural man, causes there a lower natural kind of conscience, which is called the conscience of truth. On this subject we read:--

The good of truth, as has been shown, is truth in will and in act. This truth is what is called good; and the conscience which is from that good is called the conscience of truth. This good, which is from truth, increases in the proportion in which a man exercises charity from willing well, and in proportion to the quantity and quality of his love of the neighbor (A. C. 4390).

326. In order that the good of truth or the good of faith may conjoin the external with the internal man, that same good, as we have seen above, must be productive of the delight of the affection of good and truth. On this subject we read further:--

When a man perceives in himself the delight of the affections which correspond to the felicity of eternal life, then his external man is beginning to be conjoined with the internal man. It is the delights belonging to the affections of good and truth which conjoin; for apart from the delight of the affections nothing is conjoined; because in these consists the life of man (A. C. 3939).

Concerning the conjunctive power of the affections, as it is manifested in the spiritual world, we read:--

In the spiritual world, whenever anyone thinks of another, and desires to speak with him, that other is immediately present; this is a common thing there. and never fails to operate. The reason is that in the spiritual world there is no distance, as in the natural world, but only an appearance of distance.

482

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 483

But as thought, from some knowledge of another person, causes presence, so love, from some affection for that other, causes conjunction. On the ground of this affection it is that they walk together, speak amicably with each other, live in one house or in one society, meet frequently, and bestow upon one another their mutual offices.... The same is the case with all the things which are in the human mind. The things therein are innumerable; and each single therein is consociated and conjoined with other things according to affection, that is, according as one thing loves the other. This conjunction is spiritual conjunction, which is the same in general and in particular things (D. P. 326).

We read further:--

We use the term affection, but mean by it the continuity of love.... Affections are means which serve for the conjunction of good and truth. Hence it is that nothing of doctrine and nothing of science can enter into man except through affections; for in the affections there is life, but not in the truths of doctrine and of science apart from them. Without an affection, indeed, a man cannot think at all, nor can he utter a single word. If a person pays attention he will find that a word without an affection is like the word of an automaton; that, therefore, it is sound without life; and he will further see that in proportion to the quantity and the quality of the affection will be the quantity and the quality of the life in a word or an expression.... It hence may appear that affections are means for conjoining truth with good; further, that it is the affections which introduce truths and arrange truths; and that genuine affections, which are those of love to the Lord and love towards the neighbor, arrange truths into a heavenly order; but evil affections, which are those of the love of self and of the world, arrange them into an infernal order that is, into an order which is opposed to that of heaven (A. C. 3049).

327. Another indispensable means for causing conjunction are spiritual temptations; for by temptations evils and falsities are conquered and removed; and, therefore, goods and truths are enabled to flow into the Natural, and to become fortified and established in it. We thus read:--

All conjunction of good with truth is effected through temptations; and temptations exist when good begins to take first place....

483

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 484

The very good that is to be conjoined with truth is not tempted, but truth. Truth also is not tempted by good, but it is tempted by evils and falsities, and also by the fallacies and illusions, and their affections, which adhere to truths in the Natural. For when good flows in, which takes place by an internal way, or through the internal, rational man, the ideas of the natural man which are formed from the fallacies of the senses and illusions thence, do not bear its approach, because they are discordant. Hence there arises in the natural man anxiety and temptation (A. C. 4341).

Again we read:--

The conjunction of good and truth is effected by temptations. The purpose of temptations is not only that a man may be confirmed in truths, but also that truths only be more closely conjoined with goods. In temptations a man fights for truths against falsities, and since at such a time he is in interior pain and torment, there is a cessation of the delights of the life of lusts, and of the pleasures thence, in which case goods from the Lord flow in, and evils are regarded as abominable. New thoughts arise thence which are opposed to the former thoughts; and to these the man may afterwards be bent, and thereby from evils to goods, and these goods may be conjoined with truths (A. C. 2272). See also A. C. 4572, at p. 288.

328. The process by which truths are conjoined with good is a progressive one; for exterior truths--those that are contained in the literal sense of the Word, are conjoined first, and interior truths, that is, the truths contained in the internal sense of the Word, later. Exterior truths, however, are general truths, and interior truths are particular and singular truths. We thus read:--

A man becomes spiritual by this, that truths with him are conjoined with good; that is, the things of faith with those belonging to charity, and indeed in the Natural. Exterior truths are first conjoined in it with good and afterwards interior truths. Interior truths are not conjoined with good otherwise, than through the enlightenment, which flows through the internal into the external man. From this enlightenment Divine truths appear only in a general way; comparatively as innumerable objects appear before the eye as one obscure thing without any distinction. A man is called spiritual from this circumstance that the light of heaven, in which is intelligence and wisdom flows into those things which belong to the light of heaven, to be represented in those that belong to the light of the world, and indeed so that they correspond (A. C. 4402).

484

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 485

Again we read:--

The case with a man when he is being regenerated, or what amounts to the same thing, when truths with him are being conjoined with good is so, that general affections with their truths are insinuated into good first afterwards, such as are less general, or respectively particular; and lastly such as are still less general, and respectively singular (A. C. 4346).

329. We have seen above (A. C. 4337, in no. 325), that the conjunction of the external with the internal man is effected in this wise, that the good which flows in through the internal man, and which is Divine by origin, flows into the will, and meets there the good of truth which has been insinuated through the external man; and that thus it becomes conjoined with it. Good which is Divine by origin, thus meets the good of truth which the member of the Church has acquired from the Divine Word by his own study, and which he has applied to his life. The Lords immediate influx which takes place into a mans will, thus becomes conjoined with His mediate influx which takes place into the mans understanding through the mediation of the Word. But from this it follows that the conjunction of the internal and external man which results from the conjunction of good and truth in the natural man, is equivalent to the conjunction of the Lord with man. For when the internal man becomes conjoined to the external, good which is Divine by origin, and thus the Lords--nay, which is the Lord with man, becomes conjoined with the Truth which the man, with the full use of his freedom and rationality, has acquired from the Divine Word, and which by an application to the life, has become changed with him into the good of truth. Concerning this conjunction of the Lord with man, which constitutes the Church--the Lords kingdom with man--we read:--

485

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 486

The marriage of the Lord with the Church consists in this, that the Lord flows into angels and men with the good of love, and that the angels and men receive Him, that is, the good of love, in truths, and that thereby a marriage is effected between good and truth, which marriage constitutes the Church itself, and causes heaven with them (A. R. 380).

Concerning this conjunction of the Lord with man, which is effected by the regeneration of the natural man, we read further:--

The Lords conjunction with man is possible only in love and charity. For the Lord is Love Itself and Mercy, and He desires to save all, and He attracts all by a strong force towards heaven, and thus to Himself. Hence every man may know and conclude that no one can ever become conjoined with the Lord except through that which is the Lord Himself; that is, unless he acts as the Lord does; and, consequently, unless he operates one and the same thing with the Lord, and thus unless he re-loves the Lord, and loves the neighbor as Himself. Conjunction is effected only by this means. But when there is conjunction by this means, it follows manifestly that the Lord is present. The Lord is indeed present with every man; but His presence is nearer or more remote according to the degrees of a mans advance towards love, or to the degrees of his removal from it (A. C. 1038).

And again:--

The Lord flows in with man and is present with him in the good which he receives from the Lord. For good constitutes the man himself; everyone also is such as his good is. By good is meant love; for all that is loved is called good. Now since the whole man is such as his love is, it is plain that the Lord cannot be present with a man in a bad love, but in a good love, and thus in his good (A. C. 10153).

330. Those who are conjoined with the Lord are also conjoined with heaven, because the Divine which proceeds from the Lord constitutes heaven with the angels (A. C. 10632). On this subject we read:--

The Church is a Church from the marriage of good and truth; and when the Church is in this marriage, it makes one with heaven, which is the heavenly marriage (A. C. 4835).

486

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 487

The conjunction of man with the angels, and thus with heaven is, however, effected through the Divine Word. For the Divine Word is the bond which holds heaven and the Church together. But when the member of the Church is in the heavenly marriage, that is, when good and truth, the internal and the external man, are conjoined is him, he sees the Word in the light of heaven, and thus in a state of enlightenment, as appears from what follows:--

The Word has been written in this wise, that each singular thing therein, even to the minutest singulars, corresponds to those things that are in heaven. Hence the Word has Divine power, and conjoins heaven with the world; for when the Word is read on earth, the angels who are in heaven are drawn towards the element of holiness which is in the internal sense; this is brought about by the correspondences which are in each single thing (A. C. 8616).

But is order that heaven and the angels may be actually conjoined with a man by means of the Divine Word, it is absolutely necessary that the man should be in the good of truth, that is, in the Good of faith. For we read again:--

When the member of the Church who is in the good of faith reads the Word, the angels adjoin themselves to him, and are delighted with him, because the wisdom which comes through the Word then flows in with them from the Lord. Hence is the conjunction of heaven with man, which apart from the Word would not exist; for the Word is of such a quality that in its original language there is not a jot or tittle but affects the angels and conjoins them with man (A. C. 9152).

An active state of love, however, is required in order that the man himself may receive enlightenment from the Lord, while he is reading the Word; but by this is meant, that he shall no longer look from truth to Good, but from good to truth. We thus read again:--

The conjunction of the Lord and the conjunction of heaven with the member of the Church is through good; wherefore, if there is no good with him, there cannot be any enlightenment; for all enlightenment during the reading of the Word is out of heaven from the Lord, and when there is no enlightenment the truths which are in the Word are in obscurity.

487

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 488
