That the Word is not understood, when a man is not in good, may appear from this circumstance, that in each single part of the Word is the heavenly marriage, that is, the conjunction of good and truth; when, therefore, good is not present with the man who reads the Word, truth also does not appear; for truth appears from good and good through truths (A. E. 365).

The Lord is present with all in the spiritual sense of His Divine Word, but in order to its reception the interiors of the mans mind must be opened by a course of regeneration. Man, therefore, must be in a state of good; and that good must be conjoined with truth; yet the measure of a mans enlightenment in the spiritual sense is the extent of the knowledges from the Divine Word that are with the man. We thus read:--

All those who read the Word are kept by the Lord in the spiritual sense, but it is received only by those whose interiors are opened; and since the spiritual sense is received in knowledges, therefore it is received according to the state of the intellectual part with man, namely, according to the extent and the manlier in which it can be enlightened through the know ledges which are with a person. Men also, in a general way, are affected by holiness thence (A. C. 10402).

331. The end of regeneration consists in conjunction with the Lord and in conjunction with heaven, which is identical with the conjunction of the Lords immediate and mediate influx in man. Conjunction with the Lord, however, as we hare further seen, is identical with the conjunction of the internal and external man; and the internal and external man are conjoined when good is conjoined with truth in mans Natural. Conjunction, however, manifests itself with the regenerate man by a state of spiritual enlightenment. This spiritual enlightenment attends the conjunction of good and truth in man in all its various stages as a necessary consequence. The requirements for spiritual enlightenment from the Lord are thus precisely the same as those which are also required for the conjunction of good and truth.

488

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 489

That spiritual condition, therefore, which is reached by man when good and truth are conjoined in him, describes also the condition which is required in order that a man may reach a state of full enlightenment from the Lord. This condition embraces the following states:--

(a) The conjunction of man with the Lord.

(b) The conjunction of man with the angels of heaven.

(c) The conjunction in man of the Lords immediate with His mediate influx.

The conjunction of the Lord with men, however, is the result of the following effects which are brought about by regeneration:--

(d) A state of correspondence between the internal and external man.

This state of correspondence is caused by:-

(e) Spiritual good; which good is wrought by man when the truth which he has acquired from the Divine Word is applied by him to the life, and conjoined with the good of charity which flows from the internal into the external man. Spiritual good, however, causes in man:--

(f) The elevation of mans interiors towards heaven and to the Lord.

(g) The opening of the spiritual mind.

Man arrives at spiritual good by the conjunction of the good of truth in the natural man with the good that flows immediately from the Lord through the internal into the external man. From this, however, it follows that all the means which are productive in man of the Good of truth, are also means which contribute to a mans spiritual enlightenment. These means consist of the four media (see above, nos. 321, 322), by which the natural man is regenerated, and, therefore, reduced into a state of correspondence with the spiritual man.

489

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 490

These media ape as follow:--

(h) The affection of truth for its own sake, which is productive of the principle of Affirmation, under the influence of which the man humbles before the Divine Truth in the Holy Word, everything of his own both in his will and in his understanding.

(i) Spiritual Temptation, which is the inevitable result when a man unequivocally declares in favor of that which comes from the Lord, and against that which comes from man.

(j) The Good of Faith which is identical with the good of truth, and which implies an implicit carrying out in the life of the truths which a man has acquired from the Divine Word. But the Good of Faith, or the Good of truth, increases in man by a life devoted to the uses of charity; according to the principle that influx is according to efflux.

(k) The Delight of the affections of good and truth, which is experienced by a man when he habitually carries out in his life the good of truth. For that delight is the effect of the charity which enters from the Lord into the affections of good and truth in the natural man.

When the affections of good and truth with a man are in a state of delight, then also the inversion of state is consummated in him; for then he no longer acts from a principle of truth in the first place, but from a principle of good. Wherefore, an additional condition for enlightenment in man is:--

(l) The inversion of state.

490

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 491

From all this, however, follow these two fundamental conditions of spiritual enlightenment:--

(m) Good, end hence love, is the medium through which man receives spiritual enlightenment from the Lord.

(n) The extent and quality of enlightenment, however, is determined by the truths which are established in a mans understanding.

As all truths, however, are derived from the Divine Word, therefore:--

(o) Spiritual enlightenment consists essentially in an enlightenment of the literal sense of the Divine Word in the mind of man by its spiritual sense, which is experienced by him who is conjoined with the Lord, and who is thus in the heavenly marriage.

332. (a) The first condition of spiritual enlightenment is Conjunction with the Lord; for

Where the Lord is present there is enlightenment (A. E. 529)

The Lords presence, however, is caused by conjunction with Him; for, as we have seen above (A. C. 1038, no. 328), No one can be conjoined with the Lord except through that which is the Lord Himself; that is, unless he acts as the Lord acts and thus unless he re-loves the Lord and loves the neighbor as himself. Conjunction is effected only by this means. But when there is conjunction by this means, then it follows manifestly that the Lord is present.

We read further:--

Those who are in love to the Lord, and also in charity towards the neighbor, are in a condition to see the interior things of the Word, of the Church, and of worship. For love to the Lord and charity towards the neighbor open the internal man; and when that is open, then man as to his interiors is in heaven among the angels where the Lord is (A. C. 10578).

491

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 492

(b) All enlightenment, however, is imparted to man by the Lord mediately through heaven, that is, through the ministration of the angels. This enlightenment is the outcome, as it were, of a mans life according to the Divine commandments, and thus according to the doctrine of faith and charity which is taught in the Divine Word. This enlightenment, therefore, corresponds to the goods and truths of which in the course of a mans regeneration his internal and external man are organized; and thus it corresponds to the contents of his internal and external memory. These contents, we learn, are put on by a mans attendant good spirits or angels (see A. C., 5853, no. 3, at p. 317), and through the medium of the spirits and angels they are exposed to the particular light of heaven which prevails in that society of heaven with which the said spirits are connected.

The light which is received by a man immediately from the Lord, enables him to rise, as it were, above the light in which he is by virtue of his enlightenment from the angels of heaven, and thus by virtue of the existing state of good and truth in his mind. It enables him, therefore, to examine and to embrace a higher good and a higher truth when they are presented to him for consideration and adoption.

The enlightenment which a man receives from the Lord through mediate influx, corresponds thus to the light which prevails in a particular section--a particular society of the Grand Man of heaven; while the light which he receives from the Lord through immediate influx, corresponds to the state of the Divine Truth as it beams down from the Lord into heaven at large, and as it is represented by the heat and light that proceed immediately from the Lord through the spiritual man.

492

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 493

The enlightenment, however, which we are discussing now is that which results from the quality of a mans love to the Lord and the neighbor, and which is conveyed to him from the Lord mediately through the ministry of angels. Concerning this enlightenment we read more particularly:--

The intelligence of truth and the affection of good are communicated to man by the angels, that is, through angels from the Lord. This communication is what is called Influx and Enlightenment (A. C. 10,330).

Again we read:--

The enlightenment which is attributed to the Holy Spirit is indeed in the man from the Lord, but it is nevertheless brought about through the mediation of spirits and angels. The character of this mediation cannot be described as yet; only that angels and spirits cannot enlighten a man at all from themselves, for they also are enlightened by the Lord in a similar manner as the man; and because they are enlightened in a similar manner, it follows that all enlightenment is from the Lord alone. It takes place through the mediation of angels or spirits, because the man who is in enlightenment is placed then in the midst of such angels and spirits as receive from the Lord alone more enlightenment than others (D. L. W. 150).

333. A man is able to be associated with the angels of heaven and to come thereby into a state of enlightenment when he receives in his mind truths from the Divine Word, and applies them to the uses of life. On this subject we read:--

When a man applies the knowledges of truth and good from the Word to his life ... he acquires to himself spiritual life; and his moral life then flows from that life. Such a man communicates with the angels of heaven, and through communication with heaven there is opened his internal, spiritual man, whose mind is a higher mind, like that of the angels of heaven, and that mind through communication with heaven is imbued with heavenly intelligence and wisdom.

Man thus becomes spiritual through knowledges of truth and good applied of the uses of life; but why a man becomes spiritual only through those knowledges which are from the Word, and through none other shall now be said. All things which are in the Word are Divine, but they are Divine because they have in themselves a spiritual sense, and through that sense communicate with heaven and with the angels who are there.

493

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 494

When therefore a man has knowledges from the Word and applies them to the life, then through these knowledges he communicates with heaven, and by that communication he becomes spiritual. For a man becomes spiritual through this circumstance, that he is in the same truths as the angels of heaven, or in truths corresponding to theirs. The expression corresponding is here used, because each and all things which are in the literal sense of the Word are correspondences for they correspond to the truths which are with the angels. Those knowledges, however, which are from other books in which the doctrinals of the Church are treated of, and confirmed by various things, effect a communication with heaven only by virtue of the knowledges from the Word which are in these books. These knowledges when they are understood truly, and are not applied to faith alone, but to life, effect communication (A. E. 195).

This then is the reason why the Wordthat is, the knowledges of good and truth from the Word, when they are applied to the life--are effective of a communication between the angels and men, and why a man through such communication receives spiritual enlightenment; but concerning the manner in which this communication is effected, we read:--

The thoughts of a man who holds the Word to be holy, and reads it for the sake of the uses of life, are like one who holds a cabinet that contains precious stones, pearls, and diadems arranged in order, and sends it to heaven, and it is opened in its ascent, and the precious things in it come to the angels, who are deeply delighted in beholding and examining them. This their delight is communicated to the man, and effects consociation, and also a communication of perceptions (T. C. R. 238)

334. Concerning this enlightenment of man through the Word, whereby he receives enlightenment from the Lord through heaven, we read further:--

From the obscurity that belongs to the natural man there may arise both truth and falsity. When a man suffers himself to be enlightened by the Lord through the word, his obscurity becomes imbued with light; for the internal way is opened, so that influx and communication take place from the Lord through heaven (A. C. 3708).

Again we read:-

Enlightenment is brought about by the Lord through the Word, in which everything, by virtue of the Spiritual which is in it, communicates with heaven;

494

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 495

and the Lord flows in through heaven. He flows in into that which is then and there under a mans gaze.... Being enlightened by the Lord through heaven means being enlightened through the Holy Spirit; for the Holy Spirit is the Divine which proceeds from the Lord as from a sun, from which Divine is heaven. It appears hence that the Lord teaches the member of Church mediately through the Word, according to the love of his will which is his through life, and according to the light of his understanding, which is his through knowledge; and further that this is not possible otherwise, because such is the order of influx (A. E. 1157).

And again:--

So far as the good of love to the Lord and the good of love to the neighbor are not with a member of the Church, the Word is not understood. For the conjunction of the Lord, and the conjunction of heaven with the member of the Church is through good. When, therefore, there is no good with the latter, he cannot possibly be in any enlightenment; for all enlightenment during the reading of the Word is from the Lord out of heaven (A. E. 365).

335. (c) Conjunction with the Lord and conjunction with the angels through the Word, is equivalent to the conjunction in man of the Lords immediate with His mediate influx, which latter influx takes place by means of the Divine Word, through the angels of heaven. For when these two influxes are conjoined in a man, he is in a state of perception of the Truth from the Lord; as has been shown at great length above (pp.344-347). We learned there that with every man there is immediate as well as mediate influx; but that the conjunction of the two influxes exists only with those who have a perception of the truth from good. We learned, further, that the Truth which proceeds immediately from the Divine enters into a mans will; and that the Truth which proceeds mediately from the Divine enters into a mans understanding. Wherefore, the conjunction of those two influxes is equivalent to the conjunction of the will and understanding in man.

495

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 496

When conjunction exists, then, however, as we have further learned, the Lord appears as present, and His presence is also perceived. But since the Lords presence, as we have further seen above (no. 332), causes enlightenment, therefore such also is the effect of the conjunction in man of the two influxes from the Lord.

During the first state of regeneration, when a man from truth has respect to good, the Lord leads him by his immediate influx; but that influx is not then perceived. But when there is a conjunction established in the man between the Lords immediate and His mediate influx, the Lords influx is perceived by the man; as appears from what follows:--

When a man is in the first state [of regeneration] the Lord flows in and leads him immediately; but the Lord immediate influx does not reach a mans perception, because it takes place into the inmost parts of the man. But the Lords influx which is immediate, and at the same time mediate, reaches the mans perception and conveys affection; because it takes place not only into the mans inmost, but also into his middle and outermost parts (A. C. 8690).

The Lords immediate influx, however, reaches not only the mans inmost, but also his middle and outermost parts, when he is in the heavenly marriage; because then his internal and his external man are conjoined.

The particular enlightenment, or perception which a man enjoys when the Lords immediate influx is conjoined in him with His mediate influx, is described in the following passage:--

Instruction in the single things of doctrine exists when the Divine Truth proceeding immediately from the Lords Divine, is conjoined with the Truth which proceeds mediately; for then perception is given. This conjunction exists especially with the angels who are in the third or inmost heaven, who are called celestial. They have a most exquisite perception of both Truths, and hence of the Lords presence, because they are in good more than others for they have the good of innocence. Wherefore, they are nearest to the Lord, and in a flashing, and a kind of flaming light:

496

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 497

for they see the Lord as a sun, the rays of whose light are such from their propinquity (A. C. 7058).

336. Thus far we have spoken of perception and enlightenment indiscriminately; yet a distinction must be drawn between them. For the term perception, as we have seen in the above passage, applies chiefly to the angels of the third heaven, while the term enlightenment belongs essentially to those who are in the second heaves. Or, again the term perception, belongs to the celestial who, in the course of their regeneration, have reached the seventh day of rest; while the term enlightenment applies to the spiritual who are regenerated as far as the sixth day of creation. We thus read:--

The angelic societies of the third or inmost heaven have knowledge from perception; that is, by influx from the Lord. The rest have also knowledge; yet not from perception, but from an enlightenment of the understanding to the angels of the second, and the lowest heaven. The distinction between the two is in this wise, that perception is a fall confirmation by virtue of influx from the Lord; but enlightenment of the understanding is spiritual sight. This enlightenment belongs to those who are in charity towards the neighbor, and thence in faith; but the former, that is perception, is with those who are in love to the Lord (A. E. 307).

Again we read:--

The Lord does not speak with the member of the Church otherwise than through the Word; for He then imparts enlightenment, so that the man sees the truth, and He also grants perception, that the man shall perceive that a thing is so. Yet this takes place according to the quality of the desire of the truth which is with a man; and the desire of the truth with him, is according to his love. Those who love the truth for the sake of the truth are in enlightenment, but those who love the truth for the sake of good are in perception (A. C. 10,290).

The character of the enlightenment which is with those who love the truth from good, that is, who love the truth for the sake of the truth, is described in what follows:--

497

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 498

There is a revelation which does not take place with a loud voice, but interiorly in man. This revelation is caused by an enlightenment of the internal sight, which is the understanding, when a man who is in the affection of the truth from good, reads the Word. The light of heaven, which is from the Lord in heaven, as a sun, causes this enlightenment; and by this light the understanding is enlightened scarcely otherwise than the external sight, which is of the eye, is illuminated by the light of the world. When the understanding is enlightened by this Divine light, it perceives that to be true which is true; it acknowledges it interiorly within itself, and sees it in a certain manner. Such is the revelation of those who are in the affection of the truth from good when they read the Word (A. C. 8780).

We read again:--

When good is conjoined with truth in a man, an when from thence, is, from good, he regards the truth, then all becomes clear before him, and indeed successively more and more so. For he is then no longer in a state of doubt whether a thing be so or so; but he knows that it is so, or some other way. When a man is in that state he begins to know innumerable things; for he then progresses from the good and the truth which he believes and perceives, as from a centre towards the circumference; and in proportion as he progresses, he sees the things in his surroundings, and he sees them more extensively by and by, for he continually enlarges and extends his borders. Then also he makes a beginning or a start from every point in the space within his borders and from thence, as from new centres, he describes new circumferences. From this source the light of truth from good increases immensely with him, and becomes like a continuous expanse of light: for he is then in the light of heaven which is from the Lord (A. C. 3833).

337. (d) The conjunction of the Lords immediate with His mediate influx in man, and hence the state of enlightenment from the Lord, supposes in man a state of correspondence between his internal and his external man. For, as we have seen above (A. C. 8690) the Lords immediate, and, at the same time, His mediate influx takes place then not only into the mans inmost, but also into his middle and outermost parts.

498

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 499

We read accordingly:--

In order that a man from enlightenment may see and perceive the genuine truths of the Word, the three degrees of the understanding, namely, the natural, the rational and the spiritual degrees must be together. For the natural understanding cannot be enlightened from its own [natural] lumen, but it requires to be enlightened by the light of the rational degree which is intermediate, and this degree has to be enlightened from spiritual light; for the spiritual understanding is in the light of heaven, and sees from it. The Rational is intermediate between the Spiritual and the Natural, and receives the spiritual light which it transmits, the wherewith it enlightens the Natural. Hence it is made evident that the natural understanding apart from light through the Rational from the Spiritual, is no understanding, for it is without any light out of heaven; and the truths of the Church, which are also the truths of heaven, can only be seen in the light of heaven. But the cause of this is, that the Divine Truth which proceeds from the Lord as a Sun, is the light of heaven; and the Lord enlightens man alone through His light, which is spiritual light (A. E. 846).

In order, therefore, that there may be enlightenment, there must be a state of correspondence between the internal and the external man, and for this purpose the external man requires to be regenerated, and to be conjoined with the internal man. On this subject we read:--

Those who are in external things apart from any internal cannot be enlightened, and hence neither can they be confirmed in truths, but those who are in external things and at the same time in internal things are enlightened upon reading the Word, and in a state of enlightenment they see truths, in which they are afterwards more and more confirmed (A. C. 7012). See also above, A. C. 3679, in no. 322.

338. (c) A state of correspondence between the internal and the external man, and hence enlightenment in spiritual matters, is, however, brought about solely by spiritual good; which good is wrought by the man when the truth which he has acquired from the Divine Word, is applied by him to the life, and conjoined with the good of charity which flows from his internal into his external man.

499

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 500

Concerning the genesis of spiritual good, which is the product of regeneration, we read as follows:--

Spiritual good is truth which has become good. For truth becomes good when a man lives according to it. Truth then passes into the will, and from the will into act, and thus becomes a matter of life; and when truth has become a matter of life, it is no longer called truth, but good. The will, however, which changes truth into good is the new will in the intellectual part. (A. C. 5595)

Again we read:--

Good conjoined with truth is what is understood by spiritual good (A. C. 9206).

And again:--

Spiritual good is the good of faith and the Good of charity ... and is from the Lord (A. C. 3470).

This same spiritual good conveys enlightenment to the man who is in a state of regeneration; wherefore, we read further:--

The things of the Church and of heaven are not understood and perceived except by virtue of enlightenment; for the things of the Church and of heaven do not enter into a mans understanding except by means of the light of heaven, which enlightens the understanding. This is the reason why the Word, in which the things of the Church and of heaven can be understood only by one enlightened and those only are enlightened, who are in the affection of truth from good; consequently, who are in the love of the Lord, and in charity towards the neighbor. Their good is spiritual good; and with that good, and from that good, is the light of heaven which enlightens (A. E. 11)

Again we read:--

Those who lead an angelic life, that is, a life of charity and faith, are enlightened by the Lord, and they see the holy things of the Word (A. C. 9088).

And again:--

The good which is of charity is like a flame which imparts light, and thus enlightens each and all things that a man had previously believed to be true.

500

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 501

He also notices then, how falsities had intermixed themselves, and had put on an appearance, as if they were true (A. C. 4245).

Further:--

To those who are in enlightenment the Lord grants to understand what they believe, and they are enlightened when reading the Word. But those understand the Word, who acknowledge the Lord, and love to live according to His precepts; while those do not understood, who say they believe, but do not live accordingly. For the Lord flows into a mans life, and thence into his faith, but He does not flow into a faith separate from life (A. C. 10,659).

339. (f) Spiritual good, however, is able to convey spiritual enlightenment to man, because it conjoins him with the Lord and with heaven; and because it raises mans interiors towards heaven, and to the Lord.

For in order that a man as to his spirit may be associated with the angels, and that thus he may receive enlightenment from the Lord through heaven, he must be elevated as to his interiors into heaven. This, however, is the result of an application of his own freedom and rationality, by virtue of which he turns away from self and the world, and looks towards heaven and the Lord; for in proportion as he turns away from the evils and falsities which originate in the loves of self and of the world, he comes into spiritual good; wherefore, good, that is, spiritual good is the real means by which man, as to his interiors, is able to be elevated into heaven. We read on this subject:--

Influx and enlightenment take place thus: Man is such that as to his interiors which belong to thought and will, he can look downwards, and also upwards. Looking downwards means outwards into the world and towards his own self; while looking upwards means inwards towards heaven and the Lord. A man, however, looks upwards not from himself, but from the Lord. The expression upwards is used, because the man is then elevated as to his interiors (which belong to his will and understanding) by the Lord towards heaven, and thus towards the Lord.

501

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 502

The interiors then are also actually raised up; and they are positively led away from the body and the world. When this is done, a mans interiors come really into heaven--into its light and heat. Hence man has influx and enlightenment.

Since the man is then among the angels, there is communicated to him by them, that is through the angels by the Lord, the intelligence of truth and the affection of good. This communication is called Influx and Enlightenment. It must be observed, however, that influx and enlightenment take place according to the faculty of reception with man, and the faculty of reception is according to the love of truth and good. Those, therefore, who are in the love of truth and good for the sake of truth and good as ends, are elevated. But those who are in the love of truth and good not for the sake of truth and good, but for the sake of themselves and the world, because they constantly look and gravitate downwards, cannot be elevated; thus, they cannot receive the Divine Influx and cannot be enlightened (A. C. 10,330).

Again we read:--

Those who suffer themselves to be elevated by the Lord into the light of heaven, are elevated at first above the scientifics which belong to the natural man, and then they see those things which are in the Natural, and which are called scientifics, from the light of heaven. These things they discriminate well, and they adopt those things which they comprehend and which are congruous, rejecting and separating those things which they do not understand and which are incongruous (A. C. 10,156).

340. (g) The actual result, however, of such an elevation of a mans interiors towards heaven and the Lord, is the opening of the internal or spiritual man, which is an indispensable condition of a mans spiritual enlightenment. For by the opening of the internal man, the light of heaven is able to penetrate into a mans mind, and to enlighten there the contents first of the interior memory, and afterwards those of the exterior memory. This opening, however, is altogether according to the good of life, and thus according to the conjunction of good and truth in the member of the Church, which results in the establishment of spiritual good in man.

502

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 503

Concerning this opening of the internal or spiritual man we read:--

Spiritual good alone, which is the good of charity from the Lord, opens the spiritual mind, through which the Lord flows in and enlightens. Apart from the opening of that mind, enlightenment is not possible; consequently, neither the understanding of the truth (A. E. 923).

Again we read:--

Only those are in enlightenment who are in the two loves of heaven; namely, in love to the Lord, and in love towards the neighbor. For these loves open the interior that is, the higher mind, which is formed for the reception of the light of heaven. Through this mind the light of heaven flows in with these persons, and enlightens; and yet, during their life in the world, they do not perceive truth in that mind, but in a lower mind which belongs to the external or natural man... That interior or spiritual mind looks to the Lord; and the Lord then raises that mind, and at the same time the lower or natural mind, to Himself, and thus leads it away from the mans self or proprium; which is not possible with those who look chiefly to themselves and to the world. When the internal or spiritual man, in which is that interior or higher mind of which we have just spoken, is opened, the Lord coerces the evils and disperses the falsities which are in the external or natural man (A. E. 177).

Further information concerning the opening of the internal or spiritual man is contained in what follows:--

The spiritual man is closed from childhood, and is opened and formed only through Divine truths received by the understanding and will; and in proportion as the spiritual man is opened and formed, the evils of the natural and sensual man are removed, and goods are implanted in their stead (A. E. 643).

The interior or spiritual mind, which is heaven with man, is opened in proportion as the man acknowledges the Lords Divine; and a man acknowledges it so far as he is in the good of love and charity and in the truths of doctrine and faith. But this interior mind is not opened in proportion as a man does not acknowledge the Lords Divine, and does not live the life of love and faith; and this same mind is closed, in proportion as a man is in evils and falsities--when it is closed, the mans natural mind becomes hell with him; for in the natural mind is a mans evil and falsity (A. E. 644).

503

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 504

Truths and goods can he acknowledged only by those whose interior mind is open. Light flows into this mind from the Lord; and in so far as this mind is open, truths and goods are acknowledged. This mind is open only with those who are in innocence, in love to the Lord, and in charity towards the neighbor; but it is not open with those who are in the truths of faith, unless they are at the same time in the good of life (A. C. 3224).

341. When the spiritual mind is opened, the light of heaven flows into the natural mind and enlightens it; as appears from the following passage:--

The spiritual mind is opened and educated in proportion as a man with his life receives the knowledges of truth which he has from the Word. Wherefore that mind is no opened with those by whom that knowledge is not applied to the life. When the spiritual mind is opened, the light of heaven through that mind flows into the natural mind and enlightens it; whereby that mind becomes spiritual-natural. For the spiritual mind then sees in the natural mind almost, as when a man sees his face in a mirror, and acknowledges those things that agree with himself.... Since the mind makes the manfor the mind is the understanding and the willtherefore it is the same thing whether we say mind or man; thus, whether we say the spiritual mind and the natural mind, or the spiritual man and the natural man (A. E. 406).

Concerning the extent of this light in the natural mind or man, Swedenborg relates from his personal experience as follows:--

I saw two spirits not far from me, but distant from each other, and I noticed that one of them loved good and truth, and through his love was conjoined with heaven other loved evil and falsity, and through his love was conjoined with hell. I approached and called them together, and from their sounds and replies gathered that the one just as well as the other was able to perceive truths, and after perceiving them to acknowledge them; that thus he was able to think from the understanding and also to determine things intellectual just as he pleased, and the things of the will just as he listed consequently, that both enjoyed a like freedom of choice, so far as rational things were concerned. I noticed, moreover, that by virtue of that freedom in their minds there appeared an element of lucidity [which extended] from the first [or interior] sight belonging to perception to the last [or lowest] sight belonging to the eye.

504

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 505

But when the one who loved evil and falsity, upon being left to himself, was thinking, I noticed that there ascended from hell something like smoke, which quenched the element of lucidity that was above the memory; whence there arose a kind of midnight darkness; and further, that that smoke upon being kindled burnt like a flame, which illuminated that part of the mind which was below the memory, from which he produced by thought enormous falsities which flowed from his self-love.

But with the other who loved good and truth, I noticed that when he was left to himself a kind of flame descended out of heaven which illuminated the region of his mind above the memory, and also the region below the memory, as far as the eye; and further, that the luster of the light which proceeded from that flame increased more and more, as he perceived and thought truth from the love of good (T. C. R. 504).

342. It must be borne in mind, however, that the light of heaven which flows into man through the spiritual or internal man when it is opened, is not merely spiritual light, but spiritual light animated by spiritual heat, as appears plainly from the following statement:--

The light of heaven which enters through the spiritual mind is conjoined with the heat of heaven, which is love; such as is comparatively the case with the light of the world in spring time (A. E. 406).

When a person, therefore, is enlightened by the opening of his spiritual mind, spiritual light and heat enter into his mind conjointly, the former affecting his understanding, and the latter his will; as appears from what follows:--

With those who are in the affection of truth from good, the Intellectual of the internal man is enlightened, and the Voluntary of the internal man is kindled (A. C. 9300).

With those, however, who are is a state of enlightenment, spiritual heat and light do not enter each independently; but light enters through heat. Wherefore, their will, that is, their love is affected first, and afterwards through the love their understanding; as appears from what follows:--

505

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 506

The light of truth with a man is altogether according to the state of his love; in proportion as the love is kindled the truth shines; for the good of love is the very vital fire, and the truth of faith the very intellectual light which is intelligence and wisdom; they must proceed at a like pace (A. C. 10201).

The light of heaven, therefore, enters into the spiritual mind or man through the voluntary or will-part, and from the will-part it passes into the intellectual. On this ground also it is that with the regenerate man enlightenment flows in through good, that is, through spiritual good; and that through good also it passes from the spiritual into the natural man; and that in the natural man enlightenment is according to the delight of natural good, that is, according to the delight of spiritual good in the natural man. On this subject we read further:--

Perception from the Intellectual does not belong to the Intellectual, but to the inflowing Voluntary; for the Intellectual is nothing else than the Voluntary in form. Such is the character of the Intellectual when it is conjoined to the Voluntary; but before it has been thus conjoined, the Intellectual seems to be by itself, and the Voluntary by itself. Nevertheless, the case is only, as when the External separates itself from the Internal; for when the Intellectual revolves or thinks anything interiorly, it is the end from the Voluntary that constitutes its life, and that rules the process of thought in it (A. C. 3619).

Again:--

The Divine Influx out of heaven takes place into a mans will, and through the will into his understanding. The influx into the will takes place into the occiput, because into the cerebellum, and from thence it passes towards the interiors--into the cerebrum, where the understanding is, and after it has passed into the understanding by that way, it also comes into the sight; for a man sees from the understanding. Whether you say influx into the will or influx into the love it amounts to the same thing; for the will is the receptacle of love; and whether you say understanding or faith, it again amounts to the same thing, for the understanding is the receptacle of faith. That which through the will enters into the understanding, or through love into faith, comes into enlightenment;

506

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 507

for what a man wills or loves, he perceives clearly. It is different when it conies by the way of the understanding alone (A. E. 61).

343. (h) In order that spiritual good may be established in man, and that thereby he may become conjoined with the Lord, and come into a state of spiritual enlightenment, those states in man which are in opposition to spiritual good, and hence to the Lord and His kingdom, must first be removed out of the natural man. For this purpose, however, it is first of all necessary that the affection of the truth shall be purified in the man, and that he shall come from the Lord into the affection of truth for the sake of truth, and especially for the sake of life. These affections a man receives from the Lord, in proportion as he accepts for a ruling principle that everything that comes from man is evil and false, and that that only is good and true which comes from the Lord. This, however, is the principle of Affirmation concerning which Swedenborg says, that it consists in our thinking and believing within ourselves that those things which belong to doctrine from the Word are true, because the Lord has said so (see above, p. 234). This same principle consists further in this that the Divine Truth revealed by the Lord shall not only be
believed without any mental reservation whatsoever, but also that it shall be applied by the natural man in all the words he speaks, and all the deeds which he performs (see above p. 239).

The result of the principle of Affirmation when it becomes the ruling principle in man is this, that the member of the Church under its influence comes into the affection of the truth for its own sake, and also into the affection of the truth for the sake of life.

The Principle of Affirmation thus becomes one of the most important means by which a state of enlightenment is spiritual matters is conveyed to man by the Lord.

507

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 508

The establishment of the principle of Affirmation in man, however, and hence his enlightenment in spiritual matters depends altogether upon a consistent application on the part of the man of his freedom of choice and thus upon the assertion, on his part, of his spiritual freedom, by virtue of which he turns himself to the Lord and His kingdom, and turns away from self and the world. We thus read:--

Two states are with man in respect to those things which pertain to the Church, to worship and to the Word. Some turn towards the Lord, thus towards heaven; and others towards self and the world. Those who turn towards the Lord, that is, towards heaven, receive influx thence, and are in enlightenment; and thus they are inwardly in the perception of the truth. This influx takes place from the Lord through the Internal into the External. But those who turn towards their own self and the world, cannot receive any influx from the Lord, that is, out of heaven; thus they cannot be in any enlightenment, nor in any perception of the truth. For the world flows in from the aspect of self, and either extinguishes altogether, or repels, or perverts whatever comes from heaven (A. C. 10,702).

Hence it is that only the regenerate or spiritual who love the Lord above all things, and their neighbor as themselves, can be in a state of enlightenment from the Lord, and therefore see and recognize Divine Truth; while the unregenerate, and hence those who are merely natural and sensual, are void of all spiritual enlightenment, and can see and understand only what enters into their minds from the world of nature through their bodily senses. This is plainly stated by Swedenborg in what follows:--

Every man as to his thoughts and affections is in the spiritual worldconsequently, as to his spirit; for a mans spirit it is which thinks and is affected. A man who through regeneration by the Lord has become spiritual, as to his spirit, is in a heavenly society; but the natural man who has not been regenerated, as to his spirit is in an infernal society. With the latter evils out of hell continually flow in, and are also received with delight; but with the formerthe spiritualgoods flow in continually out of heaven, and are also received;

508

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 509

and since goods flow into his affection, and through his affection into the thought, he is in enlightenment (A. E. 759).

344. With him who has become spiritual, we learn here, goods flow in continually out of heaven, and are also received; and since goods flow into his affection, and through his affection into the thought, he is in enlightenment. And we read further, Good from the Internal operates and causes Affirmation; which good afterwards manifests itself by affection; namely, so that a man is affected by the truth, or begins to be delighted with it; first by knowing it, and afterwards by doing it (see above, p. 233). Such is the origin of the affection of the truth for its own sake, and for the sake of life.

The genuine affection of the truth, as we have seen above (A. C. 8993, in no. 276) consists in a mans willing or desiring to know the veriest truths of faith for the sake of a good use as an end, and for the sake of life. This affection, with a person who is being regenerated, gradually takes the place of that first affection of the truth which prevailed with him during the early part of his life, and which had for its object purposes of self and of the world, or glory in heaven, and other like things. Still the affection of the truth for the sake of a good use, and for the sake of life as an end, must not be mistaken for the affection of good. Concerning the difference between the affection of good and the affection of the truth we read as follows:--

There are two affections, namely, the affection of good, and the affection of truth. The affection of good consists in doing good from the love of good, and the affection of truth consists in doing good from the love of the truth. At first sight these two affections seem identical, yet they are distinct from each other both as regards essence and origin. The affection of good, or of doing good from the love of good, is properly an affection of the will; but the affection of the truth, or of doing good from the love of truth, is properly an affection of the understanding.

509

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 510

The affection of good is from celestial love, and the affection of truth from spiritual love. The affection of good can be predicated only of the celestial man, and the affection of truth only of the spiritual man (A. C. 1997).

The affection of the truth, however, is originally not only impure, but also not genuine, being determined at first by purposes flowing from the loves of self and of the world. This quality attends the affection of truth more or less during the whole of the first state of regeneration, and it is only during the second state of regeneration when the affection of the truth becomes regenerated, that these selfish and worldly ingredients are gradually removed from it. Hence the enlightenment in spiritual matters, during the first stage of regeneration, is only a partial enlightenment by which a man is enabled to confirm the truth as it has been stated by others (see above, nos. 305, 306); while the enlightenment in full exists with a man only during the second state of his regeneration, after the affection of the truth in him has become fully regenerated; we thus read:--

The first affection of the truth exists with a man while he is being regenerated; but the subsequent affection, which is a new affection, exists after he has been regenerated. In the first state the man is affected with the truth in order that he may become intelligent but in the subsequent state that he may become wise or what amounts to the same thing, in the first state the man is affected with the truth for the sake of doctrine, but in the subsequent state for the sake of life. So long as a man is affected by the truth for the sake of doctrine he has regard to good from truth but when he is affected with it for the sake of life, he has respect to truth from good; wherefore, the second state is an inversion of the first. On this account, while the man is being regenerated, the first state is rejected, and the second state, which is new, is received. The first state in respect to the subsequent, new state, also is impure; for so long as a man is affected by the truth for the sake of doctrine that he may become intelligent, he is also affected by reputation and glory. This affection then cannot help being present, and it is also permitted for purposes of introduction, because the man is of such a character; but when a man is affected with the truth for the sake of life; then also he rejects glory and reputation as ends, and embraces the good of life, that is, charity towards the neighbor (A. C. 6247).

510

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 511

From this it is made very plain that the affection of the truth is effective of a full state of enlightenment only in the second, and not in the first state of regeneration; and consequently, only when it has the good of life for its object. On this subject we read further:--

Enlightenment with everyone is according to his affection of the truth; and his affection of the truth is according to his good of life. Hence also those who are in the affection of the truth not for the sake of truth, but for the sake of gain, are not at all enlightened while reading the Word, but are simply confirmed in doctrinals of whatever quality they may be (A. C. 7012).

Again we read:--

Enlightenment is from the Lord alone, and it is with those who love truths because they are true, and who make them uses of life.... Enlightenment in the Word is none other.... Enlightenment in the word is with them, because they are in the Lord, and the Lord is in them. For the Lord is Truth itself; ... and the Lord is then loved, when men live according to His Divine truths; thus when uses are done from His truths (John xiv. 20-23). Such are they who are in enlightenment when reading the Word, and with them the Word shines, and is translucent.... It is thence that a man, from in interior perception, acknowledges the Truth; and afterwards sees it in his thought, and indeed as often as he is in the affection of the truth for the sake of the truth. For from this affection comes perception, from perception thought, and thus it becomes that acknowledgment which is called faith (T. C. R. 231).

The affection or love of the truth for its own sake, and without any respect to purposes of self and of the world, is the result of the influx of the light of heaven. That affection also affects the new will, through which enlightenment is conveyed to man. We thus read:--

The affection of loving truths because they are true, is imparted solely through the influx of the light of heaven through the spiritual mind.

511

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 512

For through the spiritual mind [when it is opened] the light of heaven is conjoined with the heat of heaven which is love; such as comparatively the case with the light of the world in spring-time (A. E. 406).

And again:--

Those persons who are in the love of the truth for the sake of the truth, and not for the sake of self and the world, enlightened in the Word when they read it; for they communicate with heaven, and therefore with the Lord. Hence also they who are enlightened by the Lord are led to see the truths of the Word even as they are in heaven; for the Lord flows into their understanding through heaven; it being the mans interior understanding which is enlightened. The Lord flows in then at the same time with faith, by the co-operation of the new will, the character of which is affected by the truth for the sake of the truth (A. C. 9424).

345. (i) The second means by which contradictory states are removed from the natural or external man, and by which it is prepared for conjunction with the spiritual, that is, the internal man, is Spiritual Temptation. The first result of Temptation in man--that is, of those temptations in which has conquered, is that the evils forbidden in the decalogue, are subdued and removed is him by a course of repentance. But in proportion as evils are removed from the natural man, good which constantly flows in from the internal man is able to be received in the natural man, and through good, enlightenment; wherefore, repentance, and thus the conquest of evils and falsities, is a practical means by which the member of the Church is able to come into a state of enlightenment from the Lord; and, on the other hand, again, a state of enlightenment enables a man to see what is good and true, and what is evil and false; wherefore, by the shunning of the new evils lie then discovers, he is able to be enlightened still more. In conquering the evils in the natural man, however, as we have already seen, the internal man makes use forces, that is, of the goods and truths which are in the external man, especially of the truths which are there. On this subject we read:--

Since all evils and falsities reside in the natural man, therefore they must be chastised and dispersed by such things as are likewise there; namely, by truths in the natural man.... With those who are spiritual, the Lord flows in, through the spiritual or internal man, into the natural or external man, and illuminates the latter. From this enlightenment a man sees what is true and good, and what is evil and false; and when the man sees these things, the Lord breaks up and disperses the evils and falsities which are in the natural man, through truths and goods which are likewise in the natural man, and which make one with the goods and truths in the spiritual or internal man (A. E. 176).

512

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 513

And again:--

Man is enlightened in the Rational for this is subject immediately to the internal Spiritual, and receives the light from heaven which it transmits to the Natural, when it is purified and an understanding, before his Natural is purified of evils.... He who believes that a man has a Rational and an understanding, before his Natural is purified of evils is mistaken. For the understanding consists in seeing the truths of the Church from the light of heaven; and the light of heaven flows in only with those [with whom evils have been removed] (A. E. 941).

During the state of temptation, a man is not in enlightenment, but rather in a state the very reverse of enlightenment; for the evil spirits of hell are then present with the man, and seek to engulf him in their evils and falsities. The enlightenment comes after the battle; that is, after the opposing evils and falsities have been removed from the natural man; when, therefore, the love of the spiritual or internal man is able to descend freely into the natural man, and to come there into a state of delight. In this connection we read:--

When the evils and falsities of a man are removed, then temptations are ended; and when they are ended joy flows in from the Lord through heaven and fills the mans natural mind (A. E. 807).

And again:--

When a man emerges from temptation, light with its spiritual heat, that is, truth with its good appears;

513

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 514

thence he has gladness after anxiety. This is the morning which succeeds the night in the other life (A. C. 6829).

Again:--

After every spiritual temptation comes enlightenment and affection, thus pleasantness and delight-pleasantness from enlightenment through truth, and delight from the affection of good (A. C. 8367).

346. (j) The influx from the internal into the external man with its enlightening influence, as we have seen, takes place into a man, when under the full influence of his freedom of choice he declares in favor of everything that comes from the Lord and heaven, and against that which comes from the mans own self and from the world. This, however, includes on the one hand, a shunning of all the evils and falsities, which are opposed to spiritual good, and hence to a conjunction by means of that good, with the Lord and heaven; and, on the other, it means a doing or a carrying out of the goods of charity, in every-day life. For in order that spiritual life and light may be received from the Lord, that life must be able to flow out freely in corresponding words and deeds, according to the universal law that influx is according to efflux. This law, however, is resisted so long as the loves of self and of the world have sway in the natural man; but the result of such a resistance is, that the internal man is gradually closed up, and that the reception of spiritual heat and light in the natural man, and hence enlightenment ceases; as appears from what follows:--

It is a universal law, that influx accommodates itself to efflux; and that if the efflux is obstructed, the influx is impeded as well. Through the internal man there is an influx of good and truth from the Lord and through the external man there ought to be an efflux, namely into life, by the exercise of charity. So long as there is an efflux, there is a continual influx out of heaven, that is, through heaven from the Lord. But if there is no efflux, an there is instead in the external or natural man a resistance, namely, evil and falsity, by which the inflowing good is torn and extinguished, it follows from the universal law stated above, that the influx accommodates itself to the efflux, consequently, that the influx of good is drawn backwards, and that the Internal through which the influx has place, is closed up.

514

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 515

But by this closure there is caused a stupidity in spiritual matters, even to such a point that a person in that condition knows nothing of eternal life, and is not willing to know anything about it; and that at last good is altogether torn up (A. C. 5828).

This shows how necessary it is for the members of the Church, in order that they may continue in a state of spiritual enlightenment, not only to shun evils and falsities, but also to engage in the practical performance of the uses of charity; for of such persons we read:--

Those who are not in the love of self, and who strive after intelligence for the sake of the uses of life, are raised by the Lord above their proprium or self into the light of heaven, and, without becoming conscious of it, are enlightened (A. E. 356).

Truth alone, consequently, does not furnish enlightenment, but when truths are studied and acquired for the sake of uses, that is, for the sake of the good of life, then the truths are conjoined with the good which is productive of uses, and are enlightened by it. Thus we read further:--

He is very much mistaken who thinks that any one is in enlightenment if he does not love to know the truth for the sake of the truth, and for the sake of the good of life; thus, if he does not love Divine Truth for the sake of life because living according to the Divine truths from the Word means loving the Lord; but from the Lord when he is loved, there is all enlightenment (A. C. 10,861).

And again we read:--

Enlightenment is from the Lord alone, and it is with those who love truths because they are true, and who make them uses of life.... They are in the Lord, and the Lord in them. For the Lord is Truth itself, and He is loved, when men live according to His Divine truths; thus when uses are done from them (T. C. R. 231).

Again we read:--

Enlightenment is imparted to none other than those who desire to know truths, not for the sake of reputation and glory, but for the sake of life and use.

515

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 516

This enlightenment is received by the Intellectual with man; for it is the Intellectual that is enlightened (A. C. 6222).

And again:-- 

The Revelation which is given in the Word is of such a character, that every one call be taught according to the affection of his love, and hence according to the thoughts of his understanding. Those who are not in the good of life can be taught very little; those who are in that good can be taught much. They are taught by the Lord through enlightenment (A. E. 1177).

When good uses, that is, when the good of life is thus done under the enlightening influence of the Divine Truth, then the truth in the mind is conjoined with good and becomes good; and when the truth in the natural man is conjoined with good, then the natural or external man becomes reciprocally conjoined with the internal or spiritual man; and by this conjunction comes under the direct influence of the life and light of heaven. Wherefore the goof of faith which is identical with the good of truth, and which implies an implicit carrying out in the life of the truths which a man has acquired from the Divine Word is the third medium for the regeneration of the natural man, and hence for its enlightenment. The good of faith, however, that is, the good of truth increases in a man in proportion as his life is devoted to the uses of charity; according to the principle that influx is according to efflux.

347. (k) When a man is in the habitual performance of the Good of charity in accordance with the truths of faith, then the affection from which he acts, gradually comes with him into a state of delight; and in accordance with this state of delight is the enlightenment of the man. The affection of truth is the first affection which with man comes into a state of delight, and in proportion as such is the case the affection of Good descends from the internal into the external man;

516

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 517

and when this latter affection also comes into a state of delight, then the enlightenment of the Natural reaches its state of fullness; for then the natural man is reduced into a state of correspondence with the spiritual man, and the life of the internal or spiritual man is freely received in the external man. On this subject we read:--

Man has enlightenment by influx into his spiritual delight; from this he has perception according to the truths of faith, of which his understanding is composed (A. E. 825).

And again:--

Natural good and its delight imparts intelligence and enlightens.... It is to be borne in mind, however, that natural good is not good, unless it is also spiritual good; for all good through the spiritual man or mind, flows into the natural man or mind and so far as the natural man (or mind) receives the good of the spiritual man (or mind), so far it receives good. Both must be, in order that good may be; since natural good separate from spiritual good in itself is evil, although it is still perceived by man as good (A. E. 619).

From this, however, it follows that the power of enlightenment dwells solely in spiritual Good which from the internal flows into the external man, and which there, during the practical performance of the uses of life, and thus of the good of life, comes into a state of delight.

348. (1) When the regeneration of the natural man has proceeded so far that he acts from the delight of the affection of good; then it is a sign that the inversion of state, by which good becomes the ruling power in man has been consummated in him, and that he has reached the end of the sixth day of creation. A fullness of enlightenment is the result of this advanced state of regeneration, as appears from what follows:--

In general it is to be observed that a man is not regenerate [i.e., as to his natural man] until he acts from the affection of good;

517

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 518

for then he wills Good, and it is delightful and blessed him to do so (A. C. 8701).

And again:--

When good flows in--which is the ease when order is being inverted, and good takes the first place--the Natural is enlightened, and then it appears what in the Natural is genuine truth and good, and what is not (A. C 4250).

But as regards the effect of good upon truths, after the inversion has taken place, it is as follows:--

When good is in the first place, and has dominion, it constantly produces truths. It multiplies them around itself, and also around each truth, and causes each truth to be like a little star, in the midst of which there is [an element of] lucidity. Moreover, good not only multiplies truths around itself; but it also produces truths from truths successively, by derivations (A. C. 5922).

349. (m) On taking a review of the whole subject of Enlightenment, we reach this result, that Good and hence Love, is the medium through which a man receives spiritual enlightenment from the Lord. This proposition is stated in so many words, in the following passages:--

All enlightenment is with man from the Lord, and it takes place through the good which is with man. Enlightenment also is according to the quality of good.... Those who are in good can see the truth from good, and can know as in clear daylight, whether a thing is so or not (A. C. 4214).

The character of the enlightenment which a man obtains through the medium of good, is explained thus:--

The good which is of charity is like a flame which affords light, and thus enlightens each and all things which the man had previously believed to be true. He also notices how falsities had intermingled themselves, and put on the appearance as though they were true (A. C. 4245).

Good, however, is the medium through which enlightenment takes place, because all enlightenment comes from the Lord, and the Lord communicates with man only through good;

518

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 519

as is stated in what follows:--

The Lord never flows immediately into truths with any man, but mediately through his good. For good belongs to the will, and the will is the man himself. From the will the understanding is produced and formed; for the understanding was adjoined to the will, that what tie will loves the understanding may see, and also bring forth into light. If the will, therefore, is not in good, but in evil, the influx of truth from the Lord into the understanding is of no benefit; for it is dispersed, because it is not loved; nay, it is perverted, and the truth is falsified. From this it appears why the Lord does not flow immediately into a mans understanding, except so far as his will is in good (A. E. 730).

Again, good is the medium through which there is enlightenment, because the light of heaven flows into man through good. We thus read:--

Light from heaven enters through good, thus through the will; wherefore, if any one is in good there is light with him in the very principle of the truth, so that he is able to see it clearly. For heaven itself enters into man through the way of good or of love, thus through the will (S. D. 5708).

And again we read:--

Man is so far in the light of heaven, as he is in intelligence; and he is so far in intelligence, as he is in the truths of faith and he is so far in the truths of faith as he is in the good o love; consequently, a man is so far in the light of heaven as he is in the good of love (A. C. 5421).

350. Good is further effective of enlightenment, because it conjoins the man with the Lord, and with heaven; and hence good also is the medium, through which the Word is understood. We thus read:--

When the goods of the love of the Lord, and of the love of the neighbor are not with the member of the Church, the Word is not understood. For the conjunction of the Lord and of heaven with the member of the Church is through good. Wherefore, unless there is good with a man, there cannot be any enlightenment with him; for all enlightenment, during the reading of the Word, is from the Lord out of heaven; and when there is no enlightenment; the truths which are in the Word are in obscurity (A. E. 365).

519

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 520

Good also causes enlightenment, because the man who is in good is elevated into the Divine light which proceeds from the Lord. Concerning this enlightenment through Good we read further:--

When a man is in good, and from good in truths he is elevated into the Divine light which is the Divine Truth proceeding from the Lord; and according to the quantity and quality of good into more interior light. From this he has a general enlightenment, in which he sees from the Lord innumerable truths, which he perceives from good. He is led then by the Lord to notice and appropriate those truths which are suitable to himself, and indeed as to the most minute in order, even as they are conducive to his eternal life. (A. C. 9407).

Good, however, not only elevates a man into the light of heaven, but it also opens the interiors of his mind for the perception of that light. We thus read further:--

Those only are in enlightenment who are in the two loves of heaven, namely, in the love of the Lord, and the love of the neighbor. For these loves open the interior i.e., the higher mind which is formed for the reception of the light of heaven. Through this mind the light of heaven flows in with these persons, and causes enlightenment; still, while they live in the world, they do not perceive truths in that higher mind, but in a lower mind which belongs to the external or natural man.... When the internal or spiritual man, in which is that interior or higher mind of which we have just spoken, is opened, the Lord coerces the evils and disperses the falsities which are in the external or natural man (A. E. 177).

Good, in fine, causes enlightenment in man because a mans faculty of reception is according to his state of good, as appears from what follows:--

Influx and enlightenment take place according to the faculty of reception with man; and the faculty of reception is according to the love of truth and good. Those, therefore, who are in the love of truth and good as ends, are elevated as to their interiors. But those who are in the love of truth and good ... for the sake of themselves and the world, because they constantly look and gravitate downwards, cannot be elevated thus they cannot receive the Divine influx, and cannot be enlightened (A. C. 10,330).

520

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 521

351. (n) We have seen thus far that the light of heaven, and hence enlightenment, is conveyed to man through the medium of good, and thus through the affections of the will. Nevertheless, the light of heaven is only received by good in the will, in order that it may be transmitted from the will to the understanding, and thus from good to the truths of which the understanding is composed. How this is done appears very clearly from what follows:--

All enlightenment is from good; for the good of love is comparatively as the flame of the sun, from which are heat and light. But truth is like the object through which the flame shines; hence there is enlightenment by light; but according to the quality of the light from the object [that is, from the truth], such is the enlightenment. Good is received only by truth; but such as the truth is, such is the reception, and such is the enlightenment. Whenever, therefore, there is enlightenment through truth the appearance is as if the enlightenment from truth belonged to the truth, when yet it belongs to good, which shines in this manner through truth (A. C. 3004).

Again we read:--

Where there are no truths, there is obscurity; for the light of heaven flows only into truths. The light of heaven, indeed, is the Divine Truth from the Lord; from this it is that truths with angels and spirits, and also with men, are subsidiary lights. But their light they have from the Divine Truth through the good which is in the truths. For unless truths are from good, that is, unless they have in themselves good, they cannot receive any light from the Divine. They receive it through good; for good is like fire or flame, and truths are like lights thence. Truths do also shine in the other life apart from good, but they shine from a wintry light which becomes darkness at the approach of the light of heaven (A. C. 8219).

352. From the above then it follows that the enlightenment which the member of the Church receives by virtue of good, as to its quality is determined by the truths of which his understanding is composed. We thus read:--

The man who is led by the Lord is taught by Him from day to day what he should do and speak, and also what he should preach and write; for when evils are removed, he is continually under the Lords auspices, and enjoys enlightenment.

521

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 522

But he is led and taught by the Lord not immediately by any perceptible inspiration, but by an influx into his spiritual delight, from which he has perception according to the truths of which his understanding is composed (A. E. 825).

The Lord, therefore, does not enlighten a man immediately, but mediately through the knowledges of the truth that are with him. We thus read further:--

The Lord does not flow in immediately with a man, and teach him; but He flows into his knowledges, thus mediately (A. C. 4136).

And again:--

The Lord teaches every one through the Word, and He teaches him from the knowledges that are with him, and does not immediately pour into him new knowledges (T. C. R. 208).

The method, however, by which the Lord thus enlightens man, is clearly set forth in the following passage:--

The Lord teaches no one immediately, but mediately through the things which are with the man from hearing and sight. Immediate revelation is not given, except that which has been given in the Word and which is written in the style used in the Prophets and Evangelists, or in the historical parts. revelation contained therein is of such a character that every love, and hence according to the thoughts of his understanding. Those who are not in good as to life can be taught only very little, but those who are in good can be taught much. They are taught by the Lord through enlightenment.

Enlightenment takes place as follows: Light conjoined to heat flows in through heaven from the Lord. This heat which is Divine Love, affects the will--whence the man has the affection of good; and this light which is Divine Wisdom, affects the understanding--whence the man has the thought of truth. From these two fountains, namely, from the mill and the understanding, are affected all the things of a mans love, and all the things of his knowledge; but only those things are excited which belong to the topic under consideration, and these are caused to be present.

In this wise enlightenment takes place from the Lord through the Word; wherein everything, by virtue of the Spiritual which is within it, communicates with heaven. The Lord flows in through heaven; and He flows into that which is then under the gaze of the man;

522

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 523

which influx with every one is continual and universal even from the minutest singulars.... Being enlightened by the Lord through heaven, means being enlightened through the Holy Spirit; for the Holy Spirit is the Divine which proceeds from the Lord as a sun; from which sun is heaven.

From this it is manifest that the Lord teaches the member of the Church mediately through the Word, according to the love of his will which is his through life, and according to the light of his understanding which is his through knowledge or science; and, further, that this cannot be otherwise, because such is the Divine order of influx (A. E. 1177).

353. From the above it follows that the extent to which a member of the Church is capable of being enlightened by the Lord is commensurate with the extent of his knowledge. We hence read further:--

The man whose internal is opened, is in the internal sense of the Word, although he is not aware of it. Thence he has enlightenment when reading the Word, but this enlightenment is according to the light in which he is able to be by means of the knowledges which are with him. (A. C. 10,000).

Again we read:--

Spiritual perception [consequent upon enlightenment] exists from spiritual truths which are called truths of faith; and, indeed, on this ground, that the light of heaven is the Divine Truth proceeding from the Lord; which Truth shines before the eyes of the angels like light, and which also shines in their understanding, and imparts to them intelligence and wisdom; yet with a variety according as this light is received in good. In order, therefore, that spiritual perception may exist, there must be spiritual knowledges with a man in his Natural; and these spiritual knowledges must be from Revelation. When the light of heaven flows into these knowledges, it flows into its own; for, as said above, this light is the Divine Truth which proceeds from the Lord (A. C. 9103).

And again:--

The influx of the light of heaven, from the Lord through the internal man, accommodates itself to the analogous end corresponding knowledges of the Truth in the Natural; and it is according to the obedience yielded to them (Ibid).

Enlightenment with the member of the Church is thus according to the state of the natural man in respect to the knowledges of the Truth;

523

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 524

wherefore we read again:--

Apart from the knowledges of good and truth the Natural cannot be enlightened by the national, that is, through the Rational; for knowledges are the recipient vessels of the good and truth which flow in from the Rational. According to the quality and quantity of what is received by the vessels is quantity and quality of their enlightenment. The vessels which receive good and truth from the national are the very truths of the Natural, which are nothing else than scientifics, knowledges and doctrinals (A. C. 3508).

Hence also it is that no one can be enlightened in, and therefore perceive, what he does not know and believe; wherefore, we read:--

The interiors, therefore, and the internals are formed and adapted for the reception of the goods of love and the truths of faith, and thus for the perception of good and truth, by instruction. For no one can perceive what he does not know and believe; wherefore, he can be gifted with the faculty of perceiving the existence and quality of the good of love and the truth of faith only by knowledges (A. C. 1802).

354. In order, however, that scientifics and knowledges may receive the 1ight of heaven, and thus may be enlightened, it is necessary that they shall be learned for the sake of use; because in this case they are opened, and are ready to receive the influx from within. We thus read:--

In proportion as scientifics are learned for the sake of use, as, for instance, for the sake of human society, for the sake of the Lords Church on earth, for the sake of the Lords Church in heaven, and still more for the sake of the Lord, they are opened (A. C. 1472).

And again:--

When scientifics and knowledges have use for end, they receive life from uses but life of such a quality as the use is.
