Those who learn knowledges in order to be perfected in the faith of love--for true and genuine faith is love to the Lord and love towards the neighbor--are in the use of all uses, and receive spiritual and celestial life from the Lord; and so long as they are in this life they are in the faculty of perceiving all things which belong to the Lords kingdom (A. C. 1964).

524

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 525

When scientifics and knowledges have thus use for end, they are illuminated by the light of heaven; and are made spiritual and then spiritual things are in the Natural. We thus read:--

The interiors of the scientifics are the things that are spiritual in the Natural; and spiritual things are in the Natural when the scientifics which are therein are enlightened by the light of heaven; and they are then enlightened by the light of heaven, when the man has faith in the doctrinals which are from the Word; and a man has then faith, when he is in the good of charity. For then truths, and thereby scientifics are enlightened by the good of charity, as by a flame. Scientifics have their spiritual light from thence (A. C. 5637).

Scientifics which in themselves are natural, are thus made spiritual with a man who is in the good of charity; for with him they are enlightened by the light of heaven. On this subject we read further:--

Every scientific with a man is natural, because it is in his natural maneven the scientific concerning spiritual and celestial things; because the man sees them in the Natural, and from the Natural; and what he does not see from the Natural, he does not comprehend. nut the regenerate man who is called spiritual, sees things differently from the merely natural man. The scientifics with him are enlightened by the light of heaven [received through the medium of the angels]; while, with the latter they are not. With him they are enlightened by a light which flows in through spirits who are in falsity and evil; which light is indeed from the light of heaven, but with them it has become opaque, like the light of evening or night. For such spirits, and hence such men, like owls, see clearly at light, and obscurely in day-time; that is, they see clearly falsities, and obscurely truths; and hence they see clearly the things which belong to the world, and obscurely, if stall, those things which belong to heaven (A. C. 4967).

355. The quality produced in the understanding by spiritual enlightenment is faith; for by the reception of the light of heaven in the Intellectual, in the plane of conscience, faith is established also in the internal man.

525

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 526

But by the conjunction of the internal with the external man, the light of heaven, by the process called Enlightenment, is established in the knowledges and scientifics, which are transformed thereby into truths of faith. In a certain sense Faith and Enlightenment are synonymous; for faith consists of truths seen in spiritual light; while enlightenment is caused by the reception of the light of heaven in the truths which the man derives by the study of the Divine Word. Concerning the relation between faith and enlightenment, we read as follows:--

When charity, which is the very spiritual affection, conjoins itself with knowledges, there results faith. In so far as a man is then in that affection, he sees with his thought those things which belong to his faith and which are called truths, and he acknowledges them, because they are from his very spirit, thus from his very spiritual life. This also is what is called enlightenment. Hence it is that no one be enlightened from the Word, unless he is in the spiritual affection of the truth (A. E. 242).

As regards the further development of faith, we read:--

Faith which in respect to its essence is charity is constantly being perfected by such things as are confirmative; for many truths are constantly being perceived from spiritual light, and all these truths conjoin themselves with the good of charity and perfect it. From this a man acquires intelligence and wisdom, which at length becomes angelic (Ibid).

Enlightenment, consequently is the result of a conjunction of charity and faith; for these two have a mutual affinity for each other and unless they are joined together charity fails to be charity, and faith faith; for charity is the life of faith, and the two are thus related like soul and body. We read further on this subject:--

Charity which is the spiritual affection, cannot exist with any one unless he is acquainted with truths, explores himself in accordance with them, receives them, and leads a new life in harmony therewith.

526

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 527

But from this it follows that charity is the life of faith, and that there is life in faith in proportion to the charity that is in it; and further, that in proportion to the charity which is in faith a man is led by the Lord (A. E. 242).

Faith, thus, has a twofold origin, an internal and an external. Its internal origin is charity, and its external origin the knowledge of the truth from the Divine Word. Unless faith in man has this twofold origin it is not real, and hence not saving; nor is faith, in this ease, synonymous with enlightenment. We thus read:--

A merely natural faith is a faith insinuated through an external, and not an internal way such as is the sensual faith which arises when a thing is believed to be so because the eye has seen, and the hand touched it. This is the faith concerning which the Lord said to Thomas, Because thou hast seen, Thomas, thou hast believed; blessed are they who do not see, and yet believe (John xx., 20). Further, such a faith is the faith of miracles which has an existence when a thing is believed to be so, solely on the strength of miracles; and, further, it is the faith of authority which has place when a thing is believed to be so, because another in whom a person has faith, says so.

But spiritual faith is that faith which is insinuated through an internal, and at the same time an external way. The insinuation through the internal way causes a thing to be believed; and what is insinuated through the external way causes this thing to be confirmed. The spiritual of faith is the affection of charity, and flowing from this the affection of the truth for the sake of a good use and for the sake of life. These cause faith to be spiritual. The insinuation of faith by an internal way, is effected by the reading of the Word, coupled with enlightenment from the Lord which is granted according to the quality of the affection, that is, according to the end by which a man is influenced in acquiring a knowledge of the truth (A. C. 8078).

356. (o) All enlightenment is effected through the truths of the Divine Word. As there is no enlightenment, unless a man is in spiritual knowledges (see above, A. C. 9103, in no. 353), so also there is no enlightenment independently of the Divine Word, because all spiritual knowledges are derived from the Divine Word.

527

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 528

The enlightenment which results from regeneration is, consequently, an enlightenment in the truths of the Divine Word. Yet it must be well borne in mind that enlightenment is the Divine Word is altogether dependent upon the extent of the knowledge which a person has derived by a study of the Word. Good, indeed, is the medium through which enlightenment takes place; wherefore, unless a person is in spiritual good, he cannot be enlightened; but the extent of the enlightenment is determined by the extent of knowledges. For a person cannot perceive, and hence see in spiritual light, what he has not previously known and believed (A. C. 1802).

Enlightenment in the truths of the Divine Word, means enlightenment in, and by means of, its spiritual sense. For during enlightenment the light of heaven, through the spiritual sense, flows into the knowledges from the Divine Word which are in the mind and especially into those knowledges which are stored up there from the letter of the Word. On this subject we read:--

With those who are in enlightenment from the Lord, while they are reading the Word, light out of heaven flow sin through the internal sense (A. C. 10,648).

Again:--

The internal sense, in a certain way, is open to every one who is in an External from the Internal, i.e., whose internal man has been opened; even though he should not know what the internal sense is. For heaven which is in the internal sense of the Word, flows in with the man, while he is reading the Word; it enlightens him, and gives him perception, and thus teaches him. Yea, if you are willing to believe it, a mans internal man, of its own accord is in the internal sense; for it is a heaven in a least effigy, and hence, when it is opened, it is with the angels in heaven; wherefore it is also in like perception with them.... It hence appears, that a man whose Internal is opened, is in the internal sense of the Word, although he is not aware of it. From this he has enlightenment when reading the Word, but according to the light which he is able to have by means of the knowledges that are with him (A. C. 10,400).

528

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 529

And again:--

All who read the Word, are kept by the Lord in the spiritual sense; yet, this sense is not received by any others except by those with whom the interiors are opened; and since it is received in knowledges, therefore it is received according to the extent and the charity in which their Intellectual can be enlightened through the knowledges which are with them (A. C. 10,402).

Again we read:--

Divine Truth in the literal sense is in natural light, and Divine Truth in the spiritual sense is in spiritual light; when spiritual light, therefore, flows into natural light with the man who is reading the Word, he is enlightened, and sees the truths which are in it; for the objects of spiritual light are truths. The Word in the literal sense, also, is of such a character that the more a man is enlightened by an influx of the light of heaven, the more does he see truths from their connection, and hence from their form; and the more he sees them, the more interiorly is his national opened; for the Rational is the receptacle of the light of heaven (A. R. 911).

357. It is those men who, by virtue of the opening of their internal man, are in the spiritual sense, and from this in a state of enlightenment from the Lord, who are able to form doctrine from the literal sense of the Word, for the use of the Church. We read concerning them in a general way:--

The genuine sense of the Word is not grasped by any others than those who are enlightened. But those only are enlightened who are in love and faith to the Lord. Their interiors are elevated by the Lord even into the light of heaven (H. D. 10,323).

The Word in the letter can be understood only by means of doctrine from the Word made by one who is enlightened. For its literal sense is accommodated to the apprehension of even simple minded men; wherefore, doctrine from the Word must be with them for a lamp (H. D. 10,324).

We read further:--

Doctrine must be collected from the Word, and when it is collected the man must be in enlightenment from the Lord;

529

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 530

and he is in enlightenment when he is in the love of the truth for the sake of the truth, and not for the sake of self and the world. Such persons are enlightened in the Word when reading it; and they see the truth, and make for themselves doctrine. The reason of this being so is, that these persons communicate with heaven, and thus with the Lord and hence they who are enlightened by the Lord are led to see the truths of the Word such as they are in heaven. For the Lord flows into their understanding through heaven, because it is the interior understanding of the man which is enlightened. The Lord also, at the same time, flows in then with faith, by the co-operation of the new will as a means, the part of which new will it is to
become affected by the truth for the sake of the truth. In this wise the doctrine of truth and good is given by the Lord to man (A. C. 9424).

358. Doctrine is necessary because the Word in its literal sense as stated above, is accommodated apprehension of the simple-minded. While, therefore, in some parts of the letter the internal sense of the Word, which is true doctrine shines forth, in other parts the truth, by appearances, is accommodated to the state of reception of the simple-minded. The apparent contradictions which necessarily arise under such circumstances, are explained and reconciled by the doctrine of the Church, which is made by those who are in a state of enlightenment from the Lord. On this subject we read:--

The truths which are drawn from the literal sense of the Word are called scientific truths. The general truths from that source are received by the generality of men, and hence are current in ordinary conversation. There are many truths of that kind, and they have great power. But the literal sense of the Word is for the simple-minded, for those who are being initiated into the interior truths of faith, and for those w do not comprehend interior things; for that sense is according to the appearance before the sensual man, and thus according to the appearance before the sensual man, and thus according to his comprehension. Hence it is that in a number of places in that sense there occur incongruous things and such as are contradictory.... These things, because they are drawn from the literal sense of the Word are called scientific truths, which differ much from the truths of faith that belong to the doctrine of the Church.

530

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 531

The latter truths arise from the former by explanation; for when they are explained, the member of the Church learns that these things are so expressed in the Word for the sake of comprehension, and according to the appearance. Hence also it is that the doctrines of the Church in very many cases recede from the literal sense of the Word. It is to be observed that the true doctrine of the Church is what is called here the internal sense; for in the internal sense are truths of the kind that the angels have in heaven (A. C. 9028).

From this may be seen the importance of true doctrine from the Word, which is to be formed by those who are in a state of enlightenment from the Lord. We read further concerning them:--

Truths from the Word are to be fitted together into doctrine, so as to be subservient for use. This should be done by those wile are in enlightenment from the Lord. But in a state of enlightenment, while reading the Word, are they who are in the affection of the truth for the sake of the truth, and for the sake of the good of life; and not they who are in this affection for the sake of self-glory, reputation and brain (A. C. 10,105).

And again we read:--

Every one is enlightened and instructed from the Word according to his affection of the truth, and the intensity of his desire for the truth; and also according to his faculty of reception. Those who are in enlightenment, as to their internal man, are in heaven; for it is the light of heaven that enlightens a man in the truths and goods of faith. Those who are illuminated in this manner understand the Word according to its interiors. Wherefore, they form doctrine for themselves out of the Word, to which they apply the literal sense (A. C. 9382).

359. It is thought sometimes that a member of the Church, by virtue of the good of life in which he is, or by virtue of an advanced state of regeneration, is able to see the spiritual sense of the Word in the sense of the letter, independently of the condition of his mind in respect to a knowledge of doctrine. But this is a fallacy; for it is a fundamental condition of enlightenment that spiritual good is the medium through which the light of heaven is admitted into the man in whom the external and the internal man are conjoined;

531

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 532

but that the extent of this illumination is determined altogether by the state of spiritual knowledges in the mind. That by these knowledges, however, is not meant simply a knowledge of correspondences, but also a knowledge of doctrine, that is, a knowledge of the truths taught by the spiritual sense, appears from what follows:--

Hereafter the spiritual sense of the Word will not be given to any one, except to one who is in genuine truths from the Lord. The cause is that no one can see the spiritual sense except from the Lord alone, and unless he is in Divine truths from the Lord. For the spiritual sense of the Word treats of the Lord alone and His kingdom; and that sense it is in which are His angels in heaven; for it is His Divine Truth there. This Divine Truth may be violated by a man, if he possesses a knowledge of correspondences, and by means of that knowledge is desirous to explore the spiritual sense of the Word from his own power; for by some correspondences known to himself he may pervert that sense, and bend it so as to confirm even what is false. But this would be doing violence to the Divine Truth, and hence also to heaven, which is its dwelling-place. If any one, therefore, wishes to open that sense from himself and not from the Lord, heaven is closed; and when heaven is closed a man either sees nothing of the truth, or he is spiritually demented. The cause of this is also that the Lord through the Word teaches every one, and He teaches him from the knowledges that are with him, and does not immediately pour in new ones; unless, therefore, a man is in Divine truths, or if he is only in a few truths and it the same time, in falsities, he may from these falsities falsify truths as is also done by every heretic, so far as the very literal sense of the Word is concerned. Lest, therefore, anyone should enter into the spiritual sense, and pervert the genuine truth which belongs to that sense, guards are placed by the Lord, which in the Word are called cherubim (T. C. R. 208).

We read again:--

It may be thought that the doctrine of genuine truth can be acquired through the spiritual sense of the Word, which is given by means of the science of correspondences. Doctrine, however, is not acquired through the spiritual sense, but it is simply illustrated and corroborated by its means for no one comes into the spiritual sense through correspondences, unless he is previously in genuine truths from doctrine.

532

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 533

Unless a man is previously in genuine truths, through some correspondences known to him, he call falsify the Word, by connecting and explaining these correspondences so that they shall confirm what is inherent in the mind from a preconceived principle. Besides, the spiritual sense is not given to any one except by the Lord alone, and it is guarded by Him, as heaven is guarded; for heaven is in that sense (S. S. 56).

And again:--

No one can see the spiritual sense except from the doctrine of genuine truth. From that doctrine the spiritual sense may be seen, when there is some knowledge of correspondences. But he who is in the doctrine of what ms false cannot see anything of the spiritual sense. He draws and bends the correspondences with which he is acquainted towards the falsities of his doctrine; wherefore, he is able to falsify the Word still more. The spiritual sense of the Word, therefore, is from the Lord. This is the reason why no one either in the natural, or in the spiritual world is allowed to investigate the spiritual sense of the Word from its literal sense, unless he is thoroughly in the doctrine of Divine Truth, and in enlightenment from the doctrine of Lord. Wherefore, the spiritual sense may be seen from the doctrine of the Divine Truth confirmed from the literal sense of the Word; but doctrine can never be seen first from the spiritual sense. He thinks falsely who says to himself: I know many correspondences; now I may know the doctrine of Divine Truth, the spiritual sense will teach it to me. This cannot be done. But, as said above, let him say to himself: I know the doctrine of Divine Truth, now I may see the spiritual sense, provided I know correspondences. Yet even then he must be in enlightenment from the Lord; because the spiritual sense is the very Divine Truth in its light, and it is understood by the glory, while the literal sense of the Word is understood by the cloud (De Verbo, posthumous, no. 21).

A knowledge of correspondences, however, is not the only means by which we may arrive at a knowledge of the spiritual sense. This sense appears also by a study of the context, and a comparison of a number of passages from Scripture; as appears from what follows:--

The internal sense is not that sense only which is hidden away in the external sense, but also that sense which results from a proper comparison of various passages of the literal sense; and this sense is noticed by those who are enlightened by the Lord as to their Intellectual.

533

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 534

For the enlightened Intellectual distinguishes between apparent and real truths, and especially between falsities and truths, although it does not judge of the very truths in themselves. The Intellectual, however cannot be enlightened unless it is believed that the love to the Lord and the charity towards the neighbor are the chief and the essential things of the Church. He who proceeds from an acknowledgment of these things, and provided he is in them himself, sees innumerable truths nay, many arcana are uncovered to him, and indeed from an interior acknowledgment, according to the degree of his enlightenment from the Lord (A. C. 7233).

360. Those who are taught by the Lord by means of the Word, are enlightened as to the literal sense in their minds; for this sense is illuminated with them by the light of the spiritual sense. We thus read:--

When those who are in Divine truths, and in the faith that the Word interiorly in its bosom is the Holy Divine and still more when those who are in the faith that the Word is such by virtue of its spiritual and celestial senses, read the Word while in a state of enlightenment from the Lord, they see Divine truths in natural light. For the light of heaven in which is the spiritual sense of the Word, flows into the natural light in which is the literal sense of the letter of the Word, and illuminates the mans Intellectual, which is called the national, and cause the man to see and acknowledge Divine truths where they stand forth, and where they are hidden. With some these things flow in with the light of heaven; sometimes even, while they do not know it (T. C. R. 215).

The enlightenment of the Divine Word in man takes place through the influx of his interior, spiritual thought into his exterior, natural thought which is from the knowledges and scientifics in the external, natural memory; concerning this influx see above (no. 300). On this subject we read further:--

Those who are in enlightenment while reading the Word, see it from within; for their Internal is opened; and when the Internal is opened, it is in the light of heaven. This light flows in and enlightens, although the man is not aware of it. He is not aware of it, because this light flows into the knowledges in the mans memory, which knowledges are in natural light. And since the man, from these knowledges, thinks as from himself, he is unable to notice the influx;

534

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 535

nevertheless, from various indications he may know that he has been under the influence of enlightenment.

The influx, however, through which enlightenment takes place is as follows: When the Word is being read the angels perceive it, as well as the men; but the angels perceive it spiritually, and the men naturally. The man whose Internal is aware of it so long as he lives in the world, because his spiritual thought flows into natural thought in the external man, and presents itself there to the sight. Nevertheless, it is that Interior thought which enlightens, and through which the influx from the Lord takes place. The ideas of interior thought are spiritual, and on flowing down are turned into natural ideas, which appear then under another form, and under another appearance (A. C. 10,661).

361. The Word is the chief means of mans salvation, because through the Word is effected mans union with heaven, and through heaven with the Lord. But the Word has bees entrusted by the Lord to the Church, that through its teaching, the Church may become instrumental in establishing the Lords kingdom in the souls of men, and that by its means it may lead men to the Lord, and cause them to be regenerated at His hands. But since the Word cannot be understood without doctrine, and since doctrine from the Word can be prepared only by one who is in a state of enlightenment from the Lord, therefore also the Lord has provided that the ministers of the Church shall be in enlightenment from Him by virtue of their ordination into the ministerial office. This source of enlightenment is in addition to that which is enjoyed by those of the clergy, as well as by those of the laity, who suffer themselves to be regenerated by the Lord. Concerning this twofold enlightenment we read:--

That Divine virtue and operation which is meant by the sending forth of the Holy Spirit, with the clergy in particular consists in enlightenment and instruction. The operations of the Lord enumerated above, namely, reformation, regeneration, renovation, vivification, remission of sins, and lastly, salvation, flow in from the Lord with the clergy, as well as with the laity, and are received by those wile are in the Lord and the Lord in them (John vi., 56; xiv 20; xv. 4, 5).

535

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 536

But the reason why with the clergy in particular there are enlightenment and instruction, is this, that they belong to their office, and that the ordination into the ministry conveys them.... That with the clergy there are two other spiritual operations besides may be seen below in no. 155 (T. C. R. 146).

It was shown above (no. 146) that the Divine virtue which is meant by the operation of the Holy Spirit consists with the clergy in particular in Enlightenment and Instruction but two intermediate [virtues] are added to these, namely, Perception and Disposition. Wherefore, there are four things which follow with the clergy in order; Enlightenment, Perception, Disposition and Instruction. Enlightenment is from the Lord; Perception is with man, according to the state of his mind as formed through doctrinals if these doctrinals are true, the perception becomes clear from the light which enlightens; but if these doctrinals are false, the perception becomes obscure, and yet by dint of confirmation it may appear as if it were clear but this is due to a fatuous light, which before the merely natural sight appears like brightness. Disposition, however, arises from the affection of the love of the will; the delight of which love disposes and arranges. If this delight is that of an evil love and of the falsity from it, it excites a zeal which outwardly appears harsh, rough furious and fiery, and inwardly consists of anger, rage and unmercifulness but if this delight is that of good and of the truth from it, the zeal which it causes is outwardly gentle and smooth, thundering and flashing, yet inwardly it consists of charity, grace and mercy. Instruction, however follows, as an effect from the above causes. Thus the enlightenment which is from the Lord is turned into various kinds of light and heat with every one according to the state of his mind (T. C. R. 155).

362. There is thus with the clergy an enlightenment which is inherent in the use of the ministerial office, and which is conveyed to them by ordination. This enlightenment, however, is not independent of those conditions under which the members of the Church ordinarily enjoy from the Lord enlightenment in spiritual matters. For as enlightenment is received by the members of the Church generally through the medium of the good of charity, and thus through the spiritual love of use, so also enlightenment comes to the ministers of the Church while they are engaged in the performance of the use, that is, of the good of their office which concerns the salvation of souls.

536

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 537

For according to a ministers love of the use of his office, is his affection of the truth, and his understanding of the truth, and his skill in presenting the truth to others. For we read:--

The good of the priesthood consists in caring for the salvation of souls, in teaching the way to heaven, and in leading those who are taught. In proportion as a minister is in that good, in the same proportion he acquires, from the love and the desire of that good, the truths which he may teach, and through which he may lead (Doctr. of Life, 30).

But is T. C. R. 166 we read, that the delight of the affection of a ministers love disposes and arranges--namely, the truths in his mind, so that he is able to teach, and to lead those who are taught.

363. Another general condition of enlightenment, as we have seen, is this: that the extent of enlightenment, with a member of the Church, is determined by the knowledges in the mind. For, as we have seen, enlightenment with a man is according to the light in which he is able to be by means of the knowledges which are with him (A. C. 4136). And, again, the Lord teaches man from the knowledges that are with him, and does not immediately pour into him sew knowledges (T. C. R. 208).

This fundamental condition of enlightenment applies emphatically to that enlightenment which the ministers receive from the Lord by virtue of their ordination into the ministerial office. For the perception of a minister which results from the enlightening influx of the Holy Spirit into the ministerial office, as we have seen, is according to the state of his mind as formed by doctrinals; and, again, the enlightenment which is from the Lord is turned, with the ministers, into various kinds of light and heat;

537

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 538

with every one according to the state of his mind. This same doctrine is further expressed in the following passage:--

The clergyman who is to teach the Word, the doctrine of the Lord, of redemption and salvation by Him, is to be ordained by the solemn promise of the Holy Spirit, and the representation of its transfer; but it is received by the clergyman according to the faith of his life (Canons, Holy Spirit, iv. 7-9).

As no new knowledges are poured into a minister by his ordination; but only those knowledges are enlightened in his mind which he has acquired by previous study; therefore, also, it is necessary that ministers should receive a special training for their office; and that by their training not only the generals, but also the particulars and singulars of the doctrine of the Divine Word, should be firmly implanted in their minds. For the difference between the clergy and the laity does not consist simply is the fact that the former are ordained, and the latter not, but that the former are in the interiors, and thus in the particulars and singulars of doctrine, and the latter not; as is plainly stated in what follows:--

The Church [that is, the outward, visible Church] is internal and external. It is internal with the clergy, and external with the laity; that is, it is internal with those who have studied interiorly the doctrinals of the Church, and confirmed them from the Word; and it is external with those who have not done so (A. R. 393).

But that the ministers should be trained in the particulars and singulars of doctrine, follows from the fact that internal things are particulars and singulars, and external things generals, as appears from what follows:--

The more exterior a thing is, the more general also it is; and the more interior, the less general--so that interior things are respectively called particulars and singulars (A. C. 4345).

364. Enlightenment, again, as we have seen, is brought about through association with the angels of heaven.

538

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 539

When, therefore, a member of the Church, by virtue of his regeneration, is associated with the angels of heaven, then through his associate angels the light of heaven is directed into the truths and knowledges which hare entered into the formation of his understanding. We thus saw above (D. L. W. 150, in no. 334), that enlightenment takes place through the mediation of angels and spirits, because the man who is in enlightenment is placed then in the midst of such angels and spirits as receive from the Lord alone mole enlightenment than others. From this, however, it follows that the enlightenment of ministers also takes place through a similar channel; that, therefore, by virtue of their ordination they are placed in the midst of such angels and spirits as receive from the Lord alone more enlightenment than others.

This consociation with angels and spirits is effected through the rite of the imposition of hands, which is introduced into the ceremony of ordination; and which is the correspondential sign of the transfer of the Holy Spirit; as appears from what follows:--

Communications of the mind are effected through the touch of the hands, because the hands are a mans ultimates, and because the first things of man are at the same time in his last things or in his ultimates; for by this means all the intermediate things belonging both to the body and the mind are kept in unbroken connection. Hence it is that the Lord touched infants(Matt. xvii., 6; Mark x., 13, 16) and that He also healed the sick by the touch and that those also were healed who touched Him. Hence also it is that ordinations into the priesthood are effected at the present day by the imposition of the hands (C. L. 396).

Through the rite of ordination, therefore, ministers as to their minds are associated with such spirits and angels, as are more than others in the good of the ministerial office--that is, in the love of saving souls, and as, at the same time, receive from the Lord alone more enlightenment than others.

539

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 540

This enlightenment the ministers of the gospel enjoy, while they are engaged in the performance of the duties of their office; but when they act in their private capacity, and in their capacity as members of the state, then they act from the enlightenment which is theirs, by virtue of their own regenerate life.

From this, however, it follows that the ministers of the Church have a twofold character; their official and their private character belongs to the Lord, because the ministerial office is representative of the Lord in the work of saving souls; but their private character is their own. In ordinations, the representative character of the priesthood, supersedes altogether the private character of the minister. In this representative character the Lord is present with the ordaining ministers of the Church when they introduce candidates into the ministerial office through the gate of ordination; and through the representative character of the ordaining minister, the Lord conveys the Holy Spirit to the person ordained. Concerning this communication of the Holy Spirit we read:--

The Holy [influence] which is understood by the Holy Spirit, is not communicated by one man to another, but it is communicated by the Lord through one man to another man (Canons, Holy Spirit, iv. 5).

And again:--

The Divine which is understood by the Holy Spirit, proceeds from the Lord through the clergy to the laity, through preachings, according to the doctrine of the truth received therefrom. Also, through the sacrament of the Holy Supper, according to repentance before it (Ibid. 8, 9).

As the doctrine of the Church through the special influx of the Holy Spirit into the minds of the ministers by virtue of their ordination, is enlightened in their minds even beyond the light in which they are able to be by virtue of the good which is theirs by regeneration; as they are thus specially protected by the Lord against evils and falsities, while they are in the exercise of the duties of their office, we read concerning them in conclusion:--

540

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 541

Good can be insinuated into another by any one in the country, but not truth, except by those who are teaching ministers. If others do so, heresies spring up, and the Church is disturbed, and torn to pieces (A. C. 6822).

This closes the important subject of enlightenment, as set forth by Swedenborg in the doctrines of the New Church. This enlightenment is the crowning state of regeneration; and, therefore, with the doctrine of enlightenment, the doctrine of regeneration also is brought to a close; that is, the doctrine of the regeneration of the spiritual or fallen man. The spiritual man, however, may continue the course of his regeneration until he reaches the seventh day--the seventh state of the regenerate life, which is called the celestial state. But as the regeneration of the celestial man, in the letter of the Divine Word, has a special chapter devoted to it-chapter ii. of Genesisso also, in our present work, we shall devote a special article to the Doctrine of the Celestial Man.

k. The Doctrine of the Celestial Man.

365. The man who by birth is in a state of order, is called celestial. A man, however, is said to be in a state of order, when his will and understanding are perfectly united, and when the life of love and wisdom from the Lord flows immediately into his will-faculty, and from his will passes into his understanding, where it gives rise to the perception of the truth. Such was the quality of the man who belonged to the Most Ancient Church, called Adam, and wile figuratively dwelled is the garden of Eden. Of him we read:--

Man from the beginning was so created, that the will and understanding in him should make a one; so that he should not think anything but what he willed, nor will anything but what he thought.

541

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 542

Such is the state with those who are celestial, and it was so in the celestial Church, called Man, or Adam (A. C. 2930).

Again:--

With the celestial, good itself is implanted in their will-part, and from thence light with them passed into their intellectual part (A. C. 2715).

And again:--

When a mans will-part is of such a character that it is able to receive the rays of the celestial flame, his Intellectual is enlightened; and from love he knows and perceives all things which are truths of faith (A. C. 1043).

We read further:--

The men of the celestial Church are such that they perceive all the truths and goods of heaven from the Lord through influx into their interiors whence they see truths and goods interiorly in themselves as though they were inborn; and they have no need to learn them by a posterior way, and to enrich the memory therewith. Thus neither do they reason about truths, whether a thing be so or not so. For he who sees truths within himself, does not reason; because reasoning implies a doubt whether a thing is so. This also is the reason why the celestial never mention faith; for faith implies something the unknown, which nevertheless must be believed, although not seen (A. E. 730).

366. The internal, and external man with the celestial man are thoroughly conjoined, so that the external man corresponds to the internal. But the result of this correspondence is, that with him light from the internal man passes at once into the sensual and corporeal degree of the external man, where it is received by the impressions which enter through the bodily senses; these sensuous impressions, however, by the reception of the light from within, become, as it were, the mirrors and reflections of the truths which are perceived by the enlightened understanding of the internal man. The external man, with the celestial man, is therefore in a state of correspondence with the internal man, down to the very sensual degree, which yields all unquestioned obedience to the goods and truths willed and perceived by the internal man.

542

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 543

We thus read further:--

The order of life with the celestial man is, that the Lord through love and the faith of lore flows into his intellectual, rational and scientific things; and since there is no combat, he perceives that a thing is so.... Such order, that is, such a man is called a garden in Eden eastwards.... The state of that man is then, that he is with the angels in heaven, and is, as it were, one with them. For man was so created that, while living on earth, he is at the same time in heaven. All his thoughts, and the ideas of his thoughts, yea, his very words and actions, in which is contained what is celestial and spiritual are open, and they continue open even to the Lord. For in every one is the Lords life, which enables him to have perception (A. C. 99).

And again:--

In the Most Ancient celestial man the sensual things of the body were such as to obey, and to be subservient to the internal man. Beyond this they did not care for these things (A. C. 243).

That the mirroring, in the sensuous impressions of the external man, of the heavenly truths perceived by the internal man, constitutes the basis of the perception of heavenly truths in the world of nature, appears from what follows:--

A man sees interior things in the sensual things which belong to the exterior Natural, almost in the same may in which he sees affections in the face, and still more interior affections in the eyes. Apart from such an interior face, or apart from such a plane, a man could not at all think in the body of such things as are beyond the impressions of the senses; for he sees them there, as a man sees the affections and thoughts of another in his face, when he does not pay any attention to the face itself; and also as he hears another talking when he does not pay any attention to his words, but to the meaning of his speech--the very speech of the words being the plane, wherein that meaning is contained (A. C. 5166).

In order, however, that the sensual degree of the external man may thus mirror heavenly truths, the whole of the external man must he in a state of correspondence with the internal man, and to be most intimately conjoined with it; as is the case with the celestial man.

543

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 544

We thus read:--

The rational mind, that is, the interior will and the interior understanding with man, ought to represent itself in his natural mind, as this latter main represents itself in the face and its expressioneven to such a degree, that as the face is the expression of the natural mind, so the natural mind ought to be the expression of the rational mind. When there is a state of conjunction, as in the case of those who have been regenerated, then whatever a man wills and thinks interiorly in the Rational, renders itself visible in his natural mind, which in its turn manifests itself in the face. Of this character is the face of the angels; and of this character was the face of the Most Ancient people, who were celestial men. For they were not afraid to let others know their ends and intentions; because they only intended good. He who suffers himself to be led by the Lord, never intends and thinks anything (A. C. 3573).

367. With the spiritual man, that is, with the man born with hereditary evil, who has been regenerated as far as the sixth day of creation, the external man, as we have seen above (no. 318, at p. 464 et seq.) is reduced into a state of correspondence, so far as its two higher degrees, namely, the rational and the interior natural, are concerned; but the lowest, i. e., the sensual degree, is not regenerated with him although it is reduced into a state of obedience, and hence of compliance. With the celestial man, however, the sensual degree is in a state of order, and hence of correspondence as well; and inasmuch as he perceives that a thing is so; by which is meant that he enjoys the perception of the celestial man. But the perception of the celestial man, as we have also seen, comes into existence when the sight of his internal man is introduced into the sight of his external manthat is, into the sight of those things which, through the senses of the body, are conveyed into the mans interior sensory; and, further, when the truths which are perceived by the internal man are mirrored or reflected in the objects which are received by the external man from the natural world.

544

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 545

Concerning this bringing down, or this leading forth, of the sight of the internal man so that it sees internal in external things, which takes place with the celestial man, we read as follows:--

The case with the sight of the interior or inward man when from external he sees internal things, is as follows. Internal things are led forth, when anyone with the eyes of his body beholds the starry heaven, and from it thinks of the Lords Kingdom. Whenever a man sees anything with his eyes, and as it were, does not see the things which he sees, but from them sees, or thinks of, those things which belong to the Church or to heaven, then his interior sight, that is, the sight of his spirit or of his soul, is led forth without. The eye itself in reality is nothing else than the sight of the spirit led forth without; and indeed chiefly for this end that a man from things external may see internal things; that is, that from the objects in this world he may constantly reflect on those things which are in the other world; for it is for the sake of that world that he lives in this. The sight of the Most Ancient Church was of this description; such also is the sight of the angels who are with the man; and such was the Lords sight (A. C. 1806).

Again we read:--

A man beholds internal from external things, when he views the sky, and does not think at all of the starry heaven, but of the angelic heaven and when on beholding the sun, he does not think of the sun but of the Lord who is the Sun of heaven and likewise, when he contemplates the moon and the stars. Yea, when such a man beholds the immensity of heaven, he does not think of its immensity, but of the immense and infinite power of the Lord; so with the rest--for there is nothing but what is representative. In like manner he regards the things on earth: when he beholds the rise of the day, he does not think of the sun-rise, but of the rise of all things from the Lord, and of the progression into the full day of wisdom. Again, when he sees gardens, orchards, and flower-beds, his eye does not dwell on any tree, or its blossoms, foliage, and fruit, but upon the heavenly things which they represent; nor upon any flower its beauty and charm, but upon those things which are represented by flowers in the other life; for there is nothing beautiful and delightful, either in the sky or on the earth, which is not representative of the kingdom of the Lord (A. C. 1807).

545

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 546

368. Men at the present time, and even those who have made a thorough study of the doctrines of the New Church and of the subject of correspondences have to make a considerable effort with their minds, in order to realize, when in the midst of the things of this world the spiritual signification of only a few of those things which strike their bodily senses. For even should they be progressing in their regeneration, and should they, by the Divine Mercy, have reached the fourth, fifth, or even the sixth day of creation, there are scarcely any at the present time with whom also the sensual degree of their external man has been regenerated. And yet only in the case of these can the sight of their internal man, and determine the same. The rest are too much engrossed by the outward appearance of things, and the affairs of this world, so that it becomes irksome and difficult for them to raise their eyes at all to heaven, so long as the things of this world claim their attention. On this subject we read:--

It may be known to every one that the general idea governs all particulars, and hence all the objects of the senses, both those that are seen, and those that are heard and indeed to such a degree that these objects are not cared for, except so far as they flow into the general idea entertained by a person. When thus any one is glad in his mind, everything that he sees and hears, appears to him as though it were joyful and smiling; while to him who is of a sad mind, everything that he hears and sees, appears sad and painful. Thus it is in all other cases. For the general affection and causes each single thing to be seen and heard in the general affection; the rest does not appear and it is even as though it were absent, or of no account. Thus it was with the member of the Most Ancient Church; whatever he saw with his eyes was to him heavenly; and hence each and all things with him were, as it were, living (A. C. 920).

We read further:--

The Most Ancient Church which was celestial, looked upon all the earthly and worldly, and also upon all the bodily things, whichever became with them objects of the senses, as merely dead things.

546

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 547

But, because each and all things in the world present some idea of the Lords kingdom, and thus of things celestial and spiritual, therefore, when the members of that Church saw, or apprehended by any of their senses, such worldly things, they did not think from them, but by them, as means. Dead things, with them, thus became living (A. C. 1400).

And again:--

To the Most Ancient people who were celestial men, whatever they apprehended with any of their senses, was a means for thinking concerning those things which are the Lords, and thus concerning the lord and His kingdom. The delight which they derived from worldly and earthly things was from that source. Yea, even when they beheld the lowest and ultimate things of nature, these things appeared before their eyes as though alive. For the life, from which these things [originally] descended, was in their internal sight and perception; and the things which were presented before their eyes were like images of that life; and these images, though inanimate still became animate for them, in this manner (A. C. 3702).

369. Further particulars concerning the character of the perception which was enjoyed by the Most Ancient people, and, therefore, which is enjoyed by the celestial man, are contained in what follows:--

Because the members of the Most Ancient Church were angelic, internal men, they indeed become sensible of the external things belonging to the body and the world; but they did not care for them. In each single object of the senses they perceived something Divine and heavenly; as for example: When they saw a high mountain, they did not lay hold of the idea of a mountain, but of height; and from height they perceived heaven and the Lord. On this account it was that the Lord was said to dwell in the Highest, and was also called the Most High and the Most Exalted; and that worship was afterwards celebrated on high mountains. Again, when they perceived the morning, they did not perceive the morning the day itself, but what is celestial, which is like the morning, and the day-dawn in the mind. On this account the Lord was called Morning, and also Day-spring. With a tree, its fruit and leaves, the case was the same; for the trees themselves they did not care at all; but in them they saw, as it were, a representation of man: in the fruits they perceived love and wisdom, and in the leaves faith.

547

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 548

Hence also the member of the Church was not only likened to a tree, and to a paradise, and the things with him, to fruits and leaves but he was also called so. The case is so with those who are in the angelic idea (A. C. 920).

And again:--

The Most Ancient people in each and all things, as in hills, open fields, gardens, groves and forests in tilled grounds and in fields covered with grain, in trees of every kind, in animals of every kind, and in the luminaries of heaven. saw something representative and significative of the Lords kingdom but they never dwelled with their eyes, and still less with their minds, on these objects, which were with them means for thinking of the celestial and spiritual things of the Lords kingdom; and even to such a degree that there was nothing in universal nature but served them in such a capacity (A. C. 2722).

But in order to place the perceptive power of the celestial man, as compared with that of the man at the present time into a still clearer light, let the letter of the Divine Word serve as an instance, as in the following passage:--

If a man of the Most Ancient Church had read the historical or prophetic Word, without any previous instruction, and without any explanation, he would have seen its spiritual meaning, and even to such a degree, that the celestial and spiritual things of the internal sense would have come up at once, and scarcely anything of the literal sense: the internal sense would thus have been with him in clearness, and the literal sense in obscurity. It would have been like one who hears another speaking and lays to heart only his meaning and does not attend to the words of the speaker (A. C. 4403).

370. From the fact that the men of the celestial Church perceive all the truths and goods of heaven from the Lord through influx into their interiors (A. E. 739), it does not follow, however, that they receive no truth whatever through any other channel. On the contrary, the men of the Most Ancient Church received instruction in the things pertaining to the Lords kingdom and to the Lord Himself, by association with the angels of heaven, and also through dreams and visions immediately from the Lord.

548

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 549

With regard to their association with the angels of heaven, we learn, first of all, that they were able to hold such intercourse, because they were in the love of the Lord and of the neighbor, and because, secondly, they enjoyed internal respiration. On this subject we read:--

In the Most Ancient Church they had communication with the angels, because their interior, that is, their spiritual man, by means of internal respiration, was conjoined with heaven; and because the love to the Lord and the love towards the neighbor have with them such a communication; for thus a man is conjoined with the angels through their veriest life, which consists in such a love (A. C. 1121).

Again:--

In the Most Ancient Church they had internal respiration, and only tacit external respiration (A. C. 607).

And further:--

Their respiration was varied according to the state of their love and faith in the Lord; and since they had communication with heaven, it could not be otherwise; for they respired with the angels with whom they had intercourse. The angels have a respiration to which the internal respiration in man corresponds, and it is varied with them in a similar manner (A. C. 1119).

Hence also we further read:--

The men of the Most Ancient Church perceived the state of love and faith through the states of respiration (A. C. 97).

By becoming conjoined with the angels through the life of the love of the Lord and of the neighbor, and through respiration with them, the members of the Most Ancient Church were lifted almost entirely out of their bodies, and in their minds were able to accompany the angels during periodical visits which they were able to make to heaven. We thus read:--

The angels were then [in those Ancient times] able to speak with men, and to take the minds of the men (which were almost separated from their bodily parts) with them into heaven, and to lead them about there;

549

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 550

and to show them the magnificent and blessed things of heaven, and also to communicate to them their felicities and delights (A. C. 8118).

In a state similar to that of the celestial men of the Most Ancient Church, were the prophets when they saw the wonderful things of the spiritual world as appears from what follows:--

An angel was sent by the Lord to John [the Revelator] in order that the latter might he kept in the state of the spirit, and that the angel might show to him in that state the things which he saw. For whatever things John saw, he did not see with the eyes of his body, but with those of his spirit; ... and into such a state, except through angels who are closely adjoined to the man, and who superinduce their own spiritual state on the interiors of the mans mind. By such means, indeed, a man is raised into the light of heaven, and in the light he sees the things which are in heaven, and not those which are in the world. In a state similar to this Ezekiel, Zechariah, Daniel, and other prophets, were at times (A. R. 945). See also above 9p. 82, no. 66) where the character of Swedenborgs spiritual sight is described.

371. To this circumstance, namely, that the celestial men of the Most Ancient Church, while in this world, were able to hold converse with the angels of heaven, was also due in part their faculty of seeing spiritual in natural things. For by their intercourse with the angels they were accustomed to view the objects in the natural world from the angelic point of view. We thus read:--

The men of the Most Ancient Church were of such a character that they conversed with the angels of heaven; and they were able to do so through correspondences. Hence the quality of their wisdom became such, that whenever they saw anything on earth they thought of it not only naturally, but also spiritually, and thus also in conjunction with the angels of heaven (T. C. R. 202).

Again we read:--

Because the members of the Most Ancient Church were celestial men and had intercourse with the angels, all the things which they saw or apprehended with any sense were to them representative and significative of the celestial and spiritual things which were in the Lords kingdom:

550

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 551

so that they indeed saw the worldly or earthly things, and apprehended them with some sense, but from them and through them they thought of celestial and spiritual things. Thus, and not otherwise, they were able to converse with the angels. For when the things which with the angels are celestial and spiritual come to man, they fall into those things which are with the man
(A. C. 2896).

It is plain from this that the angels were able to communicate with the men of the Most Ancient Church by correspondences; and that the knowledge of correspondences on the part of the members of that Church enabled them to commune with the angels.

Another channel through which the members of the Most Ancient Church received information about heavenly and Divine things, was through dreams and visions from the Lord. On this subject we read:--

The men of the Most Ancient Church had the knowledges of true faith through revelations; for they conversed with the Lord and with the angels; and they received instruction through visions and dreams which to them were most delightful and paradisaical (A. C. 128).

And again:--

The men of the Most Ancient Church had most delightful dreams, and besides they had visions. It was also insinuated into them what they signified (A. C. 1122).

372. As regards the instruction which the celestial men of the Most Ancient Church received by their intercourse with the angels, and by dreams and visions from the Lord, this information passed with them at once into their love, that is, into their will; and it was not received first in the memory, and thus by the understanding, as is the case with the spiritual men, that is, with those who are not born into a state of order. On this subject we read:--

In each kingdom, in the celestial as well as in the spiritual, good is implanted through truth....

551

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 552

But with those who are in the celestial kingdom truth does not become a matter of knowledge, nor of faith, nor of conscience; but the reception takes place in the good of love, and so far as they live according to the truth, it becomes perception which increases and is perfected with them according to their love. This takes place from day to day, without their knowing anything about it, almost as is the case with children. The reason of their not knowing anything about it is, that truth with them does not remain in the memory as a matter of knowledge, nor does it remain as a matter of the understanding in the thought, but it passes at once into the will-part, and becomes a matter of life. Wherefore they do not see the truth, but perceive it [inwardly], and the amount and quality of their perception is in exact proportion to their good love, from the Lord towards the Lord. Hence there is a great difference among the celestials (A. C. 10,124).

As truth is the form of good, and faith the form of love, therefore faith is a quantity which is originally included in the love, and may be developed out of it. If, therefore, a man is in a state of love, that is, if he is in the love to the Lord, and in the love towards the neighbor; and if his will-faculty is conjoined with his intellectual faculty, as is the case with the celestial man, then faith, that is, the truths of faith, are able to be developed out of that mans love, by influx from the Lord. But in order that this may be done, the understanding has first to be prepared, by the insemination, through outward channels, of the general truths of faith. On this subject we read:--

If man were without hereditary evil, he would be born into Divine order itself; namely into the love to the Lord, and the love towards the neighbor; everything of faith, in this case, would be implanted in that love.... The sons of the Most Ancient Church were almost born thus; namely, into the affections of good and into the affections of the truth; wherefore, in the very affections with them there was everything belonging to good and to truth which the doctrine of faith teaches. Nevertheless, in the course of time by instruction, experience, inspiration and revelation it was given them to become acquainted with all the things of faith, to which they immediately assented interiorly, so as to have a perception of those things which agreed with their affection (Diar. Minus, nos. 4635, 4636).

552

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 553

The method by which the members of the Most Ancient Church acquired Divine Truth by instruction from without, was as follows:--

The Most Ancient Church had an immediate revelation through consort with spirits and angels, and also through visions and dreams from the Lord, Through such means it was given them to know in a general manner what is good and true; and after they had acquired a general knowledge of these things, these general principles were confirmed by innumerable things, as it were, through perceptions. These innumerable things were the particulars and singulars of the generals to which they referred. Thus general principles, as it were, were confirmed daily. Whatever did not agree with these generals, they perceived not to be so; and whatever agreed, they perceived to be so. Such also is the state of the celestial angels. The general principles, as it were, of the Most Ancient Church were heavenly nod eternal truths; as for instance, that the Lord reigns the universe; that all good and truth is from the Lord; that all life is from the Lord; that mans self is nothing but evil and that in itself it is dead; besides other similar things. The perception of the innumerable things through which these things were confirmed, and which harmonized with them, they had from the Lord. Love with them was the principal thing of faith; through love it was given them to perceive from the Lord whatever was of faith. Thus faith with them was love (A. C. 597).

And again:--

The man of the Most Ancient Church had indeed revelations, through which he was to be initiated from childhood into the perception of goods and truths; but because these revelations were inseminated in his will-part, he perceived innumerable things without fresh instruction. He perceived them so that from one general he learned from the Lord particulars and singulars which, at the present day, have to be learned, and thus known by men; and yet they scarcely know the thousandth part of them (A. C. 895).

373. Truth with the celestial men of the Most Ancient Church was thus developed out of the good of the love of the Lord, when that good with them flowed from the will into the understanding, and assumed shape and form there; for truth is essentially the form of good.

553

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 554

Primarily, the celestial man is in the affection of Good, and not in the affection of the truth; therefore, also, he regards the knowledge of the truth as a mere means for arriving at a state of usefulness, and hence as a means by which he is able to do good and to become good. Hence, also, the knowledge of the truth which is communicated to the celestial man by an immediate influx from the Lord is altogether according to the intensity of his love of use. Wherefore, the celestial man enjoys perception from the Lord in the exact proportion to his love of usefulness. On this subject we read:--

The celestial are in the affection of good, the spiritual in the affection of the truth (A. C. 2078).

And again:--

The perceptive faculty of the Most Ancient Church consisted not only in their perceiving what good and truth are but also in the felicity and in the delight of doing good. Apart from the felicity and the delight of doing good, the perceptive faculty is not living; for it lives therefrom. The life of love, and of the faith flowing from it, such as was that of the Most Ancient Church, is life while in use; that is, it is in the good and in the truth of use. Life is given by the Lord from use, through use, and according to use.... Herein the members of that Church were likenesses of the Lord, wherefore, also, in the matters of perception they became images. The perceptive faculty consists in knowing what good and truth are, and hence in knowing what belongs to faith. He who is in a state of love is not delighted by knowing, but by doing, good and truth, that is, by being of use (A. C. 603).

374. The truths which the members of the Most Ancient Church learned from their various sources of information, and which were confirmed in their minds by perception from the Lord, constituted with them their Word, that is, the Divine Law. We thus read:--

In the Most Ancient time, when the Church was celestial, they had no Word; for the men of that Church had the Word written in their hearts. Thus the Lord taught them immediately through heaven what good is, and from good what truth is; and He granted them to have perception from love and charity, and to know both good and truth from revelation.

554

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 555

The Lord was for them their veriest Word (A. C. 3422).

And again:--

The Word in the Most Ancient Church, before the flood, was not a written Word, but it was revealed to everyone who was of the Church. For they were celestial men, and thus were in the perception of good and truth, and like the angels, with whom they also had communication. Thus the Word was written in their hearts (A. C. 2896).

Again we read:--

In the Most Ancient Church they had the Law inscribed upon themselves, because they were in the love towards the Lord and in the love towards their neighbor. For whatever was then dictated to them by laws, was in accordance with their perception, and what the law forbade them was in opposition to their perception. Neither did they entertain any doubt but that all human laws, just like the Divine laws, were then founded on the love towards the Lord and the love towards the neighbor, and that these laws have respect to those loves as to their fundamental. And since they had this fundamental in themselves from the Lord, therefore also they were in a condition to know all the things which flow therefrom (A. C. 1121).

375. From the fact, however, that the celestial men of the Most Ancient Church were born without hereditary evil, it does not follow that they were void of self or of proprium; and therefore did not need to be regenerated by the Lord. The celestial man of those times did require regeneration; for he had both an internal and an external man, and the internal man received an influx out of heaven, and the external man an influx from the world; by creation, also, the man then, even as he is now, was endowed with freedom and rationality, so that he might choose between these two kind of influxes. When the Most Ancient man decided in favor of the influx out of heaven, he then became regenerated, and in the correspondential language of Scripture he was said to eat of the tree of lives; but when the allows himself to be borne away by the influx from the natural world, he was said to eat of the tree of knowledge of good and evil.

555

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 556

From this it follows that so long as in full freedom he ate of the tree of lives, he enjoyed the perception of good and truth from the Lord in its fullness; but in the proportion in which he ate of the tree of knowledge of good and evil, in the same proportion he would lose his perceptive power, and his perception of the truth would therefore deteriorate, as appears from the following statement of Swedenborg:--

I have been informed by the Most Ancient people that the more they were in scientifics derived from those thing which constitute the objects of hearing and sight, in the same degree their perceptions were inferior; but the more they were raised from those scientifics to the heavenly things of charity and love, the more. interior their perceptions became, because they were nearer to the Lord (A. C. 2145).

As the men of the Most Ancient times had not only an internal, but also an external man, and as they enjoyed the faculties of freedom and rationality, therefore also they received the influences of the world and of the body, just as the men at the present time. But differently from the men at the present time, they were not allowed to cultivate the sciences of the natural world independently of the sciences, that is, of the knowledges of the spiritual world; and they were absolutely forbidden to approach the things of heaven by those of the natural world. We thus read:--

It is to be observed that the men of the Most Ancient Church were never forbidden to acquire the knowledges of good and truth out of heaven; for through these knowledges their intelligence and wisdom was perfected; nor were they forbidden to acquire for themselves the knowledges of good and truth from the world; for in this wise their natural man became imbued with science: but they were forbidden to regard knowledge a posteriori--by the posterior way; because it was granted to them to see all the things which appeared before their eyes, a priori--by the prior way. Seeing the world and the things which are in it, and deriving knowledges therefrom by a prior way, means regarding them from the light of heaven, and recognizing their quality by such means.

556

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 557

Therefore, also, through knowledges from the world they were able to confirm heavenly things, and thus to corroborate their wisdom. But they were forbidden to regard the knowledges from the world by the posterior may, which is done when conclusions are drawn from these things--thus in an inverted order--concerning heavenly things. This latter order is called by the learned the order of physical influx, or of natural influx, which does not under any condition take place into heavenly things. The men of the Most Ancient Church came into this latter order when they began to love worldly things more than heavenly things, and to become elated and boastful on the strength of their wisdom. On this ground it was that their posterity became sensual; and it was then that their sensual part, which is meant by the serpent, seduced them. The Sensual, however, is not willing to progress in any other, than the posterior way. This then is whit is signified by eating of the tree of knowledge of good and evil, of which tree they were forbidden to eat.

Their being permitted to acquire knowledges from the world, and to regard them by the prior way, is signified by Jehovah God causing to sprout forth from the ground every tree pleasant to the sight, and good for eating; for by trees are signified knowledges and perceptions; by what is pleasant or desirable to the sight, is meant being desirable for the understanding; and by that which is good for food is signified what is profitable for the nutrition of the mind. The knowledges of good and evil from the Lord from which came wisdom, and the knowledges of good and evil from the world from which came science or knowledge, were represented by the tree of lives, and the tree of the knowledge or the science of good and evil which was in the midst of the garden. That they were permitted to appropriate to themselves knowledges from every source, from heaven as well as from the world, provided they did not proceed in the inverted order, that is, provided they did not draw inferences from worldly in respect to heavenly things, and did not think from worldly concerning heavenly things, is signified by Jehovah commanding that they should eat of every tree of the garden, but not of the tree of knowledge of good and evil. That in this latter case heavenly wisdom and the Church would perish with them is signified by this, that in the day the man should eat thereof, dying he would die; by eating in the spiritual sense is meant appropriation. That they were seduced by the Sensual represented by the serpent, is on this ground that the sensual part of man reaches immediately into the world, and, therefore, becomes sensible of every pleasurable sensation and of every delight from the world, and is productive of fallacies therefrom and ignores and also rejects heavenly things (A. E. 739).

557

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 558

376. We see, therefore, that the celestial men of the Most Ancient Church were just as much in need of regeneration, as the men at the present time. For only when the reign of the internal man, and thus the reign of the Lord through the internal man, was thoroughly established in their external man, were they safe against infestations from the influences of their sensual part, in which resided their own self, i.e., their proprium. It is true that that part was not perverted then by hereditary evil; that, therefore, by heredity they were inclined to do the Lords will, and thus to love the neighbor. By birth, in fact, they were in a state of mutual love, but the presence of self, that is, of proprium in their case manifested itself by this, that by birth they were inclined to love the neighbor from their own self, and not from the Lord, and thus to love the neighbor from a natural, and not from a spiritual, that is a celestial love. They needed, therefore, revelation to teach them that they ought to love the neighbor from the Lord, and not from their own self; and that they ought to love him out of love to the Lord, and not out of that mutual love into which they were born. By regeneration, therefore, the men of the Most Ancient Church, as far as their natural man was concerned, were to come out of a state of mutual love into a state of love to the Lord. This was brought about by their learning the Divine Truth which came to them by immediate revelation, and by their applying it at once to the life. For this is the way in which the celestial man appropriates the Divine Truth--he hears it, loves it, and does it (as may be seen above, A. C. 10,124, in no. 372). That the celestial man by birth is in mutual love, and that by regeneration he passes from the good of mutual love into the good of the love to the Lord, is stated in what follows:--

558

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 559

When the celestial men were being reformed and regenerated they were introduced into the love to the Lord through charity towards the neighbor [i.e., through natural love] (A. C. 3122).

And again we read:--

The man of the celestial Church was regenerated as to his voluntary part, by putting on from infancy the good of charity [i. e., mutual love]; and after he had acquired its perception, he was led into the perception of the love to the Lord. By virtue of that love all the truths of faith appeared to him in the intellectual part, as in a mirror. With him the understanding and the will made altogether one mind; for they perceived in the understanding what was in their will. Herein consisted the integrity of the first man, by whom is signified the celestial Church (A. C. 5113).

The celestial man, and hence the man of the Most Ancient Church, was regenerated first through the knowledges of good, as appears from what follows:--

The Natural becomes new, or receives a corresponding life from the Rational; that is, it is regenerated only through doctrinals or the knowledges of good and truth the celestial man is regenerated first through the knowledges of good, but the spiritual man [that is, the man born with hereditary evil] first through the knowledges of the truth (A. C. 3802).

By this passage, so far as the celestial man is concerned, is meant that the celestial man, from infancy, through the knowledges of good, put on the good of charity or of mutual love. The perception of the good of mutual love, however, and afterwards the perception of the good of the love to the Lord, the celestial man acquired by an influx from the Lord, through his will into his understanding, and indeed in the following manner:--

The Lord flowed in with the members of the Most Ancient Church by an internal way, and taught them what good is. The varieties and differences of good with them were in the place of truths, and from them they knew what each and all things in the world represented in the Lords kingdom (A. C. 4489).

559

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 560

377. There is a difference between the good of mutual love and the good of charity towards the neighbor, which difference is explained in A. C. 3741, as follows:--

There are three kinds of goods, which follow in order: (1) the good of faith; (2) the good of charity towards the neighbor; (3) the good of the love to the Lord. The good of faith constitutes the ultimate or first heaven; the good of charity towards the neighbor, the middle or second heaven, and the good of the love to the Lord constitutes the inmost or third heaven. In order that this may be still better understood, it may be added that the heavens are distinguished into two kingdoms, namely, the celestial and the spiritual kingdoms, and each in kingdom there is an Internal and an External.
