In the Internal of the celestial kingdom are those who are in the love to the Lord and in its External those who are in good of mutual love. But in the Internal of the spiritual kingdom are they who are in the good of charity towards the neighbor; and in its External, they who are in the good of faith.

Concerning the difference which exists between the good of mutual love, and the good of charity towards the neighbor, we read further:--

The External of the celestial kingdom is the good of mutual love, and the Internal of the spiritual kingdom the good of charity towards the neighbor. But the good of mutual love is more interior then the good of charity towards the neighbor; for the former is from the Rational, and the latter from the Natural. Still, although the good of mutual love, which is the good of the External of the celestial kingdom, is interior, and the good of the External of the celestial kingdom, is interior and the good of charity towards the neighbor exterior, the Lord, nevertheless, conjoins those two kinds of good through a medium, and thereby conjoins the two kingdoms (A. C. 6435).

Although, therefore, there is such a merited distinction between the good of mutual love, and the good of charity towards the neighbor, nevertheless, this distinction was observed by Swedenborg only in the latter part of the Arcana Coelestia, beginning at no. 6435; as appears from what follows:--

In order that a distinction may be made between the external good of the celestial Church, and the internal good of the spiritual Church, the former good in the following pages will be called the good of mutual love, and the latter the good of charity towards the neighbor.

560

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 561

This distinction has not been observed in the preceding pages (A. C. 6435).

When, therefore, Swedenborg, in A. C. 3122 and 5113, which were quoted above, declares that when the celestial men were being reformed and regenerated they were introduced into the love of the Lord through charity towards the neighbor; by charity towards the neighbor he means there Mutual Love.

378. The celestial men, therefore--on account of their natural man not being tainted with hereditary evil--on being reformed and regenerated, were introduced at once into the good of mutual love, and thus into a good more interior than the good of charity towards the neighbor, which prevails in the second or middle heaven, and which is the interior good of the spiritual kingdom. Mutual love and the love of the Lord, again, are loves which with the celestial man prevail is his internal man, while his external man is in the delight of mutual love, as appears from what follows:--

It is, moreover, to be observed that both kingdom spiritual and the celestial, in the heavens, are tripartite. They have an inmost, a middle, and an external. The inmost of the celestial kingdom is the good of the love to the Lord; its middle the good of mutual love, which is the good proceeding thence and its external is the delight proceeding from that good. The two former are in the internal man with those who are in the Lords celestial kingdom; but the third is in the external man of the same (A. C. 9993).

From this it follows that the children in the Most Ancient Church who began their life in the external man were in the delight of mutual love, which prevails in the external man; and that from that delight they acquired the knowledges of good, by which they were to be introduced into the good of mutual love, and its perception. On this subject we read:--

The celestial man is regenerated first through the knowledges of good, and the spiritual man [that is, the man tainted with hereditary evil] through the knowledges of the truth.

561

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 562

Doctrinals, or the knowledges of good and truth cannot be communicated to the natural man, and hence they cannot be conjoined and appropriated to it, except through delights and pleasantnesses accommodated thereto; for they are insinuated by an external or sensuous way (A. C. 3808).

With regard to the state of the celestial man, after he had been regenerated, it is described in the Sacred Scripture by Adams abode in the garden of Eden. The intelligence which he received from the Lord is signified by the garden itself which Jehovah planted eastwards in Eden; his state of perception, by the trees which Jehovah caused to sprout forth; and his wisdom by the river which went out of Eden to water the garden, and which was parted and came into four heads. By the four rivers were represented four aspects of the mind of the celestial man; (1) the intelligence of the faith which flows from love, (2) the knowledge of all the things which belong to good and truth, (3) reason and (4) science. But the freedom of choice which the celestial man enjoyed was represented by the tree of lives in the middle of the garden, and the tree of the knowledge of good and evil.

379. Such then was the state of the celestial man in the Most Ancient Church--of the celestial man born without hereditary evil. We shall discuss next the celestial state of the man of the spiritual Church who in his regeneration reaches the seventh day of creation. The celestial state is represented by the Sabbath, or the seventh day of creation. In the celestial state the man of the spiritual Church no longer acts from truth in the first place, but from good; for the inversion of state has been accomplished in him, and from the good of love he is able now to perceive the truth of faith. In order that this state may be reached by the spiritual man, the regeneration of his external man has to progress downwards as far as the exterior natural or sensual degree;

562

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 563

and his internal man has to be opened in the direction of the love of the Lord; as is stated in what follows:--

After charity, which had been the end, [by the inversion of state] has become the beginning, new states commence from it. These new states progress in both directions namely, towards the interiors in the direction of the love to the Lord and also towards the exteriors in the direction of natural truths, and at last in that of sensual truths. All these are successively reduced into correspondence with the goods of charity and of love [i.e., of mutual love] in the Rational [i.e., in the internal man], and thus into heavenly order (A. C. 5122).

The regeneration of the exterior natural, or sensual degree, is accomplished by the bringing down of the good of remains from the interior into the sensual truths belonging to the exterior natural or sensual degree, so that the perceptions of the internal man can mirror themselves in these sensual truths, which are derived from the letter of the Divine Word.

With respect to the additional opening of the internal man with the member of the spiritual Church, it is opened as far as the celestial-spiritual degree in which prevails the good of mutual love, which is the External of the celestial kingdom. The man of the spiritual Church, however is not able to reach the good of the love of the Lord i.e., the Internal of the celestial kingdom; for this can be reached only by the celestial man who is born without hereditary evil. The good of love to the Lord, and thus the celestial degree is represented in the letter of the Word by Judah; but the good of mutual love, and hence the celestial-spiritual degree, by Joseph; while the good of charity towards the neighbor which constitutes the Internal of the spiritual kingdom is represented by Israel; and the good of faith which constitutes the External of the spiritual kingdom, by Jacob. The medium, however, which conjoins the External of the celestial kingdom with the Internal of the spiritual kingdom, and which is called the Spiritual of the Celestial is represented in the letter of the Word by Benjamin.

563

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 564

The good of mutual love, which is the External of the celestial kingdom, is the highest good that be reached by a member of the spiritual Church; as appears from what follows:--.

That the spiritual Church progresses as far as celestial mutual love is signified by the words even to the desire of the everlasting hills (Gen. xlix. 26) [in Jacobs blessing of Joseph].... Mutual love is that 1ove into which the spiritual Church ought to try to come (A. C. 6435).

380. The succession of degrees in the human mind from the longest degree of the external man to the highest degree of the internal man, is clearly exhibited in the following passage:--

The interiors in man which do not die succeed in the following manner: There is the Sensual, the Natural, the Spiritual-natural--these are of the external man. Afterwards comes the Celestial of the Spiritual, the Celestial, and the Inmost which has no name, because it receives immediately the good and truth which proceed from the Lord--these are of the internal man. The intermediate between the external and the internal man, is called the Spiritual-celestial (S. D. 4627).

But the succession of names by which these degrees are represented in the letter of the Divine Word, is given in the following passage:--

Between the third and the second heavens there is an intermediate heaven, through which there is conjunction. The internal third heaven [the Internal of the celestial kingdom] is represented by Judah; the external third heaven [the External of the celestial kingdom] by Joseph; the intermediate heaven by Benjamin. The internal second heaven [the Internal of the spiritual kingdom] is represented by Israel; the external second heaven [the External of the spiritual-kingdom] by Jacob. In the ultimate or first heaven are simple-minded spirits, to whom the exteriors of man, as, for instance, the cuticles, correspond (S. D. 4640).

381. In order that the spiritual man who by regeneration has arrived at the good of chary towards the neighbor from spiritual may become celestial, and thus that, in the process of his regeneration, from the sixth day of creation he may reach the seventh day, he has to pass through the Intermediate or Medium, called the Spiritual of the Celestial, which is represented by Benjamin.

564

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 565

On this subject we read:--

This Intermediate derives something from the Internal of the Natural [i.e., of the external man] represented by Israel, and from the External of the Rational [i.e., of the internal man], represented by Joseph. For that which is intermediate must derive something from either, otherwise it cannot serve as an intermediate. In order that any one from spiritual may become celestial, he must necessarily progress through this intermediate; for apart from this intermediate it is impossible to ascend into any higher parts (A. C. 4585).

The spiritual good represented by Israel is obtained by loving and doing the truth which is taught in the written Word of God. After the inversion of state has been accomplished, and the man out of the first state of regeneration has passed into the second state, this same spiritual good yearns for the perceptions of the truth from the Lord from within; and for this purpose it generates from itself a new truth which tends heavenwards. This new truth which is able to receive the perception of the truth belonging to the good of mutual love, and to transmit the same to the external man below, is represented by Benjamin. This new truth is generated from the Celestial-spiritual represented by Joseph, as a father, and from the Natural represented by Israel, as a mother (A. C. 5986). Concerning the character of this new truth which is thus born from the good represented by Israel, after the member of the spiritual Church has passed through the inversion of state, we read as follows:--

After a man through truth has arrived at good, he is Israel; and the truth which then flows from good, that is, the truth which the man then receives from the Lord, is the new truth represented by Benjamin. Good in the Natural fructifies itself through this truth, and it produces innumerable truths in which there is good. In this wise the Natural is regenerated, and then through fructifications, it becomes first like a tree with good fruits, and afterwards like a garden (A. C. 5804).

565

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 566

Again we read:--

This new truth alone causes a man to be a Church; for in this truth, or rather in these truths, there is life from good; that is, the man who is in the truths of faith from good, is a Church; but not that man who is in the truths of faith, and not yet in the good of charity (A. C. 5806).

We read further:--

This truth is not born before a mans has been regenerated. Then, through this truth conjoined with good, he receives a new element of life (A. C. 6812).

382. Concerning the relation of this new truth to the internal good--the good of mutual loverepresented by Joseph, we read as follows:-

The Truth which causes a man to be a Church, is that truth which flows from good. For when a man is in good, then from that good he sees truths, and perceives them, and thus believes that they are truths; but such is not at all the case while the man is not in good. Good is like a little flame, which gives light and illuminates, and causes a man to see, perceive, and believe the truth. For the affection of the truth from good determines the internal sight in that direction and withdraws it from the worldly and bodily things which induce darkness. Of this character is the truth represented by Benjamin.... This truth, however, must by all means be subjected to the internal good, represented by Joseph; for through internal good the Lord flows in, and imparts life to the truths which are below; and hence also to that truth which is derived from the spiritual good out of the Natural which is represented by Israel.... For unless this truth were subjected to internal good, so that by virtue of this submission it may receive within itself the influx of good, there would be no reception of the mercy which constantly flows in from the Lord through internal good, and thus there would be no medium. But unless there is a reception of Mercy, there also would be no conjunction (A. C. 5816)

Concerning the internal good represented by Joseph, into the enjoyment of which the member of the spiritual Church enters on the seventh day, we read further:--

566

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 567

Joseph represents internal good, and hence the internal Celestial; for by the Celestial is meant the good that proceeds from the lord (A. C. 5809).

Of this good we further read, that it imparts the faculty of perception to the truths in the Natural (A. C. 5877). And again we read:--

From the internal Celestial [represented by Joseph] there is a continual influx of good into the spiritual good [represented by Israel] and into the truths of the Church in the Natural; whence comes their life (A. C. 6106).

383. By this influx of the Celestial of the Spiritual represented by Joseph, into the external or natural man, after evils and falsities have been removed from it, there is generated in the natural man a new Voluntary and a new Intellectual which are represented by Josephs sons Mannasseh and Ephraim. This generation of anew Voluntary and a new Intellectual is the natural man by influx from within is the crown of the regeneration of the spiritual man, and through them the state of rest of the seventh day is firmly established in the natural man. Concerning this generation of a new Voluntary and a new Intellectual in the natural man, we read as follows:--

When, after the removal of evils, the man receives the influx of the very Celestial from the Lord, he then gets a new will and a new Intellectual. By virtue of the new will or Voluntary he feels a delight in doing good to the neighbor from no end of self; and by virtue of the new Intellectual he perceives a delight in learning what is good and true for their own sakes, and for the sake of life. Since this new Intellectual and this new Voluntary exist through an influx from the Lord, therefore, he who has been regenerated, acknowledges and believes that the good and truth by which he is affected are not from his own self but from the Lord and, further, that whatever is from self or proprium, is only evil (A. C. 6354).

Such then is the state of the spiritual man, after he, by regeneration even to the seventh day of creation, has become celestial-spiritual.

567

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 568

He is then, from the Lord, in that state of perception which is inherent in the good of mutual love; but he is not in the perception which belongs to the good of the love to the Lord. Still, we read of those who are celestial-spiritual, that many of them are preachers in the highest heavens (De Verbo, 3).

384. There are some at the present day who by birth are in a relatively celestial state, while others are born with a thoroughly spiritual disposition. The former would, with comparative ease, reach the seventh state of their regeneration, while the others would only with difficulty be able to step out of the state represented by the sixth day. We read concerning them as follows:--

Children are of various dispositions. There are some who are of that disposition or genius which characterizes the spiritual angels, while others are of that genius which marks the celestial angels. Children of a celestial genius appear in heaven at the right side, and those of a spiritual genius at the left side (H. H. 333).

And again:--

Those children who are of a celestial genius are well distinguished from those who are of a spiritual genius. The former think, speak, and act with softness, so that hardly anything else appears, except something flowing from love to the Lord and to other children, but the latter do not think, speak and act so softly, but something like a shaking of wings manifests itself in every thing with them. It also appears from their indignation, and so forth (H. H. 339).

Those of a relatively celestial genius, on reaching adult age, are represented, in the letter of the Word, by the Church in Pergamos (Rev. ii., 12, 17). Concerning those belonging to that Church who will be of the New Church, which is signified by the New Jerusalem, we read:--

They will be in wisdom, and will appropriate, the good of celestial love in works.... The truths of faith will be added to their works;

568

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 569

and they will be in the hidden wisdom which belongs to those of the third heaven. For, since they, while in the world, were in good works, and at the same time in the truths of doctrine, they excel in wisdom the other angels; yet, in hidden wisdom, because it is inscribed on their life, and not so much on their memory. For they are of such a character that they do not talk about the truths of doctrine, but do them and they do them because they know, and also see those truths when set forth by others. The good of love is appropriated by those who adjoin the truths of doctrine to good works, and the Lord also conjoins Himself with them, and thus imparts wisdom to them in their goods, which is meant by I will give them to eat of the hidden manna (A. R. 120).

Again, we read concerning them:--

They [the regenerated members of the Church in Pergamos] see truths from good alone, and are meant by those who have the law written on their hearts; concerning whom we read in Jeremiah (xxxi. 14), I will put my law in their inward parts, and in their heart I will write it. They shall teach no more every man his brother saying, Know the Lord; for they shall all know Me. Of such a character are all who are in the third heaven. They do not converse concerning truth from any memory, but they see truths clearly when they hear others conversing about them, and especially do they see them when reading the Word. The reason is, that they are in the very marriage of good and truth. Such is the character of those who in the world have approached the Lord alone, and who have done good works, because they are according to the truths of the Word (A. R. 121).

And again:--

Truths united with good, do not belong with them [the celestial men of the Church in Pergamos] to the memory, but are inscribed upon their life, and that which is inscribed only on the life, and not on the memory, does not appear to anyonenot even to themselves, except by this, that when they listen or read, they perceive whether a thing is true, and what is the Truth. For the interiors of their mind are open to the Lord; and because the Lord is in them, and He sees all things, therefore, He causes them to see, as of themselves; but still they know from their wisdom that they do not see truths from their own self, but from the Lord. But from all this it appears that they will be angels of the third heaven, if they read the Word, if they derive from it truths of doctrine, and approach the Lord (A. R. 123).

569

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 570

In this sketch of the spiritual condition of those who are understood by the Church in Pergamos, Swedenborg gives us a description of the celestial state of those who, at the present day, suffer themselves to be regenerated by the Lord as far as the seventh state; and he enables us to institute a comparison between their state, and that of the celestial men of the Most Ancient Church who were treated of in the first part of the present chapter.

The chief difference between these two is, that the latter, that is, the members of the Most Ancient Church, after they had reached the highestthe crowning-stateof their regeneration, were truly celestial men; while those of the spiritual Church who are represented by the Church in Pergamos, after reach the seventh state of their regeneration, are celestial-spiritualthat is, they are in a celestial state, yet without giving up their essentially spiritual character. Love, and thus good, is the prevailing element with both; but with the celestial proper, the good of the love to the Lord, by flowing from the will into the understanding, produces therein out of its own bosom the truth of faith. Truth, therefore, increases with them in proportion to their increase in good, that is, in love; or as it has been stated above, in proportion to the intensity of their love of use. With the celestial, consequently, the limit of their perceptive power is determined by the intensity of their love of use; while with the celestial-spiritual it is determined by the truth from the written Word which has penetrated with them into the interior recesses of their mind; and, indeed, in the form of that new truth which is represented by Benjamin, and which is conjoined with the good of mutual love represented by Joseph. With the celestial-spiritual, therefore, the basis of their perception are the correspondences contained in the written Word of God; while the celestial have the Word of God written in their hearts, and the basis of perception with them are all things which through the senses of the body have entered into their natural man.

570

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 571

The Word of God is also written into the heart with those who are celestial-spiritual; yet the Word of God with them is even the written Word of God which through the senses of the body has entered into their minds, and the teachings of which, by an application to the life, have been committed to their hearts. Of them we read, that they see truths clearly when they hear others conversing about them and that they especially see them when reading the Word. The celestial, however, see the truth while they are in the exercise of the celestial love of use; for it is then that the good of love passes from the will into the understanding, and generates truth there. The celestial, in fine, enjoy the perception which belongs to the good of the love to the Lord; while the celestial-spiritual enjoy that which is inherent in the good of mutual love.

385. From the whole of the Doctrine of the Celestial Man, as exhibited in the present chapter, it appears further that, according to Swedenborg, the perception of the celestial man can be enjoyed only by those who have reached the seventh stage of their regeneration. In the future, it is to be hoped, that there will be many among the members of the New Church, who will be in a state of perception from the Lord, by virtue of their having reached the seventh day of creation. Swedenborg, however, does not give us much hope that at the present day already there are any who, by virtue of their having attained to the celestial state, enjoy perception from the Lord. He says:--

Those who are being regenerated do not all reach the sixth state; but some, and indeed the greater part, arrive only at the first state; some attain simply to the second state; some to the third, fourth or fifth state, but rarely any to the sixth state; and scarcely any at all to the seventh state (A. C. 3).

571

SWEDENBORG AND THE DOCTRINES OF THE NEW CHURCH p. 572

Even those who by birth are in a relatively celestial state, and who after reaching adult age will spiritually belong to the Church in Pergamos, are not at all sure that in the end they will arrive at the seventh state of their regeneration; although compared with those who are of a purely spiritual character, they will pass more rapidly from one state of regeneration into the next. Those among them who do not reach the seventh state, on departing their life in this world, will be received in the celestial-natural division of the first heaven; concerning which heaven we read:--

The Divine which flows in from the Lord, and is received in the ultimate or first heaven, is called the Divine Natural. Yet because the Natural of that heaven is not like the Natural of the world, but has in it a Spiritual and a Celestial, therefore this last heaven is called spiritual-natural and celestial-natural; and the angels who are in it are called spiritual natural and celestial-natural... Those are called celestial natural who receive an influx out of the third or inmost heaven, which is the celestial heaven. The spiritual-natural and celestial-natural angels are distinct from each other; but still they constitute one heaven, because they are in one degree (H. H. 31).

Our exposition of Swedenborgs Doctrine of Regeneration is now at an end. We had intended to include in it the Doctrine of Worship and the Doctrine of Marriage, because these two subjects enter most intimately into the work of regeneration. But we reserve a discussion of these two doctrines for a future volume on the Doctrines taught by Swedenborg.
